Takes on an almost mythical quality with all this grey mist and slick mud invading more and more of the film as the runtime marches along. "Satellite" and his gang of children feel as though they live in a world just parallel to that of Agrin and her bastard son until the slightest graze intersects the two as the tragedy reaches its peak. The second half of this truly did feel like something out of folklore---the deathless child, the deep lake, the high cliffs...

Do I believe we need to be inundated with school shooting movies? No. Do I agree with a lot of the criticisms of this film? Also no. Two things can exist at the same time.Van Sant's bit of having practically no character development didn't bother me all that much, it feels like a Dunkirk-esque choice that leaves me feeling mostly meh. However, I do feel that the portrayal of the shooters' radicalization could've used a second read-through. Were we this clueless in 2003? The hatred these boys have didn't translate, they felt too much like kids playing war until all of the sudden they're psychopaths.

why aren't you crying?Perhaps we'd all like to be asking little Frida this. Your mother just died, you've been orphaned, why don't you cry? The silence is more unsettling. Instead you do bad things, you have no morals, nobody can safely touch you. The unspoken response: I want to go home, I hate god, I miss my mother. I have to leave, nobody loves me here. Simon captures the grief of this child so impressively, and Artigas gives one of the best child performances ever put to screen (in my book). Heartbreaking!

Really conflicted on how to rate this... Rossellini's experiences under Nazi occupied Rome obviously influence his view of the German people, but it's possible that the endless suffering here hinders the film. If Rossellini's Italians are rendered unable to communicate by the war and find themselves struggling to reinvent a dying country, then his Germans are totally stripped of humanity, already dead. None of the levity in something like Rome, Open City or even Paisan is present here: just ruins.

One of the cool things about David Lynch is that his early works maintain their power. Later works contain deeper levels of craft and complexity while plumbing the same psychosexual depths, but earlier movies like Blue Velvet still feel like a complete thesis. The spiritual successor to this, Twin Peaks, goes farther and looks closer, but never feels like it's coming from a place of filling in the gaps for an earlier exploration. Lumberton is a proto-Twin Peaks town inâ€¦

Saved almost entirely by Jim Broadbent and Helen Mirren, both of whom have enough native watchability to elevate this entry in the Magical Doofus genre from "kill it with fire" to "well, I'm okay with the fact that I watched that."This one's about Kempton Bunton, a real-life figure in the 1960s who attained some notoriety for being tried in the Old Bailey for stealing and then ransoming Goya's paintingPortrait of the Duke of Wellingtonas part of aâ€¦

Extraordinarily silly movie about brush salesman Migg Tweeny (Jack Oakie) who falls instantly in love with a woman named Angela (Susan Fleming) on what's apparently a routine business trip to the fictional country of Klopstokia. Angela (apparently every woman in Klopstokia is named Angela, while all the men are named George) happens to be the daughter of the country's president (W.C. Fields), a literal strongman looking for ways to prop up the failing economy. Hijinks ensue as Migg is taskedâ€¦

As a general rule I'm suspicious of artistic/commercial ventures that include an entire family. Comes across most of the time as exploitive and more than a touch culty, a feeling that's not helped by the current age of families constructed entirely around Pinterest personas and the like. It's hard to not be charmed by a family that makes horror movies together, though, and so I sought out my first Adams Family movie.Hellbender slots nicely into the ongoing moment thatâ€¦

If movies like Gold Diggers of 1933 are the apex of the Busby Berkeley delivery system, Footlight Parade nestles somewhere underneath those rarefied heights. The chassis is all right here, as James Cagney plays a producer who comically rushes to create prologue segments for movie theaters before his financial backers close in, all while his secretary (Joan Blondell) juggles all the details and keeps things afloat as the movie goes manically from stage to stage. The narrative portion of theâ€¦

Someone apparently wrote a review of this in one of the mainstream media outlets that criticized this for being non-universal in its storytelling, and coming across as being written for a specific audience that consisted of the writer and her immediate relations/friends. I'm not sure if that's what the review actually said, because it was pulled by the publication amidst a slew of apologies after the standard anger brigade showed up.Whatever that review said, it's true that this lacksâ€¦

There's something special about a gathering of three people. It's somehow, by default, a more free and easy exchange. You're not part of a two-person contract bound to hold up an end of a conversation, fill awkward silences, meet whatever level of intimacy is being expected given the context the situation, and generally not expected to be everything that persons needs in this particular moment. Instead there's a more fluid feeling to the room, the conversation can turn quicker, there'sâ€¦

Edward G. Robinson follows up Little Caesar in another crime story, this one an interesting-enough and much tamer iteration. Edward G plays Nick the Barber, a big gambling fish in a small town pond who makes his way to "the big city" to get into a big game and start building his legend.This one's notable for being the only time Robinson and James Cagney appeared in a film together; unfortunately, it's more of a footnote than an opportunity toâ€¦

There. That's how you do a piece of transgressive cinema.The stage is set for you right at the beginning. This story is taking place at a time and place in history where religion is not one of the many abstract concepts that get tossed into the collective psychosphere, to be subsumed into the larger cultural stew. Religion isthesocial framework, dominating how institutions are structured and thus shaping how reality flows from there. The young Benedetta shames someâ€¦
Video PSA found on a whim to watch something from South Sudan. As far as internet flotsam goes, "don't burn your wife to death" is about as sensible as these come, I suppose.

One of those movies where you get more out of it for its historical implications than the film itself, and of course watching Cagney be Cagney. The story is a now-familiar tale of a young man embracing the quick riches of a life of crime, although there are some sharper edges courtesy of the pre-Code era. Cops are shot, goons get got, and the ladies are hot, although you still get disclaimers about how crime doesn't pay. And for someâ€¦

Somewhat of a non-standard take on the refugee's tale here, focusing much more on the isolation of the experience and the effects it can have years after someone successfully makes it into another country. In a lot of ways that makes for a more compelling story, allowing for some gradation of human experience and not necessarily just a non-stop horrorshow of degradation as one is in the act of escaping life-threatening dangers. Though there is certainly a fair amount ofâ€¦

The Batman, part 4,354 in the Batman Extended Universe, has already been greenlit for two feature length sequels and two spin-off television series. Good news for these Batman-starved times, in which the lack of Batman products has left a Batman-shaped hole in our collective lives that we have unsuccessfully tried to fill with poor non-Batman substitutes like careers, children, or religion. Batman.How much longer are we going to do this, he asks while looking at the box office receipts.â€¦

Okay, I think I've watched enough biopics now. Kindly please hold off on making more for a while, we're all full up here. Thanks.While we're at it, please dial it back on the victim narratives. I get that this is "The Eyes of Tammy Faye" because it's based on the documentary and not the real life story, which makes a difference for some reason I can't be bothered to contemplate, but it should have been titled "The Crucifixion ofâ€¦

Helps to go into this knowing who you're dealing with. Michael Moriarty is a once-promising Hollywood B-lister who parlayed some early high-profile roles in movies like Bang the Drum Slowly into steady supporting role work in TV and film throughout the 80s, culminating in a prominent role in Law and Order. Deeming this productive existence too boring, Moriarty then blew up his career and left the show over a deranged one-sided wharrgarbl feud with then-Attorney General Janet Reno, going onâ€¦

Jaw dropping Busby Berkeley numbers sandwiched between radiant performances from the three main Gold Diggers (Joan Blondell, Ruby Keeler and Aline MacMahon) and some great Ginger Rogers scenes, laced with deliciously lascivious shots of scantily clad women and some of the great early Hollywood mugs like Ned Sparks. Really something for everyone here.The "scantily clad" angle gets really pushed here, with lots of scenes of tee-hee'ing young actresses frolicking in their apartment and quite a few costumes that areâ€¦

Comparing Princess Di to Anne Boleyn is fucking ridiculous. Leaving aside the complete failure of history that represents, the mind boggles at how overwrought that is. Itâ€™s like your teenager telling you that you might as well have sent them to Auschwitz when you make them stop texting at the table.Thatâ€™s the level of insight we have going on here. People are going on about how good Kristin Stewart is here and I donâ€™t have much to say aboutâ€¦

I have such a difficult time with these "now [INSERT GROUP HERE] is represented" movies. It's hard to reconcile the understanding that yes, people of all kinds should have their stories told, with the grating undercurrent of "see, [INSERT GROUP HERE] are actually people too" that these movies usually have. Rarely do these movies ever just consist of a good story that also has an example of a fully portrayed [INSERT GROUP HERE] character, which to me is true representation.â€¦

Paul Thomas Anderson is one of the four or five American directors working today that you could credibly call a master of the craft, so it's always tricky for a random internet guy such as myself to talk about this without sounding like a goof. When you get something from one of the masters you're mostly just grateful to be there when these come out. Then again I bitched plenty about West Side Story earlier this year.I don't usuallyâ€¦

Will Smith can indeed play people other than Will Smith. Whether this is up there with the best performances of the year, I'm not certain, but this was a well-constructed effort that packed some real emotion in it. Maybe I'm just a sucker for movies with dads and daughters.I wasn't expecting much out of a biopic/sports movie/social consciousness genre mashup, but the performances of the main members of the Williams family help to maximize the limited potential of thatâ€¦

This feels like a step back from Raw. That movie wasn't necessarily revolutionary, but it did some daring things on top of the sexual awakening chassis, and established Julia Ducournau's ability to film physical violence as well as any of the other modern French masters of that art. The body horror paired with the deceptively fresh-faced setting felt like a unique signature.Here, she leans way, way heavy on the Cronenberg, and I don't think it's an unfair comparison toâ€¦

Here's a slightly odd slow-cinema crime story set in the Romanian countryside. Thankfully, this isn't like five hours long as other intentionally slow efforts tend to be, but it also feels like there isn't much story there, as a result. A young man inherits his grandfather's country estate in the hinterlands, which has been kept empty for decades so that the grandfather's gang could use it for various nefarious purposes. He wants to sell it, the remaining gangsters don't wantâ€¦

For something that at heart is a morality tale, there's quite a bit of complexity here. The story revolves around Rahim (Amir Jadidi), a man in prison for debt who concocts a scheme on his two-day furlough to sell some gold coins found by his girlfriend, but backs out after his conscience gets the better of him and returns the lost merchandise. Local media picks up on his good deed, and the attention from that causes people to look aâ€¦

Iâ€™m not trying to be pithy or hyperbolic when I say that the extent of the background the producers did on this was to read a Wikipedia summary of the original TCM when they made this. I genuinely think that most of the people involved with this never saw the original. I donâ€™t know how else you end up with something that stuffs references and callbacks into a movie while also missing the feel entirely of the original. Itâ€™s likeâ€¦

movietitle: The Worst Person in the World
review: Thereâ€™s a distinction to be made between oppressive, society-driven expectations about what you should have accomplished by whatever arbitrary age weâ€™re talking about (30 in this case), and how mature someone should be by that point. Iâ€™m not going to judge anyone for not having kids, owning a house, having a career, or any of the other things that are much harder to do these days and arenâ€™t even things everyone should want. But I do expect a person toâ€¦

The temptation is to transpose the events of this movie onto the story of Uncle Vanya, which serves as the scaffolding of Drive My Car. That'd be a convenient Rosetta Stone to the lives of the characters here, and it would maybe demystify some of the interactions between folks if there was indeed a 1:1 resonance with the actors and the roles they've been assigned. That doesn't feel like Hamaguchi's intent, though, and regardless, most of the pleasure here isâ€¦

Both Abel Ferrara and Harvey Keitel are very close to the perfect expressions of their screen selves here. Ferrara, with ample chemical enhancement, constructs the apex New York hellscape that cinema had been building toward since the late 1960s. Keitel empties his toolbox in a completely gonzo performance where he hits nihilistic violence on one end of the wavelength and extreme vulnerability on the other. The resonance between these two meeting on this level of performance reverberates through the restâ€¦

This might have been fun had it been true to its nature as a spiritual DTV schlock exercise. There are glimpses of something worthwhile whenever the camera lovingly pans over the mangled bodies left behind by the movie's antler monster, which are a welcome opportunity for practical effects to come to the fore. Instead this is a weirdly incompetent effort with a ton of established names tied to it that takes itself way too seriously for something that's like aâ€¦

I don't know if Kenneth Branagh strikes anyone as a master of the art when it comes to film, although he inarguably has some high points in his career that'll stand as achievements in the craft. I do think that he is certainly aninstitutionin film, which is a different thing but really worthy of the same kind of respect.So when you watch Belfast, which is something of a culmination of Branagh's relationship with film, you're not seeingâ€¦

Credit to Nicole Kidman for even accepting this role in the first place. I can't imagine the sand it would take for someone to agree to play Lucille Ball, herself an incredibly gifted actor. They assist her by keeping the comic acting to a minimum, which would have been an unfair ask for anyone to replicate.That said, this is sporting three nominated performances and it's hard to argue that any of them are up to that level. Kidman isâ€¦

I just couldnâ€™t find much resonance with this one. Which is a little strange to me, since Iâ€™m fairly attuned to stories about ambivalent parenthood. It could be the target audience is people who havenâ€™t experienced those moments of parenthood firsthand, the ones where you think to yourself â€œwhy the hell did I do this,â€ and then stuff the feeling down for obvious reasons. Because in the end, I couldnâ€™t get much more out of this than â€œhereâ€™s a person,â€¦

Everyone has short memories, thus we all have to act surprised whenever Nicolas Cage does a movie where he's quietly restrained, as though he doesn't have a long track record going back decades demonstrating a wide range. I suppose it's good to remind people of stuff, again and again.Nic Cage stars as a recluse in the woods who makes his living selling truffles to Alex Wolff, a young and hustling purveyor of high-end ingredients to the Portland restaurant scene.â€¦

Neither fish nor fowl, which keeps this from being truly great. It isn't quite a polished Hollywood blockbuster, despite its A-list cast and clean production, but nor is it truly the grimy noir that del Toro wants it to be. I guess that's a general issue I have with his movies, which in turn is the same issue I have with the James Camerons and Steven Spielbergs of the world. Clean, competent, sometimes great productions that it's hard to feelâ€¦

For about an hour or so, this is a standard horror chassis with a below-average script and some incredibly goofy CGI sequences. It also opens with a random scumbag bashing his pregnant wife into a wall to the point of a TBI, which is fairly unpleasant and a little higher-octane than the rest of the movie warrants. Getting through this portion of the movie takes some work, especially the police scenes (which operate on the idea that the cops canâ€¦

Basically if someone made The Wailing, except bad. A monster vanquished by Buddha in times of antiquity returns because an archaeologist got angry and decided to unleash a portal to hell on everyone. Thus begins a series of actions taken for bewildering reasons that lead to a couple of monks fighting the monster, who possesses corpses in search of a lost relic that it needs to destroy to the world.The gore is mostly off screen, so thereâ€™s no realâ€¦

A Lubitsch remake of one of his earlier silents in which a stale marriage is interrupted with various infidelity hijinks. Melvyn Douglas plays a stuffy old insurance salesman, Merle Oberon plays his flighty, dissatisfied wife, and Burgess Meredith is a vainglorious pianist who makes a play for her.Not quite as top tier as some of Lubitschâ€™s greats, especially in the earlier going before things start getting wacky. The Merle Oberon character is also a little unfortunate since she comesâ€¦

In the sense that a barely comprehensible, niche franchise has been successfully adapted for a mainstream Hollywood production, for what most would consider the first time, this is certainly a triumph. The Dune books have never been my thing but I respect that achievement. Something on the order of the Lord of the Rings, if the second half of the story is pulled off well.I have the same feeling about this as I do about a Spielberg production. Which,â€¦

Does exactly what it says on the tin. A pretty straight up biopic of the Gucci family executed in a competent-but-not-spectacular fashion by stalwart Ridley Scott. At least with this one itâ€™s not a canonization and thus can be a little more fun than most of these, since itâ€™s covering a sordid and shocking event and the players therein.I always enjoy seeing Lady Gaga on screen, and sheâ€™s expectedly the main draw. The omnipresence of Adam Driver continues andâ€¦

An idyllic lakeside retreat frames an intricately told story of a man settling a few bits of personal business prior to getting married. The action is driven between Jerome (Jean-Claude Brialy) and old flame Aurora (Aurora Cornu), a writer who playfully goads Jerome into pursuing the daughter of a local landlady.Befitting the filmâ€™s vacation land setting, this moves at a leisurely pace, and through its characters goes in for a deep exploration of desire, the purpose of romantic dalliance,â€¦

movietitle: Munich â€“ The Edge of War
review: Interesting cinematic presentation of the revisionist view of Neville Chamberlainâ€™s historical legacy. Iâ€™m not sure if I entirely buy the premise that the Munich Agreement bought enough time to be the difference for an ultimate Allied victory, but I am of the view that Chamberlain takes way too much historical flack for the political realities of his time.Jeremy Irons performs to his usual high standard here and paints a believable portrait of a conflicted man. The underlying story ofâ€¦

Might be that Iâ€™m just the wrong person to ask about this movie, since Iâ€™m not really one for musicals as a general rule, and Rent especially just wasnâ€™t my thing. Still, this is suffused throughout with a sense of being way more charmed with its main character, a pre-fame Jonathan Larson, than anyone else possibly could be. Like other biopics itâ€™s a hagiography, and in this case one made by a theater person essentially canonizing one of their own.â€¦

A mostly tiresome morality play beset by a lot of really odd narrative choices that work against it a majority of the time. Starting with the choice to import a bullet-point list of #metoo topics into the Middle Ages and then construct the story in a superficial Rashomon device.The whole interesting thing about Rashomon is the subjective nature of whatâ€™s â€œtrueâ€ and how that changes based on personal viewpoint and the desire to fit a narrative to oneâ€™s ownâ€¦

movietitle: Jesus Shows You the Way to the Highway
review: I donâ€™t know what to make of this. Itâ€™s completely insane. Thatâ€™s not a reaction I have often.Like, this isnâ€™t just â€œman thatâ€™s some weird imagery how random lol.â€ This is a fully realized world that plays by its own internal and incomprehensible rules, which is impressive to set up. Thereâ€™s some stuff about the Cold War and cultural influence and whatever but it doesnâ€™t matter. Not really. This is a journey of a pizza-loving dwarf and his internetâ€¦

As a modern day blaxploitation flick, it ainâ€™t bad. Youâ€™d be forgiven for expecting maybe a little more given the A-list cast, and that was sort of a consistent feeling watching this. You keep waiting for this to hit a higher gear, with the sets, the personalities, the gunfights, and it never quite gets there.This probably could have used a better director. Jeymes Samuel is more known for being a musician, and parts of the movie feel very muchâ€¦

movietitle: His Majesty, the Scarecrow of Oz
review: The imaginative spirit of the Oz books first makes it onto the screen in 1914, courtesy of L. Frank Baum, the man himself, and the unfortunately ill-fated production company that he started for the purpose. The Oz franchise is interestingly ahead of its time in its attempts at being a multi-media empire; Baum supplemented his best-selling book series with stage plays, radio dramas, lectures, and three movies in 1914.The translation to the screen is a little imperfect, as variousâ€¦

Producer and writer Val Lewton concludes his run of budget RKO horror movies that were way better than anyone had a right to expect with Bedlam, a standard Karloff heel demonstration that's been given a little extra spice. Boris Karloff plays the villainous overseer of the the 18th century Bedlam mental institution, who takes exception to the criticism of his patron's latest girl, played by Anna Lee.I'll always have a place in my heart for the efficient, studio go-toâ€¦

All the fast-talkin' newsie hijinks you could want in a scandalous pre-Code package. Lee Tracy plays a Walter Winchell analogue, and the story follows his rise from hustling ad copy hack to nationally syndicated gossip columnist, specializing in the bedroom exploits of the rich and famous. Snappy jokes a plenty and a generally lighthearted good time as Lee Tracy feuds with a popular bandleader (played by then-newcomer Dick Powell), lays waste to everyone around him with the power of scandal,â€¦

This proves to be something of a frustrating and uncertain experience as Paul Thomas Anderson provides you with precious little ground to firmly stand on. Freddie Quell (Joaquin Phoenix) is an unreliable narrator as our protagonist and in addition to being a habitual liar is also delusional and prone to confabulation, as expressed both through his own dialogue and numerous sequences that are apparently dreams with no clear bounding lines between them and the other parts of the story. Lancasterâ€¦

Houses not doing what theyâ€™re supposed to do is a nicely effective channel for sending chills up the spine. Sometimes theyâ€™re haunted, sometimes they donâ€™t obey physical laws, sometimes they draw attention from unwanted parties. The house that serves as the throughline for our three part animated anthology in this case is a sinkhole for hopes and dreams, a theme thatâ€™a expressed well in all three segments.The first segment is probably the most disturbing of the three, detailing theâ€¦

Mary Pickford plies her well-refined kid sister act in a movie about a girl and her grandmother living in isolation out in the woods. Fanchon (Pickford) is a mischievous, forest spirit-like presence that becomes more interested in the affairs of the nearby town as she becomes a young woman. Melodrama and a romance ensue.Beautiful restoration for this one which is available for streaming through Amazon Prime, albeit with a soundtrack that is all right at times but veers intoâ€¦

Will Rogers vehicle, a story about a humane small-time judge who dispenses jokey wisdom and general humanity to the folks around him in his rural Kentucky town.The movie is fairly corny and plays like a version of To Kill a Mockingbird except everyoneâ€™s kind of racist, but it really is fascinating in a historical sense. Starting with this being a good demonstration of the Will Rogers spirit, and he does have an innate humanity that just makes you feelâ€¦

Clara Bow plays a bohemian socialite who scandalizes her old guy father by living it up in Greenwich Village. Old guy dispatches young hothead to go pressure her into coming back home, antics ensue.In terms of the movie itself, pure filler designed to show off Ms. Bow, though that's no sin given how easy she is to look at. Some fun scenes of partying in a New York speakeasy, and a really odd comedic side bit involving the young guy's assistant, a Buster Keaton stand-in that keeps pulling a gun on everyone, which provides more discordant notes than humor.

One of Umberto Lenzi's three contributions to the Italian cannibal film genre that he helped to create, alongside Man From Deep River (arguably the movie that kicked things off) and Cannibal Ferox. While you can see how movie producers and studios would be constantly talking to each other and poaching ideas back and forth as to what's going to make money, it's interesting just how specific a formula these movies are, despite the differences between the directors who made them.â€¦

Part of me thinks that one of main reasons Joel Coen directed his first solo feature after almost 40 years of collaboration with his brother Ethan was to wrong-foot everyone that came to see whatever he made. No matter how hard you try, you go into a Coen Brothers movie with a certain set of expectations, even when they're doing stuff supposedly against type like No Country for Old Men. You try to set that aside going into this movie,â€¦

Less a horror movie than a new EP from the synthwave band Boy Harsher. Be advised, Shudder browsers.Light fare that struggles at times to justify the presence of the alleged premise; a woman covered in blood runs around in the woods committing acts of violence, to an unknown purpose, and what will she do next. Mostly, a collection of Boy Harsher music videos, with interstitial segments involving the titular runner doing stuff for some reason.The music videos aren'tâ€¦

movietitle: Valerie and Her Week of Wonders
review: I'm not sure when it was that fairy tales were stripped of their darker undertones and sanitized for more palatable consumption, or whether that's a general thing or more localized. Someone somewhere has written books on that that, but it does feel like we do everyone a disservice when we pretend that there's a clear, dividing line between childhood and adulthood. And a lot of that feels like it's mostly to avoid awkward subjects and conversations.This movie is interesting,â€¦

Decided to just take my medicine now, instead of waiting for this to get nominated for Best Picture in a few months and being forced into watching it anyway. Yes, I know that I'm not technically forced into doing that. Anyway.Adam McKay continues his transformation into the left wing Dinesh D'Souza with this one. A comet stands in for climate change/COVID/the erosion of democracy etc. etc. and for two long, punishing hours, everyone ignores it because lol corporations orâ€¦

And now, to cram some cowboys into a movie with witches. Joe R. Lansdale serves as executive producer here, though unfortunately it doesn't look like he had much of a hand in the screenwriting. Beyond the Lansdale-y premise, this is pretty standard stuff. An outlaw gang gets more than they bargained for on a train heist, and runs afoul of a coven of witches. Neither the outlaws nor the witches get much depth to them, even with a brotherly loveâ€¦

A pleasingly bleak window into an old hoodâ€™s creaky world of poorly-weighed risk. â€œThe Friends of Eddie Coyleâ€ is apparent early as an ironic title for the events that make up the story. Eddie (a late-stage Robert Mitchum) is a low-level con who acts as a middleman for various criminal enterprises, lately as a supplier of guns for bank robberies. Eddie, of course, has no friends, just a collection of people who will do jobs with him on occasion andâ€¦

Good old, stick-to-yer-ribs serving of Western cinema. A spare production that leaves the set pieces and sweeping vistas at home in favor of Tim Blake Nelson brooding in the hills. Location-wise, about which I'm particular, the landscape of Tennessee (where this was shot) ain't Oklahoma (where this is set), but it's fine. Not nearly as jarring as watching New Zealand stand in for Montana earlier this year.It's a good character study for Nelson, playing a hard, wiry farmer whoâ€¦

Couple of weird little synchronicities accompanying this movie. Both the director (Larisa Shepitko) and star (Maya Bulgakova) ended their lives in car crashes, something that's hard to put out of mind when watching a sequence where planes crash. Maya Bulgakova's last film credit also happens to be, weirdly, Terminal Velocity in 1994 (her only American film), in which of course planes and crashes and such figure prominently. Kind of adds to the forlorn feeling of Wings.Well observed and understatedâ€¦

I can see why a lot of folks might be disappointed. How do you manage expectations when you put Sion Sono and Nicolas Cage together. Anything short of Magilla Gorilla materializing in your living room and flinging piles of literal ape shit at you is bound to disappoint on some level.This is a strangely subdued movie for something that does, to its credit, feature Nic Cage getting multiple body parts blown off, nuclear mutants, and Bill Moseley. Things feelâ€¦

An anthology of heavy hitter directors of the mid 1980s, representing features, stage productions, and music videos, tied together with opera scores and an interweaving plot involving John Hurt as a haunted stage performer.The operatic sensibilities provide a loose thematic current which is played with as the various directors will. Never a particularly coherent movie, but certain segments are worth the going just on their own. Ken Russell stops by to drop some car crash Salome imagery that mustâ€¦

Neil Marshall has got quite a few absolute bangers under his belt (Dog Soldiers and The Descent are all-time favorites of mine), so any time he's got something I'm in. Thanks Shudder.Charlotte Kirk is a woman in Ye Olde England trying to survive a plague in her village, and the movie opens with her husband contracting said plague and then hanging himself in order to avoid spreading it to his family, which seems a little drastic compared to sleepingâ€¦

I talked earlier this year about how I find William Friedkin to be more of a workman director than a virtuoso, which is kind of strange given the great heights of some of his films, The Exorcist among them. I still hold that view, but this latest viewing has me giving the old man a little more credit.The things that pop culture chose to preserve are of course all the Linda Blair shit, thus creating a feedback loop whereâ€¦

Supposedly The Blood of a Poet was not officially "accepted" by the Surrealist community at the time as a work befitting inclusion in that school of art. Stuff like the Surrealists and the Dadaists doing this always amuses me, as people get into slap fights about whether the thing that's about deconstructing narrative meaning or whatever is doing so in a manner consistent with the larger meaning of whatever it is they're trying to do.There is a basic axisâ€¦

Never quite sure how I feel about Guy Maddin's thing where he deploys late 20s cinematic techniques to tell his stories. It's clear that this era of filmmaking really resonates deep in him, but there are times where it feels like an unnecessary distraction from what's really going on. This is an early one, so maybe that's more apparent than the gauzy, shiny weirdness that's more perfected in something like The Saddest Music in the World. The thing that heâ€¦

movietitle: The Conjuring: The Devil Made Me Do It
review: I have to give credit to James Wan and this franchise. It takes a lot of skill to present Ed and Lorraine Warren, two unapologetic God-botherers who served as standard bearers for the Satanic Panic mindset of the 70s and 80s, as modern-day heroes. I wonder sometimes whether the Conjuring movies are ever screened at the rowdier church functions. It wouldn't shock me since these are so strangely wholesome. Patrick Wilson with his sideburns and Bible, resolute like a polyesterâ€¦

You can tell what you're in for during the first five minutes of this, which as how long it takes John Krasinski to reference himself as he slowly pans over visual cues to the opening scenes of the first A Quiet Place, as though what he'd done in the first movie was so incredibly groundbreaking that you'll be stunned and amazed to see it all show up on screen again. Clap, seal, clap. And then you get a flashback sequenceâ€¦

movietitle: Miss Dundee and Her Performing Dogs
review: Early Alice Guy Blache short depicting a brief demonstration of trained dogs emceed by the eponymous Miss Dundee. Lasting entertainment value in the form of some impressive dog wrangling. The dogs do various coordinated tricks and dances, and even a few costumed dramatic routines into the bargain. Cute stuff.Above baseline for 1902, a time where people were still screening random stuff happening and relying on the still-new technology of motion pictures to impress audiences on its own.

A finger in the eye to Prussian ideas of discipline, a very specific axe to grind in early 1930s Germany. A new girl shows up to a boarding school and, like every other one of the female students, develops an intense crush on one of the teachers.As a film experience, something of the standard melodrama, without much in the way of technical flourish, though there are some memorable bits here and there. There's a shot at the end that'sâ€¦

Latin American narrative tends to be shot through with a specific brand of madness. The preferred term in most quarters is "magical realism" but I think that misses the visceral nature of it, putting snotty airs on the thing and a veneer of academic certitude. That's the first thing that comes to mind as I digest this 13-hour behemoth of expression. La Flor is lacking in a lot of the hallmarks of "magical realism" that you find in something likeâ€¦

I'dknown ofPhilip Ridley before watching this one, but didn't really know much about him prior to finally wading into a series of movies that I'd heard about for years. An initially surprising (to me) facet of his multimedia artistic output is focused on stories for children. After watching The Reflecting Skin, that part of Ridley's work first seemed a little out of place, but then it started making a little more sense when I thought about it. Thisâ€¦

If and when I ever get around to a â€œmost important films in 21st century cinemaâ€ list, this is absolutely one of them. Itâ€™s like the old canard about Hemingway. Youâ€™re focused on imitating him, or youâ€™re doing everything to not imitate him, but no oneâ€™s ignoring him. Itâ€™s impossible to have a discussion about this movie limited to the film itself because of how dominant a place it has in one of the more enduring genres. And itâ€™s alsoâ€¦

Charming The Tramp outing. This time he's on his way to New York on a steamship full of the huddled masses, expertly dodging seasick Cossacks and an angry cowboy(?) at an impromptu dice game. Then, upon arriving in New York, The Tramp must find a way to pay for his meal of beans and humorously elongated bread without getting his ass kicked by the waitstaff.A nicely pure exercise in comic timing (starting with a great fake-out where an apparentlyâ€¦

Solid psychological piece from Robert Wiene, whose next feature would be the landmark Cabinet of Dr. Caligari, also featuring Conrad Veidt who supplies the foreboding parts of this one. Fear isn't the same revolution in visual style that Caligari is, but it's got a nicely twisted throughline to the same species of mental fuckery.Bruno de Carli plays a hapless member of the European gentry who comes back from a journey abroad as a shambling, nervous wreck, consumed with thoughtsâ€¦

A generally less-interesting version of The Woods. New student shows up to Mean Girls Academy boarding school after a cold open in which one of the group yeets out a window after a seance prank gone awry. Is everything as it seems, or are there seeeecrets in this secluded school, boogedy boo.More slasher than paranormal, to adjust audience expectations, which means this ought to be judged in accordance with the quality of its kills, most of which happen offscreenâ€¦

Film DNA that will show up in future hitman classics Le Samourai and Leon: The Professional is on display in this gritty noir standard. Robert Preston gets an undeserved top billing as a generally milquetoast detective assigned to catch a hitman who's just offed a chemical executive in San Francisco, and by far the movie's least interesting character. The real drama is our hitman, Raven (a young Alan Ladd, full of menace and violence), as he gets double-crossed by theâ€¦

Standard Zack Snyder genre shitpile. He seems to be getting worse with the juvenalia with each movie, and this proves no exception, a too-much-Mountain-Dew mashup of Oceanâ€™s 11 and zombies shot like a music video and complete with a â€œThe End?â€ ending.Dave Bautista has his usual charm, one of the few things that made two hours of this bearable. Otherwise, miss me with this shit.

I'm sitting here trying to think of a way to be fair to Preston Sturges by not comparing this to an Ernst Lubitsch film, even though Lubitsch gets name checked several times in this. And Sullivan's Travels is very much its own thing; a little darker in its portrayal of Hollywood spiritual decay, and a little more unwashed in its incorporation of the Great Depression into the story.Still, it's no shame for someone to think of one of theâ€¦

The French countryside plays host to a humorous battle between a put-upon young Romani woman and a town full of provincial yokels, after our hero loses her mother to a hit-and-run driver and the townsfolk who are at best indifferent to her plight.The story is a wonderful exercise in social judo, where Marie (Bernadette Lafont) leverages the fact that everyone in town wants to fuck her to ever-increasing schemes in manipulation and control, starting with her clever pulling ofâ€¦

One of those movies that has an impact way different than what the director was going for. Although I'm not really certain what Robert Wise was going for here. Starts off as a moody psychological drama, starring workaday TV guy John Beck and on-the-cusp-of-respectable Marsha Mason having their happy New York family menaced by an ominously looming Anthony Hopkins for unclear reasons. Rainy New York is a nice backdrop for the initial paranoia and fear that you imagine you're beingâ€¦

Nicolas Cage beats the shit out of people in mascot costumes that spray oily blood everywhere for ninety minutes without saying a word. He does this exclusively on his mandated breaks from thoroughly cleaning a dilapidated Chuck E. Cheese analogue, while also finding time to pound sodas and do a pinball dance number. How can younotenjoy this.It amuses me to no end that someone beat the Five Nights at Freddy's merch juggernaut to the movie version andâ€¦

Standard Netflix filler material. Joe Wright rides point on everyone's paychecks, bringing Amy Adams, Gary Oldman, Julianne Moore(!), and Jennifer Jason Leigh along for the ride, not to mention a few relative up-and-comers in Bryan Tyree Henry and Wyatt Russell. Oh and Anthony Mackie is in this too. Jesus Christ.Ridiculously stacked cast that goes almost entirely to waste in service of a moronic script flavored with enough "politics of the day" signals to feel manipulative. I don't so muchâ€¦

movietitle: Spiral: From the Book of Saw
review: The local theater chain is back up and running, and with it, my monthly pass. Restoring my ability to consume everything playing in the manner God intended, regardless of how bad itâ€™s almost certain to be.That this was a bad movie shouldnâ€™t surprise anybody. The Saw franchise hasnâ€™t been worth much since the first couple entries, and Chris Rock is a well-documented bad actor. What did disappoint was the relatively tame nature of the mayhem. You watch these moviesâ€¦

I could watch MÃ©lanie Laurent all day. I'm also content any time you sit me down in front of an Alexandre Aja movie. So maybe I don't turn much of a critical eye to this one.That's the thing about Aja movies though. They succeed because the man knows his lane. A less charitable soul may find fault with some of the series of twists that start coming left and right as the story proceeds, or maybe the science, ifâ€¦

There's a discussion adjacent to the endless debate about auteur theory, about how a movie's appearance in its time and place affects its historical standing. The French Connection, as far as this kind of thing goes, won Best Picture of 1971 at the Academy Awards. It enjoys a towering reputation as one of the best films ever made. If you look at it without emotion, both these accolades are probably not entirely deserved. While this is a damn good movieâ€¦

Talked up as something of a plus entry in the "creepy kid" subgenre. Don't know that I found it to be that, and it's more of a standard home invasion thriller than anything else.If anything, the cues set you up for a French countryside horrorshow a la High Tension and other, more impactful movies. The opening kill scene is pretty tense, featuring a nicely escalating roadside murder finished off with a seatbelt choking scene, but this takes a littleâ€¦

Couple of hurdles to clear for a viewer here before being able to fully enjoy it. Some clunky storytelling at the front end, where the entire scare-premise of the movie (government-mandated nightly power cuts as part of 70s decay UK social upheaval) has to be blared across the screen via title cards. Could have benefited from weaving that part into the story, a la the way Bader-Meinhof was integrated into the story in the 2018 Suspiria remake.I'll also justâ€¦

All the 80s you can handle. A genre-standard entry perfectly suited for the Satanic panic crowd concerning, you guessed it, a Ouija board and the hijinks that ensue.This is mostly memorable for just how many 80s archetypes show up. There's the Cool Guy in the Shades and One Earring, the Reagan Stockbroker, the Big Haired Girl What Shows Her Boobies (Tawny Kitaen, naturally), and the Free Spirit New Age Psychic. A good time capsule of how American pop cultureâ€¦

movietitle: The Last House on the Left
review: Regardless of the infamy enjoyed by The Last House on the Left for its notorious violence, it really ought to be enshrined for having one of the best ever soundtracks for a horror movie. I don't know that this is nearly as effective without the goofy 70s singer narration (recorded by David A. Hess, who plays the main villain), which is complete with a theme song for the murderous gang that feels like it should be in The Dukes ofâ€¦

Ti West and Amy Seimetz have been established as essentials on the modern horror scene. Draw enough to go and check this one out since I missed it back in 2013.The plot is framed in a pseudo-found footage style, told from the point of view of a Vice reporting team being sent to check out a religious community deep in the jungle of an unnamed country, the hook being that they're following up on a staff member's sister (Amyâ€¦

Rough hewn little indie scarer about a woman on parole looking for her missing sister in a haunted train museum.This one has got a little more artistry going for it than the average microbudget streaming project. The movie is set in rural Nevada, a mountainous, desolate and beautiful location that lends a lot of its very unique flavor to the film's look. The director does a good job leveraging that asset, one that you don't see in many otherâ€¦

The world in which this movie is funny is not this one. I get why Sacha Baron Cohen does this character and what he's trying to do with it. For someone that seems determined to hold a mirror up to the uglier parts of American society, though, Cohen really doesn't understand America or why things have gotten the way they are here now.Back in 2006, it was a road trip through the South and its gaggles of dumbass neoconfederateâ€¦

Would you like to see The Omen shot again except with William Holden in the "late career acting legend who's slumming it a bit" role? And maybe more focus on the annoying kid character? Of course you would.This is basically the same film as the original, minus some of the better-shot kills and with more Satan's Helpers assisting Damien as he grows into the role of Lil' Antichrist. This time there's less drama since you know immediately that Damienâ€¦

Craig T. Nelson serves as a living embodiment of how this movie did not age well at all. I'm old enough to remember his schtick as a slightly lunkheaded manly man goofball, and it didn't play all that well in the first Poltergeist movie even. Here, it's turned up to an obnoxious degree, as he's more of a central character and is primarily defined by a "father knows best" sensibility of family and casual racism. I don't much like applyingâ€¦

The way this is such a direct embodiment of British-American horror is neat. Got your American star, Gregory Peck, playing the US Ambassador to the United Kingdom, allowing him to traipse about in all kinds of great countryside shots and stately manors. All American vigor with the bonus of the signature "horror pastoral" thing that English productions do so well.Time-worn entrant in the creepy kid genre. The strength here is the wise choice made by a young Richard Donnerâ€¦

A big Hollywood production of a grimy little urban legend is doomed to fail. It's like yanking one of those blobfish up from the deep sea. You're taking a fine fellow like the Mothman, whose natural environment is in the backwoods of West Virginia and on websites that still have things like counters and "under construction" .gifs, and hauling him in front of the bright lights. This never stood a chance, Mark Pellington's previous success with the fine Arlington Roadâ€¦

It'd be easy to write this one off as an on-the-nose allegory for the struggles of breaking into the movie business. As I was in fact tempted to do at several points during this. Aside from some weirdness at the beginning, this movie takes a while to really get into its premise; a secretive movie studio cult offering a young actress (Alexandra Essoe) the chance to sell her soul for stardom. For quite a while, it's a mundane affair focusedâ€¦

movietitle: The Masque of the Red Death
review: Love the insane visual palette on this one, starting off with a mysterious dude in a bright red robe that's just casually flinging some tarot cards at peasants. "Your deliverance is at hand." Haw haw.I love the AIP "Edgar Allan Poe" movies, and everything you could want from the Corman/Price duo is on display. Vincent Price is in fine fettle as a sadistic prince who prowls around in his Castle of Satan and demands greater and greater acts ofâ€¦

I hate the spoiler thing but it's pretty hard to discuss this one without it.Found footage gets the indie Mark Duplass treatment, and I'm not sure this is quite the way here. Director Patrick Brice and Duplass star in what starts out as a humble videography about an awkward, weird man attempting to find friendship. From the start, though, the narrative rug-yank is telegraphed pretty hard (you are watching something titled "Creep" after all) and you wait expectantly forâ€¦

Oh look, the world is ending again. I'm so very tired of these. The premise has been beaten into the ground so often lately that it's just ridiculous. This time around the world's been thrown into apocalypse mode because of some bit of radio frequency or some such, it's not explained well, and it's our protagonist's job to fix it in an adorably millennial way.The framing device is our lead Aubrey (Virginia Gardner) grieving the loss of her bestâ€¦

Not so much a movie as two or three decent scenes sandwiched between awful video game adaptation sputum. And sadly, the scenes that are cool, set pieces of bizarre and grotesque violence, are marred by terrible early 00s CGI work. This gets cited sometimes as one of the few examples of the successful video game - cinema transition, but it's not even really Resident Evil tier.It's at least somewhat amusing just from the sheer stupidity of the characters' decisions.â€¦

The A24 horror film is well established as its own genre at this point. That undercuts this one, since it signals a number of things that kind of deflate the tension of the movie. You know that "the people are the real monsters(TM)", and you can rest assured that someone is going to have to do something horrifying at the end. So while Trey Edward Shults gives some semi-hearted head fakes about where the danger to the family comes from,â€¦

Cinematic comfort food all the way. The Phantasm-esque mausoleum setting, 80s girls with teased hair and matching bully jackets, some truly disgusting practical effects, fuckin' Adam West even. Love it.Plot centers around the collision between a dead Russian psychic who loved nothing more than to terrorize young girls and a mean girls hazing ritual that involves locking Meg Tilly in a mausoleum overnight, which means that she's given pills in order to trip balls while being terrorized by herâ€¦

A largely incoherent microbudget streaming project. These always seem to have an annoying douchebro lead in them. Combine that with the film's opening scene, in which said bro, who looks to be in his early 30s, has a "you're not the boss of me" argument with his parents, and you've got a main character who you're not invested in at all.Not that would have helped much anyway, since his actions make no sense from moment to moment, going fromâ€¦

In terms of documentarian flourish, a minimalist styling, straightforwardly presenting the building friendship between a painter and the man who stole two of her most prominent pieces out of a gallery showing. There's some bits in the beginning that feel a little awkwardly staged, as though they were arranged after the fact, but nothing that gets terribly in the way. The filmmakers are largely invisible in the presentation.As a story, it's a compelling one, especially when you realize thatâ€¦

There's a feeling throughout this movie of tourists coming to gape at Appalachia, looking on in stunned horror at what they think they're seeing before getting their fill of controlled shivers and packing back up in the Volvo. I wasn't surprised at all after watching this to find that director Antonio Campos is a denizen of NYC, and that this was produced by the likes of Jake Gyllenhaal. I don't doubt that they were honestly going for authenticity, and likelyâ€¦

I'm not sure how I feel about Cecelia Condit leaving behind the Video Toaster and moving forward into the current age. VHS seems like it suits her thing so well, but I do respect the determination to not become hidebound. We split the difference here, Condit deploying detritus imagery in the internet era, all looped dancing babies and After Dark graphics overlaid with the familiar death imagery.While this isn't a new trick by any means in the lineage ofâ€¦

Close-up shots of fountains and water, one shot fading into the next one, again and again. You'll read all sorts of analysis of this one, but for my money this really misses its original context; one scene in a larger work about a medieval cardinal who was really into golden showers.

Christopher Nolan has completed the journey up his own asshole. This was a subpar spy movie with the patented Nolan faux-intellectualism smeared all over it. Unlike previous products like Inception (a decent heist movie at heart) and Interstellar (an all right sci-fi movie underneath), Tenet isn't even a good action movie after you sift through all of the internally inconsistent applications of reverse entropy or whatever the hell Nolan thinks he's trafficking in.The only actor here that seems likeâ€¦

This is a masterclass in storytelling. Incredible that this is a first feature from writer/director Andrew Patterson. Keep your eye on that guy.Our minds like to organize based on past experience so I'm tempted to say that this has got a feeling of Spielberg to it, in the way that Patterson constructs a fantastic, immersive world for his audience from the very beginning. This has got something a little more daring to it, though, a more layered narrative thanâ€¦

The trailer for this months ago did a pretty good job of convincing me to not watch it. The relative lack of new content in 2020, though, keeps forcing my hand on stuff I would otherwise never have looked at, for good or ill. This one turned out to be not nearly as bad as it looked.Ben Affleck plays a depressed alcoholic who cycles through his days as a construction worker with no real verve or direction. I didâ€¦

A deeply flawed New York mother (Amy Ryan) gets a serious version of the Erin Brokovich treatment as she relentlessly pushes the police to investigate the case of her missing daughter, a working girl who's vanished in the same vicinity as four other bodies were found.This comes with a lot of the problems that message movies tend to have; factual truth is sacrificed on the altar of narrative. There's an argument to be made that the trade-off is worthâ€¦

Pointless. Zombie apocalypse blah blah blah and the twist this time is...a guy stuck in an apartment. Oh and helpfully there's another person also stuck in their apartment and they live directly across from the guy, and it's a hot girl. That's pretty much all the setup you need and I don't think much thought was put into it beyond that either.For something that looks initially like a Train to Busan knockoff, this is filtered through a teeny bopperâ€¦

A Fox Film Corporation pre-Coder Spencer Tracy vehicle, based on a tell-all book written by the widow of famous high-rolling organized crime figure Arnold Rothstein. Edwin Burke directs, which is a shame since Burke was much better known as a screenwriter than a director. An experienced director could have imposed some vision on this and made it memorable, instead of leaving behind a pile of wasted potential.Arnold Rothstein was an interesting dude. The Jewish crime boss of New Yorkâ€¦

As remarked elsewhere, access to the Studio Ghibli catalog is almost worth the HBO Max price of admission on its own.Revisiting this one for the first time since it came out. Better than I remembered; the seaside port village is one of the better settings in a Miyazaki film. A modern town, which allows Sosuke's mother to be an interestingly liberated character in the background, but also remote and rural enough to have the countryside charm that's part ofâ€¦

Would be easy to ding this for being a strictly formula exercise in the teen buddy comedy genre, which it is. Every single general plot movement will be one that you anticipate miles in advance. And in terms of recent examples, this lacks a lot of the off-the-rails humor and star power of Booksmart. But, as it says on the tin, what differentiates this is being one of the first comedies to prominently feature an abortion. Certainly the only oneâ€¦

Sometimes I wonder if I'm just too far gone. I should probably feel some sense of revulsion at this exploitation film set in a concentration camp. Many apparently did, earning this a spot on the infamous British "video nasties" list, and I guess this is still banned in some countries. That seems like what a normal person would react with. I just spent this bored.But then, how can anyone take this seriously? This is super-amateur level stuff across theâ€¦

Feels very much like a lesser Fulci, like a rung or two below one of those productions. There are a few threads back to Italian B-cinema, mostly in the form of Marjoe Gortner, who plays the hapless husband to the demon chick. Gortner was in Luigi Cozzi's famed Star Wars ripoff Starcrash, as part of his strange journey from child revival tent preacher to C-list actor. The gore in this one isn't nearly as explosive, the effects aren't as good,â€¦

Sometimes you encounter a performer that, instead of disappearing into and inhabiting a role, makes you think about them as a person outside of the film you're watching. Helen Twelvetrees is one of those. She's got a face perfectly designed for heartbreak, impossibly sad eyes and trembling lips. One of those faces that's so unusual that it keeps pulling you out of what you're watching. Hers is one of the more bitter stories of Hollywood, like the universe wanted theâ€¦

The landmark film of 1915 is always going to be Birth of a Nation. That's just the way things developed historically. But what Birth of a Nation is to mainstream cinema, The Hypocrites is to the auteur. Lois Weber wasn't just the first major female film director. She was one of the most important directors in early cinema, full stop, with a filmography and box office receipts that rivaled D.W. Griffith. The sheer volume of her output ensured that oneâ€¦

I can imagine a young Ray Kurzweil parked immovably at whatever drive-in was showing this at the time, absorbing screening after screening.Deliciously campy B-fodder from the early 60s with some interesting lineage and a hilarious attempt at social consciousness. This is directed by Wesley Barry, who had an established career as a silent era child actor before getting into the production side of affairs, and you can tell that he believes that he's living in a crazy wondrous futureâ€¦

Strictly knockoff recycle style. A news reporter investigates a mysterious incident at a Taiwanese university that killed five students, who were rumored to have been messing around at a haunted bridge on campus. Wonder what happened.Elements of Ju-On and Dark Water are lifted most prominently, with a dash of Gonjiam thrown in for good measure. Scary ghosts contort around with their hair over their face boogedy boo etc. There is a decent scene in a makeup classroom involving theâ€¦

Sooo many zombie movies. They just keep on coming, waves and waves of them, like some sort of living tide of reanimated, unstoppable corpses. It takes a lot to make the effort to watch these days.Overcoming that soul-weary zombie fatigue is a feat in itself these days, and for that director Jeff Barnaby is to be commended. Continuing his penchant for indigenous horror films, Blood Quantum depicts the ever familiar zombie apocalypse from the view of a Mi'gmaq reservationâ€¦

Can't really fault Christopher Nolan as a filmmaker. The dude undeniably has the ability to make an entertaining movie, and has that Spielbergian talent for competently managing large budget productions. This thing, though, with the fronting like he's an intellectual, it grates. It bothers me because we end up with things like Batman being viewed as some sort of active participant in American thought. And I don't like emperors clothing types.I've avoided this for years because I didn't wantâ€¦

It always warms my heart when someone uses Nicholas Cage correctly. It's been made clear over the years that he's going to constantly work, and if he's willing to share his crazy-ass shaman antics with the world, we owe it to him to provide a suitable stage. And sometimes we give him something that's worthy of his contributions to society.Richard Stanley is an experienced old salt with enough weird creds to handle someone like Cage, and the most impressiveâ€¦

The chassis is a Bollywood supernatural thriller, in this case about a strange female demon haunting the woods around a 19th century Bengali manor, and a manâ€™s attempt to solve the mystery of all the violent yet justifiable if you really think about it murders. And the parts showcasing those elements are all right, decent enough if forgettable.The after market parts are worth noting, however. This oneâ€™s helmed by a female director, Anvita Dutt. The burbling subplot concerns Bulbbul,â€¦

Not a lot of meat on these bones. A teenager coping with his parents' divorce spends a summer of teenagery self-discovery in a vacation lake town, and gets Rear Windowed when he starts noticing strange doin's at his neighbor's house, where the wife has been possessed by a kid-eating witch. That pretty much sums it up.Lots of time annoyingly spent on the thing where the main character has to convince everyone that the monster is real, only for theâ€¦

There's a character archetype I use for certain people, that I call Cul-de-Sac Man. Cul-de-Sac Man is the American cousin of Japan's hikikomori, in that he's a sort of waste product of his culture, passively enabled in self-destructive behavior until he's essentially useless and spends his remaining years waiting around to die. Cul-de-Sac Man is a middle-aged male who by various measures of his choosing has failed in life, and lives more or less involuntarily in a bubble, from whichâ€¦

Jarmuschland by way of the Western. Interestingly, for a movie that starts with Crispin Glover in the prologue and begins with a shot of Gibby Haynes getting blown in an alley, this is far less apeshit than you might think it is, instead opting for a more meditative, mystical approach as William Blake (Johnny Depp) reckons with his inherent nonexistence.The West provides its usual backdrop as a place where laws only nominally exist, letting its characters forge their ownâ€¦

I can respect what Jane Arden was going for here. This is the later stage of her fascinating career, which started in mainstream film and theater and fanned out increasingly into the postmodern as a direct challenge to the idea of rationality. And unlike most postmodernists, she had enough of an unwavering and true understanding of that concept that she took it to the logical conclusion in her 1982 suicide. If nothing else, Jane Arden the artist has my attention.â€¦

As a documentary, this is a lightweight. The filmmakers don't quite know what to do with their subject material, flailing at various times as to how much consternation they should treat Action Park founder Eugene Mulvihill, who was without a doubt a scoundrel and a reprobate. And for a place that was legendary to an entire generation of NY/NJ kids in the 70s and 80s, the view of the park seems to be filtered through a limited number of disappointinglyâ€¦

A depressing iteration of the Netflix algorithm. These guys are no strangers to putting out an inferior product with just enough notability to attract eyeballs. What's different about this one is the sheer number of people who are capable of far better that got roped into the production, starting with Charlize Theron.This is directed by Gina Prince-Bythewood, who's got a couple of actual movies to her resume like Love and Basketball and The Secret Life of Bees. This isâ€¦

At some point, Pixar movies went from mandatory in-theater viewing, to noteworthy, to now being something to check off the list. I remember the first Toy Story film blowing people away, the animation at the time light years ahead of where everyone thought CGI was, and hey not badly written either. Part of all this has to be everyone else catching up technologically. You're no longer watching these and looking carefully to see where the animation continues to improve. Maybeâ€¦

Amateur level streaming production covering some niche topics among the Coast to Coast AM set. In this case, Lemurians and astral traveling. The Mount Shasta thing caught my eye, so some NorCal scifi it is.The plot focuses on a kids disappearance, narrated by his older sister, who has the ability to project her consciousness when she sleeps. This is pretty much the New Age crystal lady at the farmer's market interpretation of that phenomenon, and is presented as such.â€¦

More of a cultural outreach effort than a film. I mean, it's definitely a film in the same sense as all of the big studio Biblical epics that precede it, which is to say that it's a live action Sunday school class. The main difference being that this time, it's the story of Mohammad and the founding of Islam being put on the screen. Naturally, the palette swap of one Abrahamic religion for another caused everyone to lose their mindsâ€¦

I'd have rather gotten a straight up movie about a sentient junkyard tire coming to life and exploding various small animals and peoples' heads with its psychic powers. That would have been stupidly fun, at least.Instead you get an asinine commentary on how stupid you, the viewer, are for watching this movie. A childish set of stereotypes serve as stand ins for the film's audience and act idiotically while one of the actors babbles some entry level nonsense aboutâ€¦

Baseball is permission to feel something. There's a romanticism around it that's unique in American sports; something that's specially keyed to those with a hardened cynicism, in order to allow crusty old bastards to express things in a ritualized form. Maybe that's what allows films from the baseball movie's golden era of the 1980s (and the 80s-adjacent early 90s) to maintain relevancy. The bits of movies like this that are cloying or predictable are swept up in the feeling ofâ€¦
Silly remake of High Sierra that features an uncomfortable-looking Jack Palance. Not much more to be said and not really worth anyone's time.

One of those times where you feel like presuming to jabber about the works of a master is to make an ass of yourself. Not to say that, despite its towering reputation, I find this to be a perfect film. There are cracks if you go looking. Why would you, though. This is American cinematic source code. I'm unlikely to say anything that hasn't been covered already by Jean-Luc Godard, Akira Kurosawa, David Lean, or any of the other all-timeâ€¦

Could you have made Shane without the little kid? Mmm, I guess not. That's become one of the signature memoriam signposts for this film over the years, the "come back Shane" and the general Dennis the Menace energy radiating off aww-shucks towhead Brandon deWilde. I read somewhere that the kid serves as a sort of audience surrogate that relentlessly peppers everyone with questions, but I have trouble believing that audiences were ever so dense as to not be able toâ€¦

Mostly forgettable relationship drama with a monster stapled onto it as some sort of metaphor for the lead character's intransigence, I guess. I think that's what they were going for, but It's not really dropped in there all that artfully.A man rattles around in his old country house, drinking with his small town buddies by day and holing up with a shotgun at night to shoot at an undetermined monster, all after his girlfriend vanishes with little explanation andâ€¦

Clark Duke in his directorial debut, in which Clark Duke hangs out and slacks with Liam Hemsworth in between drug running jobs on behalf of Park Ranger John Malkovich. It sounds stupid and in its first stretches it kind of is, relying heavily upon how gosh durn goofy the Clark Duke and John Malkovich characters are. After the boys are established at the park house in which they operate, though, things slow down a bit and then get real whenâ€¦

movietitle: Birds of Prey (and the Fantabulous Emancipation of One Harley Quinn)
review: Anything was going to be better than Suicide Squad, so there was that headwind. I'll never understand the appeal of the Harley Quinn character, though. Like someone thought the whole manic pixie dream girl thing was too subtle. And Jesus Christ that awful Brooklyn baby doll voice is like nails on a chalkboard to me. Why anyone goes seeking those specific things out is on the same level of bafflement to me as people who enjoy stuff like sounding. Like,â€¦

Glad that I went into this completely blind, even if I came close to checking out in the first fifteen minutes. The opening is a little too precious for its own good, consisting of the lead character (Kate Lyn Sheil) moping around her house, for the entire day, over the fact that she's going to supply this movie its title by dying tomorrow through some mysterious means, playing the same snippet of Mozart over and over again. Once her friendâ€¦

Horror is lightly employed here at key moments of the film rather than being a full-on genre assault. The violence of past Guatemalan regimes instead serves as the primary source of fear in this unfortunately timed iteration of the La Llorona story. Latin American horror has a unique flavor evident here and elsewhere; the supernatural as the only means to obtain justice when every other system is too corrupt to deliver it. Something I suspect the US is going toâ€¦

All of the intense, lustful passion that you'd expect from Oscar Wilde by way of Alla Nazimova. An unforgettable visual experience, starting with the outlandish costuming and then Nazimova herself, wearing a series of abstractly beautiful designs as the action progresses.The cool thing about this is how the sexual urges of men and women are portrayed, not as two different things but as forces that, while having their own flavor, change shape and direction from moment to moment. Theâ€¦

I've read multiple explanations for why films by The Archers are so innately watchable. Explanations I've gone looking for, since the reason they're so enjoyable on a gut level has eluded me. I've seen plenty of things that demonstrate mastery of the art form that I respect but don't like, and I don't think it's entirely attributable to that.When I watched The Red Shoes, it occurred to me that, for me anyway, it comes from the juncture of twoâ€¦

This screened at Cannes last year. You'd think that might be a signifier that Vivarium belongs in that elevated "serious horror" category, but it speaks more to this being a substantial, polished effort with most of the sharp corners sanded off. I'm a little surprised they didn't park this one longer until it could get a wider theatrical release.I'm just not moved by the "horrors of suburbia" as a trope. Like the most awful fate ever is a comfortableâ€¦

Ant Farm Jarre floats through the desert, a billion little puppets welling up out of the sand in his wake.This like one of those times where you're up late at night, fiddling idly with the AM knob as you try to make your horror B-movie project, and suddenly you catch a clear wavelength through all the static. Can't tell necessarily what the weird guy on whatever program is rambling about, and you're sure he's got a couple empty bottlesâ€¦

This wasn't nearly as unwatchable as I'd feared after Josephine Decker put out Madeline's Madeline in 2018, one of the worst movies in recent memory. The scarcity of 2020 releases forces us all into watching stuff we wouldn't ordinarily watch. I'm glad that this wasn't as punishing an experience.I mean, it's not great either. Let's not go nuts here. This is a coloring book version of Who's Afraid of Virginia Woolf, and Decker being Decker there's tons of gauzyâ€¦

Oh man. What could have been.Paul W.S. Anderson is a good director. That doesn't necessarily mean that he makes good movies, but here's a man you can trust to competently deliver your product, which in his case for the bulk of his career have been movies about video games. And before you scoff at his Resident Evil-heavy filmography, if you actually watch those films along with his version of Mortal Kombat, you'll find that while notgood, they're notâ€¦

I'm certain that the "frolic in brine, goblins be thine" proverb was much more chilling in its original language. An argument for not forcing the rhyme scheme in translations.Foundational J-horror. Not just in creepy long black hair imagery but in the sense that this is satisfied to proceed along in its own sweet time before ramping up the fear to a slow crescendo. Which, thank god for that, because most of the pleasure here is in the cold, dampâ€¦

Did I miss something? Sadako was a young adult just trying to make her way in Tokyo and make senpai notice her or whatever in a community theater troupe? And now there's two of her, and one's the evil one, but the one that becomes Teenage Sadako becomes the evil one herself? So I guess there's two evil Sadakos?I don't know. From what I can tell this is taken from the source novels, but it feels very much likeâ€¦

Historical revisionism is tricky. It's certainly true that Hallelujah, the first major studio release of the sound era to feature an all-black cast, traffics in broad racial stereotypes. There's plenty of examples of white writers putting Uncle Ben dialogue into the mouths of the black characters, and Irving Berlin does a lot of interpretation of what traditional black music sounds like through the ears of a white guy. And if you're looking for a narrative of fighting oppression, this ain'tâ€¦

Tier 3 found footage in accordance with my scale that I made up.First time revisiting this one since I saw it in the theater. Iâ€™m still mystified as to how anyone liked this, and itâ€™s only gotten hokier in the intervening years. Micah comes across as an even bigger douche this time around, and it really saps the fear any time youâ€™re rooting for the monster in the movie to kill the main characters.While you canâ€™t handwave awayâ€¦

I live in a neverending series of Zoom calls and little boxes with faces and artfully placed background bookshelves. I'm not inclined to then watch a movie that is an extended Zoom call, especially one where nothing happens for interminable minute after minute. Fuck that.

Bob is introduced to us as the patron saint of Montmartre, a high-rolling gambler who bounces from joint to joint all night, every night. All the dealers know him, all the cafes know him, all the hoods know him. Even the cops like Bob, giving him rides and meals on account of Bob saving the life of a police inspector many years ago. He's dapper, he's street smart, and he's known to hand an extra hundred to anyone in desperateâ€¦

Good opportunity to drop some found footage doctrine.Tier One found footage horror:Extremely cheap farmed content featuring amateur-level actors, iPhone filming, no attempts whatsoever at practical effects, generally a waste of time and a way to inflate streaming numbers.Notable examples: All of the dozens of "Haunting of the _____ _____" titles you can find on Prime, most other found footage titles from places and people that you haven't heard of.Tier Two:Professional-grade productions featuring baseline CGI, hired actors, aâ€¦

Ainâ€™t no one complaining about getting your USDA recommended daily allowance of death rattles and ghost murders. All of the basic nutrition is here. Though this lacks something ineffable that was present in White Ghost, the companion piece to this.Where White Ghost was like the bloody scraps of something shocking left scattered all over the room, this is more of a straightforward outing of Ju-on. Sure, thereâ€™s some non-linear storyline fuckery, but where White was a single shocking actâ€¦

Mmmm that's good curse vittles. By the nature of its construction entries in the Ju-on franchise follow a pretty set formula. Hapless person encounters The House or something tangentially related to The House then dies horribly. White Ghost is a solid execution of such, set off by a killer opening. Guy placidly strings a noose around his neck from a tree in the middle of nowhere, accompanied by a tape recorder and a mass of writhing black hair in aâ€¦

Been thinking a lot about boats lately. A man with a penchant for solitude and a good supply of liquor could do pretty well on a little 30 foot boat, puttering around up and down the local rivers, seeing only who he wants to see, when he wants to. Will have to give further thought to rectifying the "not owning a boat" and "not knowing anything about operating a boat" obstacles.An adventure film in form and marketing, but moreâ€¦

An escalating set of misunderstandings leads Ginger Rogers to believe that Fred Astaire is an amoral swinger who's being goaded into pursuing her by his wife. The ribaldry gets pushed to the post-Code limits with this plotline, along with what's clearly a lavender marriage between Edward Everett Horton and Helen Broderick, and a couple of coded gay characters in Horton's "manservant" (Eric Blore) and an Italian fashion designer (Erik Rhodes). Add into that the "dancing = fucking" thing and you'veâ€¦

Pre-coder about a man forced to choose; his old flame and the art life, or his wife and wealthy respectability. For most of this, the main character, Tom (Leslie Howard) is an indecisive ne'er do well, malleable by the forces around him. This makes him uninteresting as a character, and the viewer never sees the side of him that's apparently so charming to the bohemian set, the patron of serious literature that he was before his marriage.If the centerâ€¦

Slightly lurid forerunner to the great tradition of the British Video Nasty. One of those movies with a rep that precedes it, so modulate your expectations accordingly.The story behind the film is far more interesting than the film itself. I won't reproduce the Wikipedia article, but generally this was a joint UK-US production, serving as the last project for live-fast-die-young director Michael Reeves and a tax write-off for American International Pictures, who forced the production to cast Vincent Priceâ€¦

In the doldrums of 2020, plays now count as movies I guess so I'll log them accordingly.I don't like to get overtly political here. It's almost always pointless, as discourse is now close to nonexistent, the landscape comprised primarily of chirp and rechirp memeing children on one wing and braindead Trumpanzees on the other.
