Nonetheless, Hamilton hits on an issue that's pretty close to me so you're gonna hear about it(tm).I have never liked the co-opting of traditionalâ€¦

The silver lining to how hard the release schedule for 2020 has been fucked: Watching new releases means exposing yourself to stuff that you ordinarily wouldn't bother with. For me, this means watching a dumbass Hulu-exclusive romcom.I do get a certain amount of empty calorie goofy pleasure out of Lonely Island stuff, so this didn't go down as terribly as it could have. Andy Samberg's nihilistic slacker shtick is amusing for a while, especially in the early going asâ€¦

movietitle: The Saddest Music in the World
review: One of the more aggressively Canadian movies I've seen. Not quite sure how I came to that conclusion, since this has Isabella Rosselini playing a double amputee, hosting an international music competition for $25,000 Depression-Era Dollars(tm), a guy with a Gavrilo Princip stage persona, Maria de Madeiros playing an amnesiac nymphomaniac, and probably the strangest rendition of "California Here I Come" committed to film. But here we are.I've never been to Winnipeg, but I'll choose to believe that thisâ€¦

For a film nominally about drag racing, a pretty laconic Jack Kerouac road deal. James Taylor, in peak heroin form, plays The Driver, and Dennis Wilson is The Mechanic, as the two bounce sedately back and forth across the country in a stripped down, utilitarian old Chevy. The two gearheads survive by hustling drag races, finding rubes and marks all along the highway willing to challenge their deceptively fast care in street races.The two Chevy guys live a Zenâ€¦

The first ten minutes or so is a collection of "DANGER: Community center art show-grade wankery ahead" warning signs. Easily could have gone the way of so many other forgettable attempts at high concept. Stick with it, and you'll see that not only do several things about this film rescue it from mediocrity, but that this ends up being a surprisingly consistent and watchable tragicomedy.I salute Mike Pinkney, the lead actor playing (presumably) himself, a struggling video artist inâ€¦

High batting average exploitationer playing in an emotional minefield. For a goofy movie about a grunting cannibal woman that avenges herself upon her captors with lawn mower blades and teeth, this is primarily an effective portrayal of domestic abuse. It's effective because Sean Bridgers (whom most will know as the hapless Johnnie from Deadwood) is very, very good in the double-faced abuser role. As the head of the Cleek family, he radiates an uncanny George W. Bush charm in publicâ€¦

This supposedly began life as a script purchased and then substantively rewritten by writer-directors Veronika Franz and Severin Fiala, which explains some of this film's essential character; sometimes brilliant, frequently shot through with genre bullshit.This is at its best when it lives in the now-familiar family drama underpinning the central horror film. Kids Aidan and Mia (played very well by Jaeden Martell and Lia McHugh) are traumatized by their mother's suicide (the mother played by a now unrecognizable Aliciaâ€¦

The only real high point here is Delroy Lindo, and not because of the wild, hand-wavey performance either. It's impressive that Lindo, at 67, still has a credibly physical presence on the screen. Of all of the Bloods in the film, he's the only one that still seems capable of violence, which becomes ridiculously apparent as this devolves into a war film every bit as silly as the Chuck Norris and Sylvester Stallone Vietnam movies that Spike Lee makes funâ€¦

Gritty dock drama perfect for some Sunday afternoon wistfulness. Jean (Jean Gabin) is an army deserter looking to escape all duty as he rolls into Le Havre one night, soon finding himself enmeshed in the affairs of local small-time hoods, a creepy old man (Michel Simon), and his young stepdaughter (MichÃ¨le Morgan). Not really a frenetic crime picture, and more of a mood piece where people get to spend plenty of time in cafes and bars. This one ain't inâ€¦

A little bit of the shine has gone off this one for me. Not that it still isn't one of the best modern Western films, and not that it doesn't stand as a high point of the Coens' filmography, because it remains those things. The darkness that this is representing, though, seems a bit off now that we're grappling with a more national-level sickness that threatens to do us in. This new-world hyper violence, the unraveling of order on aâ€¦

It used to bug me, the dumb meta-commentary grafted onto Cannibal Holocaust about consumption of media violence. It always seemed like a stupidly oblivious move from Ruggero Deodato, and a way to distance himself from making one of the purest exploitation pieces in cinema. These things are still true, but this time around it struck me that it doesn't really matter. Even though Deodato added some bits to flail around the implications, he still made Cannibal Holocaust.This appearing somewhatâ€¦

Tightly constructed tale hailing from the J-Horror boom of the early 2000s. The story centers around Yoshimi (Hitomi Kuroki), a mentally fragile woman going through a divorce and subsequent custody battle, raising her six year old daughter on her own. Mother and daughter move into a cheap apartment in a forgotten corner of town, and then things go south.Most of the tension is generated by Yoshimi's place as a divorced woman in Japanese society. She fights a court battleâ€¦

Not great. Silly story that's more a mashup of like twelve different movies rather than being a straight rip-off of Alien as advertised, full of horrible dialogue and a plot makes little to no sense. Probably best encapsulated by a scene in the last act where the heroes infiltrate the villain's coffee plantation by walking in the front door and pretending they want to buy some coffee.The effects look cheap even for an Italian knockoff production, probably since mostâ€¦

This is a drop off the cliff. The original Candyman shows its age, sure. But it was a smart, carefully constructed film that tapped into some powerful narrative currents to do that most worthwhile of things, making an audience feel uncomfortable. The sequel, meanwhile, is a shitty cash grab, packed full of awful writing, cringeworthy stereotypes, terrible effects and no understanding whatsoever of what made the original movie good. The more you dig into Bill Condon's filmography, the more reasonsâ€¦

Incredibly prescient film, hitting theaters in the same year as the 1992 Los Angeles riots. It's easy to watch Candyman in 2020 and lament the many missed opportunities to fully embrace the racial issues it dredges up from the nation's consciousness. It is, after all, primarily presented from the view of a wealthy white woman, and for all of its humanization the Cabrini Green Projects still radiate a lot of scary ghetto menace as part of the fear stew. Still,â€¦

Not much to be said about this one that hasn't already. I'll content myself by noting that even today, Conrad Veidt's murderous stare, the set design, and the commentary packed into officials scribbling away on high chairs, perched like storks over their work, still hit very effectively.Avoid the copy on Amazon Prime, which continues to do silent films a serious disservice by streaming the cheapest and shittiest versions possible.

Director Kim Jin-Won emerges from an absence of ten years to bolster Shudder's line of "originals." Shudder has done a decent job putting its imprint on foreign distributions, last year's "The Furies" being a good example. Warning: Do Not Play doesn't break any real new ground, serving as a standard entry in the established J/K-horror vengeful ghost genre. Like a lot of solid genre pictures, though, this has got just enough unique flavor to it to make it an entertainingâ€¦

About the greatest service I can provide here is to manage any expectations going in. The poster for Bandaged, as well as the promo copy, suggest some sort of psychological/Cronenbergian horror film centered around a deranged doctor, and the opening credits sequence does little to dispel any of that. Don't you believe it. This is instead a particularly well-executed softcore porn entry with a few support beams that could have anchored more of a story, if director Maria Beatty wasn'tâ€¦

With a little polish this could really be something. That false-reality narrative and the "ooogedy boogedy it might kiiillll youuuu" conceit hits some delicious trash matinee flavors, along the lines of a liability waiver being peddled in the lobby next to the popcorn. It's a neat starting point and it's carried along well enough that there's some entertainment value in the final product. Rough edges, though.The front mockumentary section is fine, and thankfully doesn't overstay its welcome. Just hangsâ€¦

movietitle: Portrait of a Lady on Fire
review: I've sat with this one for a month, having finally watched it after its US release, subsequent to tearing up the festival chatter and best-of lists in 2019. With the benefit of mulling it over and hindsight, I can comfortably break hiatus here and say that no, I did not like this. I cannot remember a single moment in this film that sticks with me and makes me think that this is something other than an award-seeking missile, locked inâ€¦

Seminal entry in the â€œKorean-directed features about train-based mayhemâ€ sub genre.Zombies, both of the moldering shambler and rage virus varieties, havenâ€™t had a whole lot to offer me for years now. Thereâ€™s a ceiling on enjoyment of these, I find. Still, as far as the genre goes this is a solidly constructed example. The combination of claustrophobic space and ravening monsters is effective, and the danger of being crowded into a tight space with a bunch of other infectedâ€¦

Not that it detracted much from the movie for me, but sexual fidelity being one of the underlying themes for Contempt is hilarious to me, being that it involves an Italian man married to a French woman who falls into the orbit of Jack Palance all while stewing around in the film industry. Nothing about any of that suggests that keeping it in oneâ€™s pants is a plausible outcome in the slightest.Regardless, Paul (Michel Piccoli) is very concerned thatâ€¦

The more Ingmar Bergman movies I see, the more comfortable I am in my lack of enthusiasm for him. I donâ€™t dislike his stuff. But Iâ€™m now beyond the initial, perverse impulse to recoil from something that everyone says you have to like.Persona. Case in point. All of the good stuff is here, sure. Bergman plays with complex emotion in ways that I canâ€™t really equate to anyone else. Which is hilarious because itâ€™s always delivered by phlegmatic, loomingâ€¦

The great narratives let their characters be people in addition to standing in for various larger, atavistic forces. And in those narratives, the people themselves are what tell them story, more than their assigned values for which they bear a standard. You could go on for quite a bit about the war for control waged between commerce and religion, but that would just drain the blood right out of this. Itâ€™s Daniel Plainview and Eli Sunday that make this worthâ€¦

Remains one of the greatest Westerns of all time. Is there a better place for putting all of the harshest elements of the Western narrative than the bitter desolation of Wyoming?Plenty of words already on this one. Every time, though, Iâ€™m taken aback by the fact that Clint Eastwood spends 90% of the film being frail and creaky, before â€œlol Old Clintâ€ was a calling card of his performances. His fever sequences, as William Munny tells his friend Nedâ€¦

Revisited this one for the first time in decades. It remains one of the finest satires anyone in a mainstream studio has greenlit, and itâ€™s only become more so as the shine continues to wear off the imperial eagle of American dominance.Of all the currents defining American politics, the desperate insistence that weâ€™re headed some toward some polished Western version of the 30s grimdark fascist state is the most hilarious. Both from the cheerleaders and the hand wringers. Asâ€¦

Props for a genuine reimagining. If youâ€™re going to remake something, do it for a reason. Leigh Whannell has discarded almost everything from the original Universal horror staple except for the central premise; guy whatâ€™s invisible causes mayhem. None of the manic cheeriness, none of the country rubes, and sadly none of the immature pranking. Beyond the basic scare delivery system and one quick reference with a bandaged guy in a hospital, the original film may as well not haveâ€¦

Pop culture does strange shit now. Or at least it's strange to me, a calcified old-head by the reckoning of my firmly with-the-now teenage daughter. I get the streamability angle, but I've never quite understood how The Office maintains immediate cultural relevancy with the younger set, despite the fact that most of the latter-day fan base seems to have never held a job. Maybe it's the vision of a workplace that's insufferable in the ways that kids have heard theirâ€¦

Something I notice sometimes with silent films is that it's not the film itself that grabs you. Were I a theatergoer at the end of the Roaring 20s, it isn't G.W. Pabst's eye for the action or his continuing fascination with the moral abyss that is poverty in his mind. That's not to dismiss his expertise, but it's not for him that I'm plunking down another two bits immediately afterward so I can watch Diary of a Lost Girl again.â€¦

Klaus Kinski holds forth before a raft full of monkeys, the only remaining subjects of his insane, dying kingdom. I say "Klaus Kinski" and not his character, Don Lope de Aguirre, because it's impossible to discern where reality is in a movie like this. The insanity of both Kinski and Werner Herzog as they made this is well-documented and I won't repeat it here. I think that Kinski was really expecting a reply from those monkeys when he's demanding who'sâ€¦

Why yes, I am indeed going to sit down and bash out some thoughts about David Lynch playing cat-and-mouse with a Clutch Cargo monkey. Wanna fight about it?The initial inclination is to wave off the absurdity and go about the rest of your day. As this popped up all over my feed I was loathe to even watch it, given the general "lol so nutty" tone of the responses. But I've seen Lynch's other short stuff, and chances areâ€¦

There's an unspoken agreement with action movies, sort of like the thing where if you drink out of a paper bag the cops will be less likely to run you in. I, the viewer, agree to suspend my disbelief a little more than usual in exchange for some fun. The filmmaker, in return for my custom, agrees not to assault my brain cells more than necessary. It's a fine line, around which William Eubank flails with no real sense ofâ€¦

Great convergence of the road movie/noir film. The setup is pretty keen; a hardened criminal (Dennis O'Keefe) escapes from prison with the aid of his San Francisco-based crime boss (Raymond Burr), but it's a setup to essentially get him killed in the attempt, as O'Keefe took the fall on a rap and might talk due to going stir crazy in the joint. O'Keefe's girlfriend (Claire Trevor) is there to help him escape, and her absolute loyalty to him is testedâ€¦

The idea of Hollywood karmic debt amuses me. After plenty of moral finger-wagging following the success of gangster pictures like The Public Enemy, studios felt the need to put out counterpoints, portraying former villain actors as crusading crime fighters in order to restore the balance of the universe. James Cagney was a part of this effort at safeguarding the thin barrier between order and movie-induced lawlessness, of which Great Guy is a part. Personally, I can't wait until Joaquin Phoenix'sâ€¦

Sacramento, the cinema capital of river-based shenanigans. I'm going to pitch that to the Chamber of Commerce in the hopes that someone offers the correct blend of tax exemptions that results in a movie about Crispin Glover operating some sort of snake-filled dunk tank.Something of a downer when you look into the backstory of this one, as this is one of the last films Buster Keaton got to make with anything resembling creative control, rejected at the box officeâ€¦

There's an ever present struggle for the modern viewer in how much to apply the standards of today to works of the past. Which things we turn a selective blind eye to for the sake of greater artistic merit, which things we choose to discard from the canon. I tend to be more permissive of past transgressions than most, I guess. Judgment implies that you yourself have got things figured out and we're not nearly as enlightened as we thinkâ€¦

Stories of the vengeful dead are a form of proto-religion in and of themselves. Is there anything that settles more uncomfortably into your guts more than the idea that the wicked might never be punished? Iâ€™m betting thatâ€™s a real top-of-mind subject for a lot of people at the moment. The powerless, confronted with this unpleasant reality, have no choice but to retreat into story and superstition. Those things have their own power, but itâ€™s not quite as immediately satisfyingâ€¦

When Zardoz came out in theaters, some film critics took to printing when in the filmâ€™s runtime the sequence occurs where Sean Connery learns the worldâ€™s knowledge via magic montage, so that filmgoers could get to the interesting part of the film without wading through a bunch of nonsense involving red g-strings and floating Karl Marx heads spewing guns at people. Misguided as it may be to encourage people to cheat themselves out of the majesty that is Zardoz, theseâ€¦

Long day, can't sleep, won't sleep, give me a dose of that good old K-drama. Can't beat the comfort of surefire cinematography, knife-twisting shock moments and deliberate menace.I've found out that Letterboxd can slap the spoiler thingie on your reviews after the fact, so at the risk of someone else violating my "no spoiler clickbox thing" policy for me, it's hard to get too deep into what goes on in this one. Suffice to say that this is aâ€¦

I'm a picky man about my Great War depictions. World War I remains the most important lesson history has for the modern person, and remains something that's shrouded in ignorance. So I'm excited whenever I see something that'll get people talking about that period of history, but it's rare that the essential spirit of the thing is captured. Witness last year's ill-considered British Museum of Imperial Harrumphing, They Shall Not Grow Old.A properly done film about the Great Warâ€¦

You can't go home again, and you can't really make alien abduction movies outside of the 1990s.I only recently discovered that one of the directors of The Blair Witch Project, Eduardo SÃ¡nchez, had made an alien movie. As an ardent defender of The Blair Witch Project, as well as a connoisseur of grimy UFO conspiracy fare, I felt obligated. Obligation just gets you in trouble, really, a lesson I feel like I should have learned long ago, and oneâ€¦

I like James Whale for a lot of reasons. One of the primary ones is his continued demonstration that horror and comedy come from a very similar psychological space. There's always tons of camp in his movies, but it's not like it diminishes the horror. Whether you're looking for laughter or screams, you're setting a very similar stage. The filmmaker invents a world that resembles our own, but in this one we know more is possible, things that will beâ€¦

Vexing. I spent most of the film wanting to hate Leos Carax's exercise in self-reference. And parts of it I did. I almost checked out after the exceedingly goofy introduction, and the ending sequence was only there to make a reference to Eyes Without a Face and then conclude with a pointlessly silly dialogue that was beyond even the loosely defined rules of this film's universe. I don't mind esotericism but this was a little much even for a Frenchman.â€¦

I was at home minding my own business when a sharp rap came at my door.Too late in the evening for the pyramid cult a few doors down, and too early for the police, I apprehensively peered through the glass at whoever was gathered on my porch. A blurry delegation of well-dressed individuals. Either the key to the city or an extraction team from the Hague. Let fate decide, I thought as I opened door.There before me wereâ€¦

I'm left disappointed that the most radical choice made by Greta Gerwig in shooting this was one that I found hard to roll with. Watching these actors play children and then adults highlighted some stuff that I'm not sure that I'd feature, such as Florence Pugh's strangely juvenile face. It's not a bad choice, and the case is talented enough to do the job. But it felt really strange to see the same actor dashing around like a puppy andâ€¦

I've been thinking often of Latin America the past few years. Every time something happens in America and one thinks, "huh, that shouldn't be that way," I consider the fact that just south of us, are an entire collection of nations of similar world lineage, where things much worse have happened regularly, and yet they keep living on. Cuba might be my favorite of the region, if for nothing else because it was a fantastic exercise in what happens whenâ€¦

movietitle: Guinea Pig Part 2: Flower of Flesh and Blood
review: Like everything else thatâ€™s fun, the story of Charlie Sheen watching this and then getting so freaked out that he called the FBI is, sadly, probably an urban myth. Still, I enjoy thinking about Charlie watching this from between a hookerâ€™s legs as he pops Xanax after Xanax into his mouth from a gold plated PEZ dispenser.More of a practical effects demonstration than a narrative film, which keeps this from being nearly as unwatchable as everyone says it is.â€¦

Wonderfully grimy piece of meatsexual zombie fare. David Cronenberg and his use of the human body as a medium need no further explanation in this space. Maybe not as signature a Cronenberg product as his 80s canon, but the 70s feel is a good match for what the man is doing.Cool alignment of sexual reverberation by casting Marilyn Chambers in the lead, bringing with her that porno theater verve that we'll never see the likes of again. The A-storyâ€¦

Christ. The real grudge is against American audiences, I guess.Your hopes can't ever be that high for remakes of international film franchises. They don't do these for art's sake. And yet, there's a reliable gaggle of suckers like myself who need their theatrical horror fix, and they attached enough intriguing actors to this, along with Nicolas Pesce, who's got some intriguing credits, to lure us in. Sam Raimi even produces.Within ten minutes, and the horrific dime store scoreâ€¦

There's a clarity of purpose running through the middle of this thing that I wasn't necessarily expecting of something billed as a foreign horror film. Admirable, though. This is my first exposure to Laotian-American director Mattie Do's work, and for someone without a ton of experience under their belt there's a pleasingly tight feeling to the production. All of the elements of this film help to underline its main themes, and things feel like they're corralled into reasonable lanes soâ€¦

"Slow and meditative" are odd ways to describe a film which is an ongoing life-or-death chase for most of the runtime, but there you have it. This is a pleasant little low-frequency import for those times when you could use a respite from the frenetic.What Away lacks in technical sophistication, it makes up for in establishment of mood. The animation here isn't going to win any awards, and there are sequences where this feels slightly above Flash level work,â€¦

I'm not quite sure I'm on the hype train for the Safdie Brothers just yet. I mean they've clearly got a bright future and they're good filmmakers. Butgreat, as a lot of people are pronouncing them with this one? I'm not quite sure yet.A couple of things figure in that assessment. At the risk of picking a side in the neverending Auteur Theory wars, I would imagine a great artist to totally clear their lane when it comesâ€¦

movietitle: At Midnight I'll Take Your Soul
review: Fascinatingly odd. A horror movie with a villain protagonist, who is the one on the receiving end of the supernatural forces at play, in the service of an essentially Catholic morality tale. Except the part where the mystical Gypsy is the one doling out justice, I guess. A beard-strokingly intriguing time, to be sure.I really, really dig Coffin Joe as a character, putting me in good company apparently with generations of Brazilian filmgoers. A cantankerous mortician in a smallâ€¦

I've seen this movie at least forty times before.Be sure to drink your Ovaltine.It's less a film than an engrammatic supplement to my subconscious to this point.Randy lay there like a slug. It was his only defense.Jean Shepherd's voice and Peter Billingsley's stupefied mug are surely baked into the American concept of Christmas at this point. As is Melinda Dillon's exhortations against eating uncooked turkey, and Darren McGavin's Yosemite Sam cursing jags.You used up allâ€¦

A Christmas card from a more optimistic time. Extended family members are frequently puzzled as I sit in place and watch this closely, parked immovably in an easy chair with enough scotch to float a battleship while the collection of various peoples' children swirl around with whatever beeping and buzzing stuff they've received earlier in the morning.It's possible to not oneself be sentimental, but to appreciate things that are above the cynicism of the larger world. Not that Frankâ€¦

This is a helpful exercise in putting the lie to the idea of discrete rankings of films, or really any other artistic work. This is considered to be, by the lights of the Sight and Sound poll, the greatest film of all time, and numerous individuals make that claim as well. We all like to order things and rank them; it's inherently pleasing to our ordered minds. I do it, you do it, we all do it. But as Iâ€¦

There's no one definition for what the cinematic experience is. But a Terence Malick film is something that may come close to encompassing all that it is. The specific means by which a movie enters your consciousness, as opposed to say a book or a painting, is visual imagery and motion, all else flowing from that pairing. If that's the standard, then it's hard to find something more emblematic than a film like this.As expected from Malick, the visualâ€¦

Making this film sounds like a far more harrowing experience than watching it. Director Del Tenney, a low-budget schlock specialist, had to extend his typical in-and-out shooting schedule by a week to deal with the fact that everyone was getting bitten by snakes and contracting various tropical diseases while shooting this in the Florida swamps. Somewhere in an attic or a rest home, there's got to be some b-roll footage of a cameraman dicking around and tracking a snake asâ€¦

Iâ€™ve got a deeply conflicted relationship with Christianity. Iâ€™m an admirer of the psychic architecture that is religion, and in particular the ancient and contradictory workings of the Roman Catholic Church. I also despise systems of control that exist only for their own betterment. This all applies to the legacy of Pope John Paul II, a man I had the fortune to meet once (he most certainly would not remember me), an embodiment of the will to greatness that theâ€¦

movietitle: Star Wars: The Rise of Skywalker
review: People are prone to extreme reactions and wild emotions when it comes to this franchise. I wish I could say the same. Something that requires billions of dollars to get a â€œmehâ€ result upon viewing bothers me on a gut level.The story concludes in ramshackle fashion, Emperor Palpatine suddenly showing up and surprise he was the villain the whole time I guess. Half two. A marked departure from the first volume, which was an almost unadulterated revenge rampage after the indignities suffered by the Bride, who pays back her assailants in kind. Unlike in the first volume, here the Bride is a much more human and vulnerable figure. Which she must be for the payoff to work.Volume 2 starts off with an extended look at what really happened in the little chapel on the outskirts of El Paso, and our firstâ€¦

Half one. Kill Bill was intended to be a single film, and from a director like Tarantino that means something. I'm unaware of how much editing surgery went on in post production to make this into two coherent films, but for something designed to be of a single piece by a man known for deliberate choices in filmmaking, it does cleave nicely into two halves.The easy distinction between the two films is the feel of the respective settings. Volumeâ€¦

There's a scene in this somewhere around the back third, where a local kid in a Peruvian village dances around while dragging her club foot behind her, our American ayahuasca tourists looking on from hammocks. It's a good stand-in for the total lack of self-awareness demonstrated by the filmmaker. Two wealthy Americans amble around Mexico and South America seeking out alternative remedies after exhausting all of the pricey "Western" medical intervention available, while one of the people who actually livesâ€¦

Went into this one with a little bit of trepidation. Michelangelo Antonioni is a bit of a blind spot for me and my only previous interaction was Blow Up, by which I felt utterly unmoved. This, though, this is my speed. Blow Up annoyed me in part because the plot's mystery is of secondary importance. Which was a problem for me because there felt like there was so little to grab onto besides how groovy Swingin' London looked. Similarly, L'Avventuraâ€¦

Styles for miles. This is a really cool little ghost story, and I like the deviation from the traditional narrative in having the ghost being the main character, and the viewer being aware that they are indeed a ghost from the get-go. Director H.P. Mendoza also takes an interesting approach in setting the mood. The action takes place in a brightly lit Victorian house, more suited visually for costume drama than horror movie. But the score, which is subtle andâ€¦

For a brief moment in the beginning of The Chambermaid, the specter of a misery narrative threatens to cast a pall over affairs. Eve (Gabriela Cartol), a service worker at an upscale Mexico City hotel, surveys the damage from a messy room and begins methodically cleaning up the unpleasant scene. She pauses, and you wonder what gross piece of human arcana she's encountered, and it's revealed that the occupant hasn't actually checked out, and instead he's fallen asleep under theâ€¦

movietitle: People Who Die Mysteriously in Their Sleep
review: As one of the remaining luddites who still uses Netflix's DVD-by-mail service, I've got this thing where once in a while I'll throw a bunch of stuff in the back end of my watchlist into the mail queue. This creates the singular experience of taking films that you've forgotten the reason for adding to your watchlist, and letting them stagnate in a slow-moving procession that periodically shows up at your door. Sometimes, a film will be out of print, andâ€¦

Enough of the old college try that I didnâ€™t feel annoyed when the proceedings jumped the rails in the third act. Maybe a touch disappointed, but you canâ€™t accuse writer/directors Jesse Holland and Andy Mitton of not putting out a solid effort. I respect the ambition of positing an answer to â€œwhat awaits us after we die,â€ even if that answer is inevitably anticlimactic.Basic premise is that our protagonist (Clark Freeman) is consumed by the fear of death, andâ€¦

For all I or anyone else knows, today is "Elder Abuse Tuesday" on North Sentinel Island and they're busy scooping out eyeballs, pop pop pop. Much like the casket unearthed by Father Udo Kier in the beginning, this cursed item ought to have been left in the ground.I'd heard that Dario Argento's more recent stuff wasn't very good. I wasn't prepared for Dario Argento forgetting basic stuff about filmmaking and making something abjectly terrible. It's incredible to think that this was the same person who directed Suspiria. Bit of rope-a-dope here. Nicolas Cage, playing the owner of a run-down Colombian hotel frequented by the underworld, is more understated than usual, keeping the manic impulses and wildness in check for almost the entire film. The events in the film, however, seem to follow the batshit logic of Cageland, and this resembles more than anything else one of those twenty-minute videos where a ball bearing is pushed along by various insane gadgets. The moment in which my efforts to repress my inner Marxist crumbled came right around the middle, in which Charlie (Adam Driver) takes the gloves off in a divorce proceeding, and right before a carefully negotiated settlement is about to be reached, blows everything up and writes a $25,000 check out of spite for the services of legal shark Ray Liotta. Hey kid. Yeah, you. I see you're loaded up for the latest iteration of the Generation Wars. Good for you. Don't trust anyone over thirty, until you actually turn thirty, and then you can spend the next fifteen years or so pretending you're still 25 before you hit 50, at which point you'll be wondering if we really should be feeding all those moocher climate refugees. Someone snag the cinematographers behind this. Beyond all the other stuff going on here, this was a beautifully shot film by Fejmi Daut and Samir Ljuma. What's more is that the visuals do a ton of the storytelling work, at times far more than the characters. Jesus Christ.The first lesson is that I need to give Sion Sono more of a chance. The only other film of his that I've seen is Love Exposure, which was impressive to me in stretches but seemed a bit overstuffed with wankery at a punishing four hour plus runtime. Go ahead and avoid reading this if you haven't seen the film yet. I don't believe in the spoiler checkbox as I find the act of making people click more things than necessary to be morally repugnant. The year of Adam Driver continues on, to the point where the Chinese government is seriously considering adding him to the zodiac.It's strange seeing the Bush II era starting to be immortalized in film more and more, and people like Sheldon Whitehouse and Tom Udall are portrayed by actors in big Hollywood dramas. Those who closely follow baseball know for a fact that The Devil takes an active role in the sport. There are 162 chances, at least, every season for you to be murderously angry or hopelessly crestfallen at the actions of others who are hundreds of miles away and care not a whit for your inconsequential anguish. The rules are different when you're watching something like this. I've been comfortable for many years considering Martin Scorsese to be the clear holder of the Greatest Living American Filmmaker title, and The Irishman doesn't do anything to change my mind on that matter. Maybe that's the issue here. My mind is really unchanged, in any respect, and I am precisely the same person I was before I watched this. Perhaps that's an unfair standard to hold anyone to, butâ€¦

War films have two main functions, whether their directors are conscious of them or not. They provide a viewpoint of a specific conflict, and commentary on war in general. From film to film, the extent to which those works perform either function varies. Some provide very deep insight into the particular flavor of a specific war, and some are more couched in the general view of the human condition.I thought of this while watching Come and See because itâ€¦

The less discerning have a habit of associating genius with being an asshole. To those yoked to the plow of cause and effect, there's a structured relationship between the two things. Some believe that success means that you now have the unmitigated right to be as distasteful as you wish, while others view a sociopathic attitude as the gateway to success. Really whiffed on the title here. Not only is Le Mans '66 by far the more fitting descriptor, "Ford v Ferrari" is an active little bit of disinformation as to what's going on. Yes, there's a corporate-funded quest to take that uppity old Eye-talian down a peg or two in a public racing event. I remember reading an article back in the 90s when Ian McKellan was really blowing up, coming off of Richard III and Apt Pupil. Back then, he was only in his fifties and already playing characters for whom "old" was a defining trait, something that he remarked on at the time. And then of course he donned the wizard beard and reinforced the image further. So seeing Ian McKellan actually be old in the present day is a little weird.â€¦

There are times when writing about a great comedy feels like putting some rare specimen of butterfly in a kill jar so you can study it later. Explaining the joke almost always nukes any feelings of joy you just experienced, and it's something I'd rather not do to one of the greatest movies about Hollywood ever made.Things I will say: This has quintessential performances from Steve Martin and Eddie Murphy. The revisionist spirit of the American West, played out in six spiritually convergent chapters. Not the first time the Coens have engaged in an examination of the Western that leaves no room for heroes. Unlike their previous efforts in that regard, the anthology format does something that goes a step further in eliminating the idea of a steady protagonist for the journey. This is the first film from co-directors and writers Britt Poulton and Dan Madison Savage, and it's surprising how in some areas they've got a deft directorial hand. Hands, I guess. I won't go so far as to say that this is above average in terms of cinematography, since Appalachia for all of its problems rivals anywhere you please in terms of natural beauty. I'm unqualified to pronounce large-scale judgments concerning Korean cinema, as someone who doesn't live in Korea and thus is only exposed to what's deemed worthy of export. But being unqualified never stopped anyone from doing anything, and as such I feel pretty comfortable in pronouncing Korean filmmakers the world's current authority on the class narrative. Hailing from the Empire of Income Inequality, I have yet to see anything from modern American film that comes close to capturing the yawning chasmâ€¦

No, I'm not going to have the inane "is it a Christmas movie" discussion with anyone.Whatever else John McTiernan might have done in his life, a life that includes going to prison for spy shit shenanigans, a string of failed marriages, The Last Action Hero, and some gnarly debts, he'll always have two things. Edward Norton took a lot of flack for setting his film adaptation of Motherless Brooklyn in the 1950s, as opposed to the novel's modern-day setting. Every once in a while you'll run into one of those English major types that will give you the spiel about the most beautiful turn of phrase in the language being "cellar door." Especially since that bit was incorporated into the Tolkien biopic. This assertion is wrong. The most lyrically pleasing phrase in the English language is "Doolemite, muthaphucka." Film and commerce have had a stormy relationship since pretty much the beginning. As intertwined as the two things are, though, they're still two separate things, with their own internal rules and guiding principles. Terminator: Dark Fate makes me think of this because, improbably, this is the second James Cameron project in a row that's underwhelmed financially, to the point that it may actually lose money in the real non-Hollywood accounting sense. I seem to have stumbled into my own moldering house of madness. I find The Old Dark House not nearly the film that its reputation hypes it up to be. Every time someone talks about the ballyhooed Golden Age of Television, they act as though well-constructed drama designed for the small screen is somehow a new phenomenon. Which ignores a long tradition of cross-pollination between the dramatic theater mindset and the extended television feature, coming to prominence with stuff like Playhouse 90 back in the 1950s. We'll just go ahead and accept the premise that there exists a Holy Trinity of werewolf films: The Wolf Man, An American Werewolf in London, and The Howling. This isn't to say that there aren't some incredible films outside of this triumvirate, but if you're asking what informs the popular imagination when it comes to our beloved lupine monsters on the silver screen, these are your signposts.What's funny about that is that in the intervening four decades since Theâ€¦

Good excuse to slam together a whole ton of cinematic flash fiction. This can't possibly be the first cinematic link between menstruation and lycanthropy. But it's the first one that I'm aware of, anyway, and it's a little surprising to me that the intersection isn't explored further.What for sure has been covered already is the common ground between teenagers and turning into a slavering, murderous dogbeast, and Ginger Snaps is a high point of the subgenre. It would make me less uneasy if Disney put out films that were clearly terrible. There'd be some kind of incentive then for audiences to react against the latest franchise installment, and finally hold someone accountable. But Disney is smart, and by now they've got this down to a science. The film that is juuuuust good enough to get you to park your ass without enough negative feelings associated with the experience that you'll do it again the next time.â€¦

Early William Garwood two-reeler. The scant information around this one is really too bad, because his leading lady in this one has an above average amount of presence for the format. Standard romantic melodrama with some boats tossed into it, of interest mostly to Garwood enthusiasts and historians looking for bits of old Thanhouser Company work.

You're all familiar with Lucy holding the football for Charlie Brown to kick, time after time, only to take it away at the last moment and deprive him of any sense of accomplishment or thrill at the partaking of sport. Charlie Brown knows better, really, not being a particularly bright kid but not an imbecile either. Lucy is animated by a lust for the frustration of others and would no sooner let him kick the ball than end her ownâ€¦

Such promise on the front end. Mata Hari opens without messing around, a line of firing squads being organized by the Great War-era French Army as they dispatch, one by one, a series of traitors and spies, all of whom are implied to have been turned by our seductive villainess. That's a dynamite hook, as we're introduced first to the end results of Mata's machinations, hapless fools being filled with lead and refusing to implicate here even as they're aboutâ€¦

So very frustrating. I won't say that I'd have rather had a straight-up terrible movie, because there were stretches of this that I was glad to be in the theater watching. Bernadette (Cate Blanchett) is a fantastic character, an always-watchable presence for the two hours and change that Richard Linklater has served up for us. Christ, though, the stuff weighing this down. I hate watching what could have been a good film get derailed by incompetence, and this is preciselyâ€¦

Maybe my expectations were easy to clear after selecting a piece of unheralded Netflix fodder that I wasn't aware existed fifteen minutes prior to watching it. Perhaps I'm more charitable to horror. But this is surprisingly watchable for something with no hype from the deeper recesses of the streaming service corner video store.I did a double-take in the opening, checking and confirming that yes, that's Janeane Garofalo playing the psychiatrist about to spring our hero onto the larger world.â€¦

And now the power of a fully-armed Greta Garbo is presented to the moviegoing public. By 1930, Garbo was a well-established box office name, and MGM had developed an idea of what kind of roles suited their enigmatic star. Anna Christie, released in both English and German sound versions, gives Garbo speech, and the full actor is now brought to bear. That low-pitched, lightly accented voice, another of her idiosyncrasies that just makes her more alluring, completes the package. Theâ€¦

movietitle: Scary Stories to Tell in the Dark
review: When youâ€™re adapting something for the screen, it requires an understanding of the original workâ€™s defining qualities. What is it that made this thing youâ€™re screenifying worthwhile in the first place, and how do you repackage that for the cinematic medium? That must have been a question that the committee behind this film asked themselves, and it looks like they came up with fifteen different answers and crammed them all into the end product.This lacks coherence of vision. Itâ€™sâ€¦

You'll never see the likes of this again. Not the main takeaway I got from La Strada, but it occurred to me that if you tried to pitch something like this today you'd get a bunch of doors in your face. A narrative that's essentially an extended clowning routine, starring an abusive circus strongman and his mentally challenged assistant that he purchased from her mother. You'd get a bunch of shuddering about clowns, and probably a few change.org petitions aboutâ€¦

It's legitimately hard to know where to start with this one. I'll just say that it's most certainly a bad movie. It's also one of the stranger experiences I've had recently, and I'm now inclined to check out Drew Bolduc's other films, and not in that snide "lol Neal Breen" way either. A bad movie that wasn't a waste of my time. There's plenty of room in my life for something like that.I feel like this should have beenâ€¦

Standard production-line one-reeler from IMP and director Thomas Ince, one little cog in the machine that he would build. Not a whole lot of substance here, just a two set minidrama in which Owen Moore learns to not be a jerk to his wife, Mary Pickford. Have to wonder whether writer Herbert Brenon was sticking the pins in here, since Moore's character is a drunken, abusive lout in much the same manner that Moore himself was a drunken, abusive loutâ€¦

A dirtier, more scandalous version of director Clarence Brown's previous film, Flesh and the Devil. John Gilbert and Greta Garbo once again anchor the cast with a doomed love affair, and there's a lot of the same story beats. Gilbert loves Garbo, Gilbert has to go away for an extended period of time, Garbo gets married to his friend, anguish ensues, onward to tragic ending where Garbo pays the price for everyone's sins. Applause, thanks Mr. Brown, onto the nextâ€¦

Destined for year-end "best of" lists, if not necessarily heaps of award statues. For my money, however, this is the latest in a deflating trend of indie misfires in 2019.Joanna Hogg spreads her wings with The Souvenir, or Auteur Theory: The Movie. And on a technical level you have to respect it. This is clearly the work of someone with years of experience in film, and each shot is intensely composed, making for a gallery showing of moments fromâ€¦

Serviceable melodrama notable for being the first time onscreen together for Greta Garbo and John Gilbert, real life lovers with a tempestuous relationship off the screen who would make a series of films together to the delight of the press. For what itâ€™s worth, these two do have a remarkable amount of chemistry together, which I suppose theyâ€™d better for all of the personal investment.Sort of amusing to consider this American production of Imperial Germany and her aristocrats, notâ€¦
Poorly acted, poorly directed, ill-conceived and badly timed. Thorough waste of time that canâ€™t even succeed in pissing someone off with its subject material. Â Not worth the powder.

Dominant feelings/motifs/whatever the hell:- The seeker.- Clear dividing lines; between the ocean and the land, civilization and nature, man and woman, stages of self.- Systems of control.- Imposition of roles on women.- Multiple visions of self.- Chess.Maya Deren's a film jazz artist and a lot of her style informs At Land. Visual beats like repetition of action in 1-3 second snippets and straight lines cutting through scenes serve as a signature. The dominantâ€¦

Homer is my go-to when people feel the need to burnish their cultural creds by bashing the superhero genre. So, you don't care for tales of super-powered warriors fighting, improbable escapes, deus ex machinas, gratuitous romance, and third act revenge against bad guys? Well then, you stand against the very roots of narrative itself, because you just tried to crack on The Odyssey. Good luck with that.I think you'd have to work hard to make a version of Theâ€¦

I'm taken aback at how well this has held up. Rob Reiner is not a deep man and has inflicted some real three-hanky manipulations on us over the years, and if you're so inclined, you've got all the ammo you need to be dismissive of Stand by Me. It's a Stephen King story, making it an opportune target for the anti-middlebrow crowd. It's a 1950s small-town American vision of a clearly delineated coming-of-age, easy to jettison as musings of aâ€¦

I hope that David Lynch has got at least a few more projects in him, if for no other reason than the hope that he'll get to work with Nic Cage again. There's a whole roster of Lynch regulars at work here. Laura Dern, Harry Dean Stanton, Jack Nance, David Patrick Kelly, and on and on. Cage fits right in there with his signature combustible goofball vibe. Imagine what both men could do now with their powers heightened further byâ€¦

If there's a dividing line between trash films that entertain and trash films that burgle time, it's conviction. Sadly for director Matthew Williams and friends, he ignores the advice of antiquity and hesitatingly looks back after he's begun his journey. Like Lot and Orpheus before him, all is lost once he deviates from his resolve.If the fact that the film is called "Maniac Farmer" didn't tip you off to the grade of film to expect, the first five minutesâ€¦

This review is for the cut shown to American audiences, which regrettably runs about an hour and ten minutes. Yeeesh.In this format, what weâ€™re left with is a regrettable melodrama that does a disservice to director G.W Pabst and omits almost entirely Asta Nielsenâ€™s portions of the film. The story is reworked to focus almost entirely on Greta Garboâ€™s character, a dutiful daughter trying to keep her family from starvation in postwar Vienna after her father (Jaro Furth) makesâ€¦

Solid, no-nonsense documentary that really brings home how damn dangerous open ocean sailing is. I kept waiting for people to be pitched over the side in the rough seas, which thankfully doesnâ€™t happen to any of the crew of the Maiden but does happen to other competitors in the Whitbread race during the course of the film.Tracy Edwards makes a compelling subject, steely gaze and death wish on full display. Alex Holmes does a good job piecing the storyâ€¦

movietitle: Anchorman: The Legend of Ron Burgundy
review: There are two phases of life. Before the man punted Baxter, and after the man punted Baxter.

Endlessly rewatchable and thereâ€™s always something else to dwell on afterward. Iconic scene after iconic scene.There seems to have been a greater appreciation for Jackie Brown lately, which followed this up. What made Jackie Brown a great film is in here too; extended romantic chemistry. The scenes with John Travolta and Uma Thurman together are always my favorite in this one.Vincent and Mia are one of the all-time great depictions of two people just clicking together. The circumstancesâ€¦

Get yourself a really comfortable chair, because here comes a sprawling, three hour Swedish epic told in ten acts. Mauritz Stiller deserves quite a bit of credit for his job directing this. For a film that's almost entirely about the Swedish nobility consuming itself, this production demanded a lot. There are lots of scenes shot from the back of a sled going across rough terrain (including ice), many scenes which take place out in the freezing woods, and apparently theyâ€¦

This is just so unapologetically goofy that I can't help but like it. How are you not going to have a good time with a van full of volleyball girls spiking balls into the faces of inbred French hillbillies while trying to avoid being cannibalized?There's exploding heads every time a shotgun goes off, a cannibal cult, volleyball used as martial arts, a decapitated guy that just sort of walks through the background, a guy pulling a chihuahua's head offâ€¦

I had to laugh when I found out that that director Lulu Wang is fucking Barry Jenkins. It was only a matter of time before he literally dipped his wick into the indie/A24 serious drama scene. Just perfect.I like Jenkins just fine, by the way. It doesn't make A24 stretching out its tendrils like an octopus and Jenkifying (does he say that when he's about to do anything sex-related?) whole swathes of independent cinema any less annoying. Pretty soon,â€¦

The film equivalent of one of those Magic Eye paintings. For the first hour or so, Serenity seemed like a standard issue brainless thriller, the kind that they film so that people can have a working vacation, in this case a beach trip to Mauritius. I had recalled seeing low ratings and scathing reviews, but what I was watching didn't seem to warrant such an adverse reaction. Forgettable, kind of dumb, sure. But nothing that really stood out in activeâ€¦

Rolls along calmly like a lazy day drifting on a delta current. A little turbulence here and there to liven up the ride, but nothing that's going to capsize you.Lynn Shelton's put together something that's real and humane without falling into the contemptible recesses of fakery. There are few things as hateful as people learning valuable lessons. Lord preserve us from narratives with a treasure map goal of personal growth leading the viewer through Potemkin villages hammered together outâ€¦

movietitle: Once Upon a Time... in Hollywood
review: Inglourious Basterds was Quentin Tarantino's presentation of the dark side of the movie industry. Once Upon a Time in Hollywood is the other side of that, a specific period in time now fixed forever in the man's imagination and preserved for us. This is the most hopeful and optimistic of Tarantino's films, even as it documents people at the end of their useful lives. It's also Tarantino letting his love of movies completely off the chain, even more so thanâ€¦

Thereâ€™s some kinship here between I Trapped the Devil and Beyond the Black Rainbow. Both films are first time directors with an abiding respect for psychological horror planting some stylistic flags. Both directors are newcomers with enough industry savvy to make something that might not feel polished but doesnâ€™t look amateur either. And like Beyond the Black Rainbow, I Trapped the Devil falls a little short of remarkable due to its glacial pacing.Josh Loboâ€™s an atmosphere man. Cool, Iâ€¦

Quentin Tarantino famously calls this a Southern. Hard to really evaluate that since few, if any other films can really claim to trace lineage from Django Unchained, itself a rich fusion of the spaghetti western, revenge story and blaxploitation films. Whatever it is, make more of that.Folks will probably consider this part of a Revenge Trilogy, along with Inglourious Basterds and Kill Bill, although like a lot of other cases this is more of a double feature with Basterds.â€¦

From the â€œitâ€™s all been said beforeâ€ files. The first twenty minutes is a masterpiece of filmmaking, and the best scene that Tarantinoâ€™s ever shot. Unalduterated exploitation delivered by the Basterds and their unstinting cruelty to every German they meet. One of Tarantinoâ€™s best written characters ever in Hans Landa. Shoshannaâ€™s maniacal laughter projected onto the smoke of the burning theater.Itâ€™s the ways that Tarantino fucks with you that provide the deeper enjoyment to go along with the fireworks.â€¦

A keystone of Chicano cinema, starting with the presence of Edward James Olmos. Set in East LA, the spiritual center of the Mexican-American experience. You've got the immigrant narrative. You've got gangbangers. Big family celebrations and relatives in prison. Religiosity and superstition. Politics. The struggle to live in a society that tells you to assimilate but then refuses you when you do. Gregory Nava has a sweeping vision that might not be deep enough from character to character, but wideâ€¦

The universe has a way of straightening you out when you go in with preconceived notions. I'd heard about this one based on my interest in the emerging Oaklandcore scene, and the director was unknown to me. Exciting. Primed up for something new that expands the Oakland Cinematic Universe, I screened this expecting to be engaged. And at first it looks like you might have an intriguing film on your hands. It's when you realize that Dave's (Mike Delaney) cringinglyâ€¦

The most distinguishing feature of East Side Sushi is its combination of earnest, sweetly gentle storytelling with an unflinching view of what it's like to live your days in an East Oakland barrio. There's a tendency when filmmakers portray socioeconomic distress to go one of two ways; the scary urban hellhole where everyone is constantly killing each other, or the soul-crushing antechamber where people have just enough time to wallow in poverty before something even worse happens. Little danger ofâ€¦

Peterloo is a cousin to the Dickensian narrative. The grand scale of Mike Leigh's film and its roster of characters feel familiar. As do the mirrored worlds of towering wealth and grinding poverty, a theme which Dickens stamped indelibly on the English soul, if not its conscience. What makes this interesting is that all of the treacly sweetener of Dickens has been stripped away from this story. There is no angelic woman to serve as the chaste love interest, elevatingâ€¦

Found footage horror from Barry Levinson, of all people. That carries some novelty.Because Levinson is a seasoned Hollywood pro, The Bay manages to avoid some of the worst parts of found footage. The perspective is broken up into an array of camera viewpoints, the special effects aren't phoned in, and the acting isn't terrible (though it isn't all that great, either). The presentation is slicker than one is used to with these, which makes it much less of aâ€¦

Lightning in a bottle. There's a lot here that shouldn't work. Ju-on: The Grudge doesn't really have a story, outside of the gradually unfolding explanation as to what happened to Kayako in order to turn her house into a gateway to Hell. The budget is barebones, which forces a number of stylistic choices and casting decisions that should have just strangled the film from birth. And for a movie in which (by my count) 15 people die, there's very littleâ€¦

Not the most lurid witch-burning to start a film, but this is a more deliberate affair than all that. The City of the Dead (aka Horror Hotel, woof) is a proper Englishman's scare, even if it's set in New England and even if John Moxey is an Argentinian chap. This doesn't preclude the good old salacious bits to be found in a movie about witches, but these are served at the proper times later in the film. Harrumph.Christopher Leeâ€¦

Probably more of a teaching aide than a film as such. Edward James Olmos steps behind the camera once more to tell the tale of the 1968 Chicano Blowouts. Michael PeÃ±a, playing real-life organizer Sal Castro, opens the film in his classroom, instructing his students and therefore the viewer about the power of who's writing history and telling one's own story. Given how little is known about the organized student walkouts among Mexican-American students and their allies in the lateâ€¦

Chronicling part two of Fridayâ€™s housebound superhero filmstravaganza.The more of these I watch the more I think Bruce Banner is the best character. Of all the people in this heâ€™s got the most interesting stuff going on. Wants to be left alone, both for his and the worldâ€™s benefit. Intellectual equal to Tony Stark and also a giant clobber monster that gets to jump scare people. Has lines with Harry Dean Stanton. Itâ€™s hard to call Mark Ruffalo underappreciated,â€¦

Part one of a â€œhigh on pain pills and immobileâ€ Friday night marathon of easily digestible movies.The pulp adventure setting and themes of this one are a good match for the genre. Makes you think that maybe theyâ€™ll finally be able to make a decent Doc Savage or Flash Gordon movie. Scrawny Chris Evans was certainly weird.Things blow up, Nazis and/or their close associates get punched, the Captain America comic book exists within the MCU, Hayley Atwell isâ€¦

The title gore here is just head-scratching. This is listed as "Little Nemo" under more sane auspices. Maybe this played better in the era of Esteemed Professor Festus' Electro-Nerve Tonic and Horse Polish.I live for stuff like this in early cinema, moments where someone just blows the doors off the kind of quota-chum one reelers that dominate the landscape. Winsor McCay already had made a name for himself by this point as the artist of Little Nemo in Slumberland,â€¦

You'll get a good acid test for 2019 when you see Cheech Marin triumphantly leading a wave of illegal immigrants over a hillside and into the United States as Neil Diamond plays in the background. Someone at a major studio would have a stroke if you pitched that to them now. Latino filmmakers of the world, reboot this movie and lay waste to whole provinces of Amalgamated Disney.If the soundtrack, neo-slapstick antics and teased hairdos haven't advertised which stopâ€¦

This is a performance roadster desperately fishtailing all over an icy road. There are stretches where this film feels glorious as it opens up and runs, and there are moments when you're covering your eyes and just waiting to careen into a ditch. By the end of the ride, you can't say that it wasn't worth it, and you have to tip your hat to the driver's skill in keeping the car on the road. But things could have reallyâ€¦

Tons of history here, starting with director Herbert Biberman, one of the Hollywood Ten that was the first group of filmmakers to be blacklisted in 1947. Salt of the Earth was one of only two films he would make after being booted out of the Directors Guild of America, the other being Slaves in 1969. There's the film's star, Rosaura Revueltas, a pioneering figure in Mexican cinema who came to the US after the Catholic Church encouraged boycotts of 1951'sâ€¦

The lesson here is that anytime a former stunt man decides to take the director's chair and then cast an accomplished martial artist in the lead, it's worth a viewing.Jesse V. Johnson, taking a page from the fantastic John Wick films, decides to give the people what they want. And the people demand kickboxing. Scott Adkins is great here as avengementer Cain Burgess, who was apparently cursed from birth by his mother naming him after history's all-time crappy sibling.â€¦

Much like any genre film, when you're watching a rom-com there's a certain list of criteria you're looking for out of the experience. Are your leads likeable? Is there an actual comedy component? Do you exit the experience on something of a lighter emotional plane than you started? There's honor in being a serviceable movie, and Ana Maria in Novela Land does its job well.The differentiator is that this is an affectionate parody of the hyper-soap telenovela genre, whichâ€¦

Mi Vida Loca is one of the purer expressions of what it is to be Mexican-American. Not everyone came up in East LA, and not everyone is a gangbanger, a statement that feels obvious but I guess needs to be made. The story of communities in America is generational, and this is a story of how even five years in an age cohort makes a huge difference in how the world looks, interior and exterior. Itâ€™s also a necessary counterpointâ€¦

I put cash on the barrel for alligators biting people a lot. Thatâ€™s precisely what I got, so I consider it a fair exchange.Alexandre Aja does a good job with a solid setup for a summertime thriller in the era of climate change. Woman goes in the basement. Gatorâ€™s in the basement. Our gator. And then thereâ€™s a lot of gators. Me gusta. The continually rising floodwaters in the basement coupled with alligators biting everyone went nicely with a couple of beers and a popcorn.Delivers exactly what you expect and what you want out of one of these.

Very A24. Not necessarily a good or bad thing in and of itself, but you know what youâ€™re getting here.Solid body snatcher story. Paranoia is always a dominant feeling with these, and Under the Skin is a clever subversion of that mood. The audience is privy to the identities from almost the very beginning, which puts the tension into an inevitable clock ticking away on everyone that our alien thingie (Scarlett Johansson) meets as she drives around Scotland forâ€¦

All the Presidentâ€™s Men occupies a no manâ€™s land. Too long after the event to get any of the thrill of the recent past coming to the big screen, too soon to prevent the history from spoiling the plot from the start. And without these gravity assists it floats along in an orbit of procedural journalism and a succession of bland, minor functionaries that eventually lead to the filmâ€™s resolution.I was surprised at how little I enjoyed this. Redfordâ€¦

movietitle: Neon Genesis Evangelion: The End of Evangelion
review: Enough of a reputation for being bizarre that I went all-in and watched the series leading up to the ending movie. Though I guess this isn't the only film to go with the end of the series. Also there's apparently other movies which reinterpret the events of the original series. I have no clue.I don't know enough about Anno Hideaki the man to really tease out how autobiographical this is supposed to be, although there's clearly some personal baggageâ€¦

Sometimes you just have to meet something halfway. It would be the easiest thing in the world to dismiss Kesari as overly schmaltzy, clichÃ©d propaganda. And in fact it is part of an ongoing publicity campaign being undertaken by the Indian Army and Punjabi filmmakers. Anurag Singh does not tap the brakes at all in his portrayal of a heroic band of martyrs led by their superhuman commander, Ishar Singh (Akshay Kumar). Every war movie clichÃ© in the book getsâ€¦

Adventures of unpeople in the capital of both filmmaking and Chicano America, Los Angeles. A lot of hallmarks of realism are here. Long, quiet shots, documentation of day-to-day existence, an almost entirely amateur cast. There's no music save an annoying teenage home DJ for a few moments. This kind of filmmaking tends to lean heavy on visual eye candy and mise-en-scÃ¨ne, but there's scarce relief to be had in The Bastards. JesÃºs (Jesus Moises Rodriguez) and Fausto (RubÃ©n Sosa) existâ€¦

They sure knew what economy of storytelling was in the early days. In the space of fifteen minutes, a young man (Sidney Olcott starring and directing) departs his bleak Irish countryside home, sails to America, works his way up from toiling on construction sites to be elected to public office, and makes it in the big time. Meanwhile, his winsome lass (film pioneer Gene Gauntier, who writes and co-directs) is stuck in the dismal poverty that will endure right alongsideâ€¦

Pretty standard-issue melodrama of the variety D.W. Griffith was beginning to pump out in earnest around this time period. This one's interesting in that you can tell that Griffith is a quick learner. The pacing on this one flows a lot better once he gets a better sense of how editing moves the action, sparing us earlier things like extended shots of people walking and other bits of less-than-excitement.Despite Griffith's lifelong fascination with the Confederacy and Lost Cause thinking,â€¦

The creepiest part of this film by far is the little kid, who looks like an animate Hummel figurine. I googled him and he's now a tech executive in Chicago somewhere. I like to think he's just a larger version of what he looked like in this movie.We come to the final installment of Lucio Fulci's Gates of Hell trilogy with The House by the Cemetery, the weakest of the three films. Things started off exceptionally with City ofâ€¦

Context, context, context. Coming into this cold is likely to leave one cold. When you consider all of the things that went into Pather Panchali and the efforts that Satyajit Ray went to in order to make this passion project a reality, though, it's hard not to have a large amount of esteem. I'm not on board necessarily with this film's enshrinement as one of the "best ever" canon; I feel like something with that distinction should grab you byâ€¦

Up until about the 70s or so, this was the kind of film that was really popular for a certain kind of socially conscious white liberal to make. After that point, the various Chicano movements had developed fully enough to be able (or more likely willing) to take over behind the camera to tell these migrant worker stories. And thereâ€™s nothing wrong with a white guy telling these stories; Robert Young did a fine job of it in Alambrista. Josephâ€¦

Successful deployment of the formula. Low points include a painfully long scene in which the villain delivers exposition in a room full of people who are already familiar with all of the villain reasoning and Nick Fury apparently turning his brain off. Thatâ€™s largely evened out by the extra dose of humor that this one had, and the opportunity to do cool visual stuff with the illusion tech.The scenes with all the high school kids are enjoyable. Easy toâ€¦

Iâ€™ll have to watch at least one other Alex Ross Perry film at some point in order to properly assess some of the motivations for choices made in making Her Smell. Given the generally positive reaction this has gotten, Iâ€™m guessing however that this is well within his baseline and that Iâ€™m likely not going to enjoy further research.I canâ€™t honestly tell if Iâ€™m supposed to feel something for Becky Something (Elisabeth Moss) because sheâ€™s a human and allâ€¦

Sometimes I think that South Korean cinema exists solely as a PR campaign to dissuade people from pissing off Koreans.The lockdown on modern revenge stories continues with I Saw the Devil. I enjoy the vengeance narrative; well-worn as it is, it's usually a pretty efficient setup for gonzo, no-holding-back action violence. Being made to watch the opening sequence in which Jang Kyung-chul (Choi Min-sik) brutally serial murders an aspiring psychopath's fiancÃ©e gives us all we really need as toâ€¦

Alambrista is something of a hybrid between a travelogue and a picaresque narrative. The hero moves from one adventure to the next, meeting a succession of challenges and new characters as he pursues his quest. Robert Young does two interesting things, though; he strips a lot of the heroic elements out of the story, and he essentially removes the voice from the character after the first ten minutes of the film, only really to return at the very end.Thisâ€¦

Pretty much everything you could want from a movie where a creepy doll starts murdering people. A definite theater-only experience. The teen girl squad sitting to my side provided ample amusement with the constant tittering and screaming.Lars Klevberg does the job and checks the boxes, which is really all I want. The doll repeatedly creeps people out, and the grotesque animatronic expressions do a fine job on that count. The kills are nicely bloody, with great over-the-top dismemberments andâ€¦

Before hitting it big with La Bamba, Luis Valdez was paying his dues as a guerilla theater orchestrator and traveling the dusty fields of California with the United Farm Workers. A consummate theater guy, Zoot Suit was an established Broadway play before he filmed a version of it in 1981. As a filmed play more than a film, it's a little rough around the edges, since you're arranging things for a traditional stage perspective but also competing against that vantageâ€¦

The grief artist, Ari Aster.A director's second feature starts to give us clues about who they really are. Expanding from one point to two starts to give us an idea of where they might be headed and enables comparisons, as far as those are productive, to start occurring. While we lack the sense of trajectory that a third point on the plot would provide, certain things begin to be apparent with Midsommar. Aster is keenly interested in the sufferingâ€¦

Cecelia Condit will be buried with a camcorder like some sort of VHS pharaoh as she continues to the next step of whatever journey she's on. If I were to go early there would be worse things than being entombed as a retainer on the voyage into deeper dimensions of late 20th century American tract homes and shopping malls.You'd shoot this today and it would be yet another piece of irony being vomited out of a bearded son ofâ€¦

movietitle: White Fawn's Devotion: A Play Acted by a Tribe of Red Indians in America
review: The earliest known (surviving) example of Native American cinema. It's weird how much of cinema as an art form, which we regard as a thoroughly modern medium, is shrouded in mystery in its early years. James Young Deer, who directed this film along with a bunch of others for legendary studio PathÃ© and eventually came to run its operations in proto-Hollywood for a time, is a pretty enigmatic figure. He's one of those guys for whom most of his historyâ€¦

One of those films where everythingâ€™s been written before. But the hell with it Iâ€™ll write something anyway.Not a minute of this feels wasted. Almost every single line is a gag, the action is madcap and the film is chock full of kooky, by-the-seat-of-the-pants plans and schemes. Tony Curtis is great as he switches between three characters, sometimes within seconds of each other, and is hilarious as Shell Oil Junior. Jack Lemmon is a fantastic goofball, and gets funnierâ€¦

Real unfortunate timing here. I feel like we've hit market saturation for musical rises to stardom, the dangers of fame, and CGI crowds filling stadiums to hear classic rock mainstays in the last six months. And to be fair to Danny Boyle here, Yesterday isn't quite as obnoxious in its hero worship as Bohemian Rhapsody or Rocketman before it, although there's more than a little of that going on. But there's still a "so very tired" aura radiating off thisâ€¦

All right, so you're all wound up after you get home from work, multiple trains of thought running through your head, the stress still radiating off your brain after a day full of cranking it up. What do you do, hot shot. It's hard to imagine doing much better than plopping your ass down in an easy chair, settling in with a mild mind alterant of your choice, and just watching Robert Redford do his calm, competent, easygoing thing inâ€¦

Presenting this as a documentary is a shaky proposition. Robert Greene does not make it clear what the extent of the filmmakers' role was in staging the re-enactment of the Bisbee Deportation. While there are numerous scenes featuring planning committees and local residents preparing for the centennial, we never quite know how much of this is organic and how much this process was coordinated by outside parties. It does seem clear that the re-enactment itself is staged with considerable helpâ€¦

Asta Nielsen announces herself at the start of the 1910s. Trends toward longer films, more narrative-driven features, and movie stars have been coalescing for some time by 1910, but things will really start to take off from this point. Nielsen, who will come to be known as "Die Asta" by her adoring public, delivers a challenging performance in one of the most psychologically complex stories committed to film at this time. It's easy to see how this would have grabbedâ€¦

Good choice if you're kind of in the mood for The Third Man, but maybe something a little lighter.I've seen Our Man in Havana described as a comedy in a lot of quarters. Not sure that I'd call it that, although the first third of the film or so has some funny parts, mostly revolving around Jim Wormold's (Alec Guinness) feckless imitations of Hawthorne (Noel Coward), himself a feckless intelligence operative. From then on things get progressively dark, andâ€¦

movietitle: The Last Black Man in San Francisco
review: It's possible that I'm not giving this one a fair shot. I grew up in the East Bay and San Francisco was always the shinier but less authentic cousin to Oakland in the local consciousness, to varying degrees of accuracy. It doesn't help that so many powerful narratives about race have come out of Oakland as a setting in recent years, which invite direct comparison. Still. The weaknesses in the film kept being paired with little whispers in my headâ€¦

A Sunday afternoon rewatch that's granted a little hindsight. 2018 was a landmark year in Oaklandcore filmmaking, giving us this along with the far less heralded Sorry to Bother You and the critically overlooked Blindspotting. This collection of films marks an evolving approach to the black cinematic experience, and something of a fork in the road. There are films which beseech the viewer that black folks are people too, proffering up Christlike suffering to various ends and taking a moreâ€¦

The good news? This wasnâ€™t nearly the unnecessary cash grab that it looked like from all the promos. Though grab cash it certainly has. I was expecting an eye roll rate comparable to the Incredibles sequel, and thank Movie Jesus it was instead a decently entertaining outing.That said, I wish Pixar had left well enough alone. Iâ€™m somewhat conflicted about what their product has become as it stands. The writing is generally above that of the standard issue animatedâ€¦

I was not expecting the best giallo film I've ever seen to be a French production in the late 2010s. But here we are.The first instinct a viewer might have is that you're looking at one of those homages, and there's nothing wrong with films like that. Berberian Sound Studio is a great example of one, a film that's a love letter to a genre, delivered in a satisfying package. Knife+Heart is something different. Whether or not Yann Gonzalezâ€¦

Inveterate masher Mr. Flip (played by a young Ben Turpin) flails about and attempts various attempts at grabbery of young ladies' bosoms. It's really unfortunate that pepper spray wasn't around in these days. Turpin would have really understood the comedic value of someone writhing around in pain after being blasted in the eyes with a hilarious stinging liquid.Nonetheless, the ladies make do with a variety of humorous defense mechanisms, ranging from seltzer bottles to anal impalement to electrocution. Unfortunatelyâ€¦

Really cool early sci-fi courtesy of Walter Booth, who like a lot of the pioneers had a lasting enthusiasm for what illusions could be performed on film. This guy pumped out a ton of "trick films" from the get-go, and had a definite fascination for airships and destruction. Interesting to me that Booth had conceptualized the idea of death from above well before this was viewed as a viable military tactic, which hadn't even caught on until after the beginningâ€¦

A little bit of the macabre, and some grist for an exploration of the psychological connection between sexual transgression and living entombment.Noteworthy for Arthur V. Johnson hamming it up as the Count even by early silent film standards, though he does go so far over the top as to be genuinely demented.
