The Count knocking on the sealed up room entrance and taunting the two lovers as they suffocate is pretty dark stuff, as is his dispatching of his two reluctant stonemasons.Early Mary Pickford appearance, though it's of the blink-and-you'll-miss-it variety.

movietitle: Princess Nicotine; or, The Smoke Fairy
review: This film reaaally speaks to me for some reason.*takes gratuitously long drag on my second cigarette since starting to write this*Tobacco companies begin their long love affair with movies here. On the positive side of the ledger, they associate themselves with a fun little exercise in by-now established visual effects. I really love the employment of rudimentary techniques to achieve fantastical elements in early film. Most notable is the use of perspective to create the illusion of theâ€¦

My favorite part of this one is the perspective. Even though I don't care for the excessive bumbling and clownery of Tahei (Minoru Chiaki) and Matashichi (Kamatari Fujiwara), I love that this film is basically the story that these two goobers are going to tell together when they finally get back to their village after their adventures. And as a grand adventure story, The Hidden Fortress is fantastic.These stories always seem to go best when the antagonist is Theâ€¦

Maya Deren plants the flag of occultism firmly in the unforgiving cinematic ground of 1944. The sensationalized imagery of a woman chanting with a pentagram etched on her forehead must have surely been provocative in a way that would register with a young Kenneth Anger. That's neat and all, but this is packed full of some strangely disturbing imagery beyond the immediate.More than the blaring neon-lit witchcraft iconography, the motifs of strings and lines are what really leave theâ€¦

movietitle: We Have Always Lived in the Castle
review: If there's anything that movies have taught me, it's that all mansions should be preemptively burned down, as there's always something hideous going on in them. Especially those abutted by spooky woods. Trouble brewin'.It's hard not to want more from We Have Always Lived in the Castle, which hints at quite a bit of sinister activity and even supernatural elements, but never really fully avails itself of them. There's a pleasing Addams Family vibe from the surviving members ofâ€¦

The issues with All Is True are almost perfectly encapsulated in the scene between Shakespeare (Kenneth Branagh, also directing) and the Earl of Southampton (Ian McKellen). It's an underutilization of acting talent, giving about ten minutes total in the film to McKellen, in the same spirit of getting Judi Dench so that she can mostly stand around and frown at Shakespeare. It introduces something fairly controversial (Shakespeare's theorized homosexuality) without delving much into it, tossing a bomb and then forgettingâ€¦

My brother described to me the other day the scenes with Keanu Reeves, and I decided the hell with it. Iâ€™ll continue inflicting these films on myself. I was pleasantly surprised. This is inoculated against netflix originalitis by Ali Wong and Randall Park, who really put something into this film. Their writing and the heart with which they play these characters differentiate this from a thousand other algorithm rom coms. The end result is a sweetly told story that feelsâ€¦

Had no idea how badly I needed this. Iâ€™ve taken in a lot of cinematic poison lately. Itâ€™s art, itâ€™s truth, and the truth increasingly poisons, but even so itâ€™s a little rough in the interior mindscape sometimes. So Iâ€™ll accept some assistance from a different time, and a different Hollywood.Julius Epstein, one of Casblancaâ€™s scriptwriters, affectionately noted that the story has more corn than the states of Iowa and Kansas combined. A Warner Brothers production analyst called itâ€¦

Late-stage Jim Jarmusch is about just hanging out for a couple of hours in Jarmuschland with some amusing and interesting folks, and if some hijinks ensue so that we can stretch our legs for a bit, hey, so much the better. As an illegal immigrant in Jarmuschland, I'm always happy to visit. This must be how more refined individuals than myself feel about Bresson or Tarkovsky.That all said, this is an easy film to hate if you're not intoâ€¦

Not quite the showstopper that the previous year's Satan at Play was for Segundo de ChomÃ³n, but still a charming early exercise in pushing the limits.Stop motion's your huckleberry here, and The Electric Hotel is essentially nonstop, meticulous examples of it. With a good showman's eye, De ChomÃ³n ramps it up, starting small with a bag of luggage putting itself away, escalating to a man (Mr. De ChomÃ³n himself, who looks exactly like I expected him to look) gettingâ€¦

Early Russian narrative piece about Cossack folk hero Stenka Razin. I'm a little surprised that Vladimir Romashkov was able to make a film about a pretty subversive figure in the midst of the Romanov dynasty's ongoing clampdown on dissent in the era. Nonetheless, the story is apolitical, and most of the footage is of dudes partying, first in boats on the Volga, and then in the forest.Not much of note in this one other than historical significance. It's oneâ€¦

Interesting little bit of proto-animation. Unlike the 1900 film The Enchanted Drawing, this employs true animation techniques, as opposed that film's reliance on editing to achieve the effect.Less narrative than proof of concept for another cinematic innovation, still an imaginative little reverie.

D.W. Griffith's debut directorial feature. And of course he heads straight for the racial stereotypes, the action driven by a pair of villainous, scheming gypsies who kidnap a kid because of a minor spat started by their inherent criminality. And to be clear, just because it's 1908 doesn't mean that film is somehow awash in ethnic villainy roles because of the times. The Adventures of Dollie is an outlier at this point and key to understanding the proper place theâ€¦

Mou Tun-fei is an interesting figure in cinematic history if nothing else. A film student from a school with no cameras, he was one of the first (if not only) Shaw Brothers directors to film a production in cooperation with mainland China, after amassing a resume that ranged between children's kung fu movies and hardcore pornography. He's an unreliable narrator for the history of Men Behind the Sun, as he's walked back a lot of the initial explanations for howâ€¦

Thought for the day: I really don't like what it says about our current state of mind that we increasingly revisit the apocalypse narrative. There's more than a little wish fulfillment underlying this impulse that if only we wiped the slate clean without so many people around, which includes any number of unspoken groups that the viewer doesn't care for, we could get it right this time. It speaks to some of the uglier aspects of the zeitgeist.I Amâ€¦

Hoooo boy. Now thatâ€™s exploitation.I could see someone being pissed off after watching this. Thatâ€™s okay. Thatâ€™sgood. Lord, give us now an actual, legitimate reason to get riled up about a film, that we may know we still feel things beyond reflexive anti or a bean counterâ€™s love of quotas. I wouldnâ€™t argue with someone who finds Deadgirl repellent. But itâ€™s a full measure, and for that I nod my head in acknowledgement.Thereâ€™s a difference between thingsâ€¦

Garage sale VHS image quality and Video Toaster effects place you firmly in an uncanny predator world from the very start. The loopy narration and Karen Skladany's insane score plant you where you stand. Short film tends to have an alternate reality feel to it to begin with. Cecelia Condit runs as fast as she can into this corner of the multiverse for fifteen minutes.The presentation as one of those oddities that the great archaeologist Internet coughs up fromâ€¦

Not sure how this one acquired the reputation it has. This is the kind of heartbreak you set yourself up for when you have an ill-advised love for found footage films.It's difficult to pinpoint the main problem with The Poughkeepsie Tapes. The first thing that comes to mind is the awful acting by the guy playing the killer (Ben Messmer). I'm not sure if anyone could have done much with the seventh-grader's vision of a serial killer presented byâ€¦

Kenneth Anger's work is slippery. You go looking for it on the internet, and you'll find eight different versions of something in the first five results. Anger himself shoots stuff, lets it sit for decades, and then edits and rereleases differing versions years apart. In this particular case, we've got footage shot in 1950 that doesn't get released until the 1970s, and in two distinct versions. Complicating matters, the version of Rabbit's Moon I got my hands on is theâ€¦

I love how science is portrayed in the 1950s. It must have felt bracing to look upon the world as a master of the atom, all societal problems just a research groupâ€™s efforts away from being solved. Thereâ€™s a feeling that youâ€™re on the doorstep of Utopia when you see clean cut men and women in lab coats busily coming up with breakthrough after breakthrough. It says a lot about the mindset of the time that a good wellspring ofâ€¦

Not quite an Asylum version of a standard MCU release. But thatâ€™s generally the spirit of this one.I think I may have preferred a straight knock off of the genuine article. Itâ€™s deflating to watch a cast of a-listers perform well below their usual standards. Tom Hardy leads the pack looking generally uncomfortable to be there the whole time, which makes any connection with Eddie Brock for the viewer impossible. Thatâ€™s especially a problem since thereâ€™s a romantic subplot,â€¦

I think I prefer my Chaplin in more limited doses. There are portions of City Lights that are right up there with anything that Keaton or Lloyd were doing in this interesting Silent Clown period of cinema. The opening scene with a new public monument being unveiled (remember those? Of course you don't, you're under the age of 100) only to reveal a sleeping Tramp, followed by an overly mannerly extrication is a fantastic start.From then on, it's aâ€¦

Kind of a bummer for Umberto Lenzi to be the one generally credited with starting the cannibal film subgenre, only to find himself near the end of the cannibal boom making a film that's a subpar ripoff of someone else's defining effort. And by that I mean it's a bummer for me personally, as I was expecting better. Shudder runs a special warning for this movie before it starts, which naturally sets expectations sky high. That and Lenzi's transparent effortâ€¦

Stick with this one. Even if what you think you're seeing is a series of dumb decisions by the characters and plot developments that make no sense, keep going until the end. You may not ultimately like Braid's interior logic, but I promise that it exists. Keep going until the end.I fear that Braid is destined to be overlooked, as a first-time director's work released straight to streaming services. This hit Amazon right around the new year, when peopleâ€¦

If I were to become a cinema Hammurabi and start carving edicts into the stone walls of Hollywood, hereâ€™s one of the laws of empire:Thou shalt not make a biopic about a living person.If Dexter Fletcher had been a law abiding subject and adhered to this directive, Rocketman could have been a bog standard biopic that would have made its requisite cash and been a forgettable but not bad film. And for the first ninety minutes, thatâ€™s whatâ€¦

Helpful to consider this one in its native environment. In a vacuum, this is a heavy handed allegory packed with cliched imagery. All of the ridiculous self-seriousness of a student film. Things, of course, do not exist in a vacuum, and in 1947 this was a radical shot across the bow of post-war America.From a historical perspective, one has to respect this film. When you talk about cliched images, itâ€™s quite possible that this was the thing that injectedâ€¦

Oh man. How have I gone this long without seeing a Segundo de ChomÃ³n film? Time to rectify this.De ChomÃ³n draws obvious comparisons to MÃ©liÃ¨s, but unlike an imitator like George Albert King, he stands as a solid contemporary. Like MÃ©liÃ¨s, De ChomÃ³n has an unbounded eye for what cinema can do, and he'll push its technical limitations to match his vision. You can't say that anything in Satan at Play (and God bless him for making something calledâ€¦

Nice of the internet to dig something up out of the early history of cinema, even if it is to recontextualize it in its typically dumb manner.In an era where the effort put into a film really distinguishes it from everything else being put out at that particular time, this is pretty impressive. The puppetry of our friend The Dancing Pig is incredible, and as a prop for this time period it's top notch in the sub-MÃ©liÃ¨s tier ofâ€¦

Very, very difficult to write this one up without a ton of unproven personal assumptions about director Michael Goi. There are a number of red flags that go up when one watches Megan is Missing, however:- The presentation of the film as "educational" by its director and producers is plainly dishonest. This is pure exploitation and the thought of showing this film to a kid is abhorrent. The fact that the bonus materials include a snippet from Marc Klaasâ€¦

movietitle: The Killing of a Chinese Bookie
review: I'm not really sure why John Cassavetes included the killing of the Chinese bookie in The Killing of a Chinese Bookie. The majority of this film is about Cosmo's (Ben Gazzara) attempts to elevate the LA girly show circuit, and the crime parts of it, up to and including Cosmo taking a slug in the guts, are treated like an unwelcome distraction from what's really important: French-themed revues anchored on Mr. Sophistication's (Meade Roberts) half-hearted singing. By the end, it'sâ€¦

Gaspar NoÃ©, you rascal.This is something of a stripped down version of NoÃ©â€™s thing, all of the raw sensory assault without much of the stuff that can make him annoying. His habit of nauseating, unwatchable camerawork is kept to a minimum, and when he finally does indulge it feels connected logically to the narrative. Thereâ€™s still things like his fascination with messing with credits and blaring text in your face, but Climax ends up being an expression of whyâ€¦

This is the most context-dependent thing Iâ€™ve seen in a long time. As a general rule I try to consider the film and not its maker, mostly a mechanism so that I donâ€™t have to morally cleanse everything that I consume and thus starve to death. Impossible here, though. You must have seen the entire three season run of Deadwood in order for this to land the way it should. More than that, this is the last act of Davidâ€¦

Complaining about this film is useless, really. My first impulse is to say that this could have hit a few levels deeper with the familial trauma, but then youâ€™d end up with something that doesnâ€™t have the goofy superpowers angle and suddenly youâ€™re not bothering and youâ€™re just watching We Need to Talk About Kevin instead. Still feels like the Gunns left something on the table though, and Iâ€™m not talking about the Superman nonsense.Itâ€™s all right, I cameâ€¦

movietitle: A Trip Down Market Street Before the Fire
review: More experiments in what exactly we're going to do with this newfangled film medium. Stock footage of stuff remained a popular draw in 1906, so the Miles Brothers churned it out.Primarily interesting as a showcase of the dogged authentication and restoration work of David Kiehn, of the Niles Essanay Silent Film Museum. Secondarily interesting as documentation of pre-earthquake San Francisco and what streets looked like before automobiles dominated traffic.

The first female film director (one of the first film directors in general, it should be said) makes one of the first provocative films.The exaggerated performance of gender in early cinema is neatly reversed, and men are seen to flutter about and simper while women lay around and drink. Women get into punch ups over passively observant men, and then forcibly grope men on park benches while onlookers walk on by in purposeful ignorance. Itâ€™s not exactly subtle, butâ€¦

First known use of the steamroller gag in film. A James Williamson product, something from a filmmaker that was all-in on the "gawrsh moving pictures" school of thought when it came to his artistic output. This, then, is pretty wild from a studio known previously for other hits such as two minutes of a baby being wiped off with a rag.Quite a lot of physical comedy and action in this one, really. The protagonist is followed through several differentâ€¦

Amazed I hadn't heard of this one before recently, it seems like one of those films destined for cult status. So many idiosyncratic aspects. Start with the 15 years it took for this to be completed, making it the Alita: Battle Angel of direct-to-streaming horror. The director is Andrew Getty, of the famous oil tycoon Gettys, who died two years before the official release of what would be his only film. The cast is weirdly accomplished for a production likeâ€¦

Aimed squarely at rubes. In this sense it's the perfect Netflix film. A cheap director, bargain basement script, and C-list actors all keep the budget down. Throw in enough horror elements to get that crowd interested, because horror makes money. Add in a lesbian encounter so that you can lead the socially conscious crowd by the nose, but make sure to show the sex scene for the prurient interest of the less conscious crowd. Don't forget to set part ofâ€¦

Been putting this one off for years. I confess to a certain intellectual laziness in this regard. Natalie Portman has been poisoned in my mind from the Star Wars prequels and V for Vendetta, a film more insulting to its source material than Jar-Jar Binks could have ever been. And I've been annoyed with Darren Aronofsky since The Fountain, a feeling which wasn't alleviated any by Mother. I skipped it when it came out and I hadn't been tempted toâ€¦

First one I've seen from Rachid Bouchareb, and I'm going to have to go deeper into his filmography now. As a film it's a solid take on the immigrant's tale. As a political statement it's suitably provocative. One wonders how much more explosive this film would be in France if Bouchareb had released it this year instead of the relative safety of 2010.Film is plenty versed in the viewpoint of the criminal. I've seen comparisons of Outside the Lawâ€¦

Watch this after you have children if you really want to be grabbed in the guts. This was already one of the more affecting films I had seen when I first viewed it decades ago. After youâ€™ve gone months without a proper nightâ€™s sleep, you begin to truly understand Eraserhead.You may want to wait until your kid is grown up a bit, though. Oneâ€™s mind lives in dark places when youâ€™re raising an infant. Not many like to admitâ€¦

Thereâ€™s an interpretation of The Third Man out there, Iâ€™m sure, as an upjumped potboiler with a whole lot of bells and whistles attached. Iâ€™m not sure thatâ€™s entirely inaccurate. All I can say is that this film haunts my mind the same way that the screaming old lady from Battleship Potemkin must have haunted Francis Bacon.The story is almost incidental to me. Joseph Cotten is fine as a goofball American in over his head, serving as the audienceâ€™sâ€¦

Notes this time around:- The use of close up shots in this film really provides a psychovisual signature.- I donâ€™t believe that art becomes lesser by the existence of other art that attempts a poor imitation of it. That said, I wish the two sequels to this didnâ€™t exist. It would have spared audiences not only those films, but also the realization that Thomas Harris didnâ€™t fully understand his own characters.- While this is a good serialâ€¦

movietitle: The Lonely Island Presents: The Unauthorized Bash Brothers Experience
review: Surreal, goofy fun with an Oakland flavor to it. I especially appreciate the channeling of Jose Cansecoâ€™s soul in order to make this happen.

I donâ€™t understand how an entire cast full of professional comedy writers could have put out a script this terrible. This is a Lifetime television movie with the word â€œfuckâ€ added to it.Thereâ€™s a scene where Jason Schwartzmanâ€™s doofy character asks Amy Poehler if they can have sex, and her extended, dumbfounded stare in response lasts for almost a full minute before she finally relents out of boredom and momentary self-loathing. That was the only time in this entireâ€¦

Baseball is the greatest of American sports. Thatâ€™s one of those things you get or you donâ€™t. And this is the best of the baseball movies, smack dab in the middle of the 1984-1993 golden age of baseball movies. More than any other film, Bull Durham gets the psychological pull of the game, the thing thatâ€™s made it into a national institution even for those who have never watched a game.This is the only baseball film that Iâ€™m awareâ€¦

The year of our Lord 2002 was long enough ago now that the post-millennium unease of those times seems like a faraway, quaint little thing. Our apocalypse porn was more hopeful and optimistic then, even if Danny Boyle thinks he's being hard here. It's even funnier when you consider that Trainspotting remains the more harrowing film.With enough distance to truly consider it outside of its place in introducing the "fast zombies" subgenre, 28 Days Later is a standard contagion/apocalypse/zombiesâ€¦

The late 2010s in horror, The Movie.Lots of elements intersecting here. You've got your A24 family-based horror. Your creepy kid trope. Babadook-esque mother/son tension. Lingering forest-based cinematography. It all makes for something very polished-looking and appropriate for its time and place. It also doesn't leave very much of an impression on me. Competent, but unmoving.The relationship between Sarah (SeÃ¡na Kerslake) and Chris (James Quinn Markey) isn't all that well-defined before the film moves right onto holegrounding the kidâ€¦

I can't help but kick myself for going into this as blind as I did. I knew the general concept, and I knew that the film was adapted from a Liu Cixin story. What I expected, then, was a high-concept sci-fi flick, which are super hit-and-miss but something which I can usually glean some enjoyment of either way. Nope. The film's primary notability is being a top box office draw in PRC, which has given it international juice. This isâ€¦

Funny that this movie about a heist came about because Jack Frawley ripped off The Great Train Robbery in order to capitalize on its success the year prior. Early American cinema is dominated by derivative copies of what was successful before, as well as straight-up piracy of European films, whose creators couldn't run back and forth across the Atlantic fast enough to complain about their copyrights.As such, this is a poor copy of that aforementioned film, and in oneâ€¦

Documentary footage of the operations of a Westinghouse Electric Company factory floor. The first minute or so is genuinely interesting, as the camera has a bird's eye tracking view through a production floor that's assembling generators, a pretty unusual perspective for the time.Things get repetitive after a while. You can only watch ladies wrap wires around a coil for so long. Primarily in existence so that you can walk away thinking to yourself "wow, Westinghouse is really, really big." Take that, Edison.

Fun little cheeseball romp that's elevated by a number of factors. Catherine Mary Stewart and Kelli Maroney are charming as hell as high school sisters navigating their way through a standard issue zombie apocalypse, giving the film its kooky bubble gum sensibility. Both women are having a good time riding motorcycles and taking target practice with Uzis in the streets of a now-roomy Los Angeles, and while there's moments of peril it's nothing so high-stakes that it undermines the essentialâ€¦

Strict paycheck fare for Bela Lugosi and director Joseph H. Lewis. Fans of spectacularly inept police procedure will thrill to a house where several murders have been committed of unconnected people but no one living there has been investigated seriously. Stay for the forensic evidence gathered by people who wander into and out of the house, after the crime scene has been poked and prodded by the help.Monogram Pictures knew what they were doing, and like so many audiencesâ€¦

Harmony Korine, back before his primary motivation became pissing people off.Thereâ€™s a level of sincerity in Gummo thatâ€™s hard to resist. Korineâ€™s stated aim is to portray people without any sort of judgment, and from that viewpoint this film is interesting. Are you able to turn off the part of your mind that recoils at squalor and people that you are conditioned to view as lesser? There is no doubt that at least some of what youâ€™re looking atâ€¦

As long as Chad Stahelski and Keanu Reeves want to keep making these, Iâ€™ll keep seeing them. Though itâ€™s hard to imagine how Stahelski is going to keep topping himself after this one.High points include fighting on horseback through the streets of New York City, the extended fight in the antique weapons collection, John Wick breaking a manâ€™s neck with a book, the Moroccan guest locale they used this time out, Asia Kate Dillon as the Adjudicator, Charon finallyâ€¦

Iâ€™m becoming a big fan of Irish horror. Steve Oram too, who gets a fantastic part in A Dark Song alongside Catherine Walker. Liam Gavin joins the ranks of promising horror rookies with his first feature here, and itâ€™s a solid one.A hard, haunted woman and a drunk, vulgar occultist cut themselves off entirely from the outside world in a country manor for months. Itâ€™s a great setup, and the ability of Walker and Oram to carry these rolesâ€¦

The opening shot of Safety Last is wonderfully perverse. Harold Lloyd is shot somberly through bars with what looks like a noose in the background, sober-faced relatives bidding him farewell. The scene is of course just him leaving a train station to the big city, but itâ€™s such a weird little fake out that has little thematic connection to the rest of affairs. Lloyd just thought it was a funny goof to play on the audience, and itâ€™s such anâ€¦

That mortuary is still one of the more iconic locations in movies. I donâ€™t think I caught what it was the first time I watched Reservoir Dogs, and I think thatâ€™s because thereâ€™s just enough of the buildingâ€™s original purpose left over without being too clumsy with visual cues. The drains, the industrial sink, the leftover containers of fluid. Best of all, the loading dock, Mr. Orange bleeding out on the ramp to Heaven. The action leaves the rendezvous pointâ€¦

Groucho may have had a point with his observation that one can't make a director out of Wood. The Pride of the Yankees commonly shows up on lists of the most inspirational films, the most important baseball films, etc. It ought to be remembered instead as one of the most notable wastes of film talent and resources of the 40s. Anyone with an appreciation for the history of baseball is also ill-served by this huge missed opportunity to immortalize oneâ€¦
Hardly a film as such, as opposed to a record of a kabuki play. From a historical documentation perspective, that's interesting enough, I suppose.

Early cinema is all about sudden leaps forward. The landscape is littered with products created mostly because they'll leave your yokel's mouth agape at the moving images on this here screen, so the person who actually puts effort into their product is going to get noticed. Especially the person who tries something new. Edwin Porter is a purveyor of both kino detritus and new things.Here, you've got something dynamic and ambitious. Twelve minutes of exciting camera movements, on-location shooting,â€¦

It would have been too much to ask for someone to cram Fat Guy Goes Nutzoid together with Hobo with a Shotgun. That's not a fair expectation of anyone, even if such a thing would mean that I could jump into a coffin right afterward, secure in the knowledge that I had seen everything that I needed to.This lives on its own planet somewhere. Clint Gaige, our director, has enough commercial production under his belt that the ultra-low levelâ€¦

I spend a lot of time in the Oakland Coliseum, and I was there for games 17 and 20 of The Streak, so it's difficult to approach this like other films. It's unsettlingly personal. Stretches of very familiar ground are constantly in this like the cranes of the port and the concrete tunnels, but familiar faces have been replaced by the likes of Brad Pitt, Jonah Hill, Chris Pratt and Philip Seymour Hoffman. It's like cinematic Capgras Syndrome.The strangenessâ€¦

You have to expect a certain amount of sappiness from baseball movies. Even so, there are places in Bang the Drum Slowly that will test even the most conditioned of genre hounds. It's not quite a three hanky deal, but not for a lack of effort. Kind of a weird follow-up project for John Hancock, who had just filmed Let's Scare Jessica to Death in 1971.The main story is about how you should be nice to people who areâ€¦

Is this how people who enjoy The Room feel? Blood Feast is so incredibly in its own tier of bad filmmaking that itâ€™s stupefying. Every single choice made here is so wrong and inept that it scrambles the brain. And yet all I can think of is how glorious it must have been to shoot this. I think of Herschell Gordon Lewis gleefully orchestrating this from a dirty little Chicago office, knowing full well that every right thinking individual inâ€¦

Slog through the first thirty minutes or so. The beginning of Strike is pure melodrama and propaganda without much of anything else to cut the artificial flavor. The going is especially tough because of Sergei Eisensteinâ€™s thing where individual characters are tools of the oppressor. The future at one time was apparently stories about lots of faceless people milling around.If you can make it through that, though, the payoff is Eisenstein the artist, the technical master, and yes, theâ€¦

Things like this make Keanu Reeves one of my favorite movie stars. This is a dude that works hard, which you can tell just by his release schedule. He reminds me of an old-school studio property guy, gamely showing up for whatever role youâ€™ve got for him, because an actor should work, by god. And once again, heâ€™s putting in the effort here in part two of the glorious riot that is the John Wick franchise.This is a manâ€¦

Everything you could expect from a stock biopic. Slight variations upon the factory presets include the Meaningful Mid Career Moment at the beginning taking place before Tolkienâ€™s literary career, more room for secondary characters, a decent performance from the Love Interest Muse character, and extra helpings of suffocating Englishness.These kinds of films for whatever reason seem to feature awful performances from their female leads, so it was pleasant to have Lily Collins buck that trend and project some personality.â€¦

As the front end of a loosely considered faith trilogy comprising this, Winter Light, and The Silence, Through a Glass Darkly suffers by comparison. As an aside on that, I'm inclined to take Ingmar Bergman at his more recent word and consider these films not as a trilogy. Instead I take Through a Glass Darkly and Winter Light as the front and back ends of the same conversation, and The Silence as an entirely separate venture. You still have myâ€¦

The idea of the scalability of horror occurred to me as I watched this. In the hands of an able practitioner a film should be scary because the director wills it. But inside its walls, what scares the protagonist? That will change from person to person, situation to situation. So when Roxanne Benjamin tailors the boundaries of this film's fear to that of a green young ranger trainee who's apparently frightened by the mere prospect of being outdoors, I'm intoâ€¦

movietitle: Execution of Czolgosz with Panorama of Auburn Prison
review: Amazing how someone can pack filler into something that's three minutes long. And yet there are multiple occasions where we get just that. The opening panorama, amazingly, has some visual interest in the pleasing way that the train in the foreground introduces some additional motion. Beyond that, the continued footage wasted on the front of a blank, featureless building would have taken quite a lot in the way of nutritional deficiency-induced mental slowness to get into.I was a littleâ€¦

I suspect that what people are responding to in this film is the Platonic ideal of what it could be. There are some really, really good elements to this that could be made into something great, starting with the stately Joan Crawford and going from there. But I was surprised at just how much this felt like Michael Curtiz finishing a project while he happened to be in Malibu as the eighteenth film he'd shot that quarter. Mildred Pierce inâ€¦

I dig what's rattling around in S. Craig Zahler's head. The realm in which he operates is a run-down strip mall VHS rental joint populated mostly by decent people who have adapted to their 70s hypercrime world with resigned cleverness. Zahler's ability to work in a universe not our own, but with consistent rules regardless, brings to mind a grindhouse Wes Anderson.The clear border between the rings of hell in this film is great. The viewer is introduced intoâ€¦

movietitle: Extremely Wicked, Shockingly Evil and Vile
review: The algorithm spits another one out. Too bad. If this had been made with any sort of intent it might have been crummy enough to piss me off, and Iâ€™d rather be pissed off than bored. As it stands, Extremely Wicked Etc. only achieves casual annoyance by portraying almost every woman in the story as a codependent imbecile. But itâ€™s hard to be mad at that because Iâ€™m pretty sure thatâ€™s the result of bad filmmaking rather than intent.Almostâ€¦

What It Follows was to the coming-of-age narrative, Under the Silver Lake is to hitting middle age. And therefore Under the Silver Lake is wrongly evaluated as a film noir story, the same way It Follows was primarily viewed as a horror film (although it's a fantastic horror film). Don't get me wrong; this is definitely a noir tale. But those parts of the film are in service to the larger narrative, not the other way around.If I wereâ€¦

Just ridiculous. A straight dose of nonstop silliness and goofballery from Ernst Lubitsch, and itâ€™s fantastic. Every element just hits.Victor Janson has a remarkable mug and itâ€™s used to great effect, an impenetrable gargoyle mask thatâ€™s a great counterweight to Ossi Oswaldaâ€™s maniacal whims of destruction. Julius Falkenstein is hilarious as a good-natured freeloading oaf, and his comedic energy with Harry Liedtke is top notch. The scene where the two men hastily transform their decrepit flat into a throneâ€¦

We're way, waaaay too late into cinema's development to be able to have pictures of pretty people carry a movie all on their own. And that's all Wolf Song really has going for it. Gary Cooper is a young man inexplicably hanging out in the woods with a couple of old character actor fur trappers, and his primary function is to look dashing and wash up in the lake. Lupe VÃ©lez is a beautiful Mexican scion in Taos who likesâ€¦

Careful with this one. If you hit it in the wrong mood it's going to come across as saccharine and by-the-numbers, especially given the close resemblance to 8 Mile. There's a lot of struggling against impossible odds and talk about how you should follow your dreams and other such things that can numb the senses. The script is the weakest part of the film and threatens to hold it back, though I can't tell if part of that is theâ€¦

Take away the explanatory text at the beginning and the end, smooth out some of the jumpier moments of editing, and ease up on the uncharacteristic hamfistedness of the Thomas Wentworth Higginson scene, and youâ€™ve got something close to a masterpiece. I donâ€™t care to lead with mistakes for this film but when a director is as locked in as Madeleine Olnek is here, the mistakes help to remind you how good the rest of it is.Hereâ€™s confidence ofâ€¦

Love of horror doesn't always translate to a good product. Witness Rob Zombie's ongoing affronts against the genre. You can tell, though, when someone loves what they're doing, and it helps add some extra zip on the final product. Jen and Sylvia Soska clearly love what they're doing, and it shows here.Just a good, cleanly done horror film that makes a solid addition to the revenge and body horror subgenres. Katharine Isabelle gets a chance to shine here, andâ€¦

The Kermit the Forg costume was a bridge too far. David Lynch is on such a different plane than everyone else that attempts at imitation donâ€™t even look bad in comparison, so the knock-off BOB and the too-close-to-the-sun sound design and the screams and the woods are all forgivable. Itâ€™s when Calvin Reeder decides to splice immaturity into this film that it becomes obnoxious. He would have done well to more closely study Uncle Lynchâ€™s ability to process sexual violenceâ€¦

This is filmed entirely through the lens of how your brain functions when you're too horny to think clearly. That's the only thing I can think of that ties together everything in this film. There's some flailing jabs at Marxism, some commentary on the commodification of sex I guess, and some really clumsily handled stuff to say about childhood sexuality. That last point is probably what got this film banned in a ton of places, although it's a horse raceâ€¦

Thus concludes Phase III. A certain amount of dread comes over me as I type that. How many Phases will we go through? I've enjoyed this decade of films that's given us an entirely new genre, but is this the future? The thought of being back here in 2029 after another 25 films culminating in Avengers: So Very Tired fills me with a sort of existential dread. The financial outlook on these films is so perfected that I worry theâ€¦

This is my first experience with Nollywood, so Iâ€™m finding my legs a bit here. The Figurine, which sports a surprisingly detailed Wikipedia article, supposedly marks a transition in Nigerian cinema away from direct-to-video melodrama and into more traditional Â larger-scale productions meant for the big screen. Thereâ€™s some work to do yet.This is pitched as a supernatural horror film, but itâ€™s best to adjust your expectations because 90% of it has to do with middle class anxiety. Itâ€™s aâ€¦

Being the next in the trilogy, The Beyond feels like something a little more lightweight in comparison to City of the Living Dead. That one had a certain atmosphere to it that was absorbing and helped its disparate parts to come together. The Beyond feels a little more scattered, a little slower, and not quite as apeshit.Not that itâ€™s without its charm. Lucio Fulci can be counted on to bring what youâ€™re looking for, which in this case isâ€¦

movietitle: A Matter of Life and Death
review: Something that struck me recently was the first point in the informal Archers Manifesto:"We owe allegiance to nobody except the financial interests which provide our money; and, to them, the sole responsibility of ensuring them a profit, not a loss."This seemed initially more like something that would be scrawled inside Zack Snyder's tomb than an auteur's imperative. Maybe it's because I'm decades removed from The Archers having to worry about keeping the lights on while funding their nextâ€¦

If you were to take the measure of an artistic work by how far above its contemporaries it is, A Trip to the Moon is the best film in the history of the medium. And it's not even close.Don't watch this unless you lead up to it with at least a few prominent films prior to 1902. Context is crucial for fully understanding just how much this changes the game when it's released in the fall of that year.â€¦

The role of Monte (Robert Pattinson) was apparently written at the start for Philip Seymour Hoffman, and then was offered to Vincent Gallo. What does it say about your film when the lead character could be played by Robert Pattinson, Philip Seymour Hoffman, or Vincent Gallo?High Life feels like a real emperor with no clothes moment. Starting with the A24 logo and Claire Denis' name attached to it, this is blasting you in the face with Prestige(tm), the kindâ€¦

Feels quite a lot like a supernatural version of Memories of Murder. There's a rural town under threat, a generally incompetent local police force that ultimately proves useless, the same grisly murder scenes repeated over and over, plot misdirections, shamans, and Kwak Do-won even does something of a Song Kang-ho impression during the straighter parts of the film. If you're going to take an existing film as a template, you could certainly do a lot worse. And Na Hong-jin hasâ€¦

Depictions of love work best when the writer isnâ€™t buying into any high-minded or idealized versions of it. Relationships are made of people and people are, of course, each their own unique and maddening things. Max OphÃ¼lsâ€™ adaptation of the 1897 Arthur Schnitzler play keeps this truth at heart and is all the better for it.La Ronde is a thoroughly charming film that doesnâ€™t have any illusions about fucking (â€œfuckingâ€ and â€œloveâ€ being far less compartmentalized in non-American climes),â€¦

There have been more perfected expressions of David Cronenbergâ€™s fascination with flesh, sure. Hard to say that any have been quite as much fun, however.Most of that spirit of demented amusement is courtesy of Jeff Goldblum, who even at this early stage had an impeccable sense of comic timing and a weird charisma of a proto-Nic Cage variety. And as a bonus, heâ€™s weird-looking enough to serve as the chassis for the monstrous human/fly hybrid that he transforms intoâ€¦

movietitle: Experiments in the Revival of Organisms
review: In terms of psychological cross-programming this is an absolute masterpiece. If I were making a horror film, and I were feeling in a Kubrickian mood, I would screen this repeatedly for my actors before shooting each day. The sense that something is not right at all but itâ€™s going to continue anyway, thereâ€™s a foundation to build terror upon.There are so many elements that are unsettlingly wrong with this that itâ€™s like aliens made it. Who is the audienceâ€¦

I have mixed feelings about art that leaves copious space. The right spot for a more passive vision is somewhere in between the oversteeped cup of tea and the flavorless leaves. Assuming you like tea.Pickpocket gives a clear idea of Robert Bresson the technical master. Iâ€™d argue that French cinema has the most conscious eye for film as a medium, and in that sense Bresson is rightfully accorded his place at the head of the table. Narrative as expressedâ€¦

movietitle: The Haunting of the Suicide House
review: Almost unwatchable. Looking at bad acting is like listening to bad poetry and there is not a single moment of this film that does not feature bad acting.I had assumed that a group of film students had decided to upload their final project to Amazon, and I was still annoyed at the sheer laziness and lack of imagination. Turns out, however, that the three directors it took to crank out this painfully stupid found footage exercise all have multipleâ€¦

One of the really neat things about cinema is the ability to tweak the brainwaves using imagery. There's a level of storytelling that can take place in a film and not in, say, print, where you can flash pictures at someone and it does stuff to the mind that neither director nor viewer have full control over. With imagery you can elicit reactions from people on a weird, reptile level, quite beyond their control. It's an interesting space to playâ€¦

A frustrating experience. The 1989 version of Pet Sematary is one of the rare films that could benefit from a remake. I didn't get the impression back then, watching Dale Midkiff wrestle around with a prop zombie toddler and looking at Denise Crosby imitate a Duran Duran album cover, that this was the best they could do. Like Suspiria, this seemed like a prime opportunity to turn a beloved genre classic into something transcendent.Instead, this became something that theyâ€¦

Oh man am I pissed. And you're gonna hear about it.PSA: If you search for the 2007 Alexandre Bustillo version of Inside (you know, the one people actually want to see), Amazon Prime will tell you that you can watch it on Hulu. The information listed will be that for the 2007 version, as will the Hulu title screen, which appears briefly before the movie starts. What you are getting is NOT the 2007 version. What you are actuallyâ€¦

Itâ€™s impressive, really, that itâ€™s taken Donald Glover this long to do something like this. Heâ€™s been putting out nonstop brilliance with Atlanta on television, after having established a successful career on the screen before that. Heâ€™s a fantastic musician into the bargain, adeptly riding the swirling currents of the modern hip hop scene. Dudeâ€™s fantastic on all fronts. So it was only a matter of time, to be fair, to make something as self-indulgent as Guava Island.The wholeâ€¦

The amount of goodwill that Ingmar Bergman assumes you have for his product here, especially in the earlier going of 1963, is pretty ballsy. The opening is slow going, as the viewer gets to sit through an entire communion sequence with minimal distraction. After the point is made that the service is sparsely-attended and mostly old people, the scene keeps going, and going. I figured, and contemporary audiences must have as well, that this is a Bergman film and thereforeâ€¦

Could have very easily been stupid and grating with the pseudophilosophy and psychobabble. Fortunately, those elements of the film seem to be there merely as an excuse to mess with Dave Stimple (Adam Edwards), who serves as a surprisingly good straight man for all of the exceedingly silly and sometimes horrifying action around him. Everyone on this production is a first time film participant, but Edwards and Joseph Graham (playing a deranged beardo with glee) are not bad at allâ€¦

Satisfyingly dirty little piece of 70s exploitation. For a while I was somewhat disappointed by the lack of follow-through on the no-nonsense cold open, consisting of Victor Clare (Mike Raven) spreading goo on a naked woman and then pouring molten bronze all over her after itâ€™s hardened into a mold. But the rest of the film has a weird, Wicker Man vibe to it thatâ€™s its own form of charm.For as lurid as the opening violence is, the middleâ€¦

I don't know what exactly it is that makes Paris the best city in cinema. Maybe it's the constant sense of motion as characters forever weave their way through sub-lethal speeds of traffic and crowded sidewalks. Could be the laconic spirit that infuses its denizens to the point that everyone is just cooler for hanging out there. Part of it might be the way that the tasteful Old World architecture framing the Seine makes it seem appropriate to lazily philosophizeâ€¦

Black auteurs have provided quite the home for top tier cinematographers recently. Following the tandem of Barry Jenkins and James Laxton, and the sun-drenched horrorscapes of Jordan Peele productions, Rashid Johnson deploys Aronofsky conspirator Matthew Libatique. Native Sonâ€™s visual signature is the most distinctive thing about it, worn inner city concrete lit by the bright colors of shop signs and graffiti. Cleveland stands in for Chicago, and really more things ought to be filmed in Cleveland. Thereâ€™s a place withâ€¦

Unicorn Store is the Bataan Death March of whimsy. Way beyond forced, this film is a grim slog through tired landscapes while Brie Larson occasionally jabs you in the kidney with a bayonet to make you keep going. I went in knowing full well that I am not the target audience for this (though who is, I wonder), and it still felt aggressively bad.Larson's first attempt at directing a feature is at least a show of some degree ofâ€¦
Harmony Korine fully embracing his poseur twat nature. A complete waste of time.

movietitle: SalÃ², or the 120 Days of Sodom
review: The capacity to be surprised at the acts committed by those in power over those below them is endless. Every time a news story comes out about an entertainer, or a politician, or a church, or a corporation, or any powerful entity engaging in acts of sexual victimization (the prurient nature of these stories being what makes them newsworthy), everyone's shocked. We like to continually forget that one of the first impulses of power is to debase and defile theâ€¦

movietitle: Austin Powers: International Man of Mystery
review: Iâ€™m glad that weâ€™ve mostly gotten over Mike Myers. Or at least that heâ€™s not as omnipresent as he was for that roughly fifteen year stretch. Looking back on this film reminds me of how annoying he can be in large doses.Parts of this have held up well enough. The sheer goofiness of the Doctor Evil scenes still makes me laugh, and Robert Wagner makes a good comic foil in the midst of the zaniness. Seth Greenâ€™s also funny,â€¦

The horror anthology has a special place in my bastardâ€™s heart, dating back to Creepshow. The genre lends itself to little bite sized portions of good old fashioned scares without messing around too much with extended, unnecessary window dressing. The need for a unifying narrative, though, especially in a case like this where it was whatever shorts the producers could find, Iâ€™m less enamored with. Patient Seven certainly has one of the dumbest attempts at such.Danny Draven really doesâ€¦

George Albert Smith finally embraces a sense of production values, a good half decade after other, better purveyors of early shorts did so. The Dickensian backdrop and the snow serve to set a imaginative scene and actually convey something resembling feeling. This is where it feels more like Smith is contributing to the development of cinema, rather than riding on coattails.

Quantum filmmaking. This is both groundbreaking as well as fucking terrible. Harmony Korine does stuff here that you just aren't going to see elsewhere in American cinema. I'm just not sure why he had to do it in such an obnoxious, sneering way. In this manner Flicker (Zac Efron, because of course it's Zac Efron) is the film's true spirit animal, not Moondog (Matthew McConaughey). An obnoxious, baseline malicious asshole stripped of all of the ersatz genius surrounding Moondog, blastingâ€¦

The more I watch George Albert Smith's work, the more impressed I am with just how revolutionary Georges MÃ©liÃ¨s was to film. The two men apparently corresponded, being in the same general line of work of public spectacle on opposing sides of the English Channel. Smith, like many good showmen being something of a con artist, repurposes MÃ©liÃ¨s' jump cut technique into something flimsier and cheaper, complete with a hastily-assembled box labeled "X RAYS" on the side. Smith really oughtâ€¦

When you look at a title and without researching it you can think of at least three iconic moments or scenes that have leaked into your consciousness without having seen the film, what youâ€™ve got on your hands is a gaping hole in your cinematic knowledge. This one has felt like a missing tooth for some time, and my set of teeth feels more complete now.Park Chan-wook rides Choi Min-sik like some sort of rented, unidentifiable beast of burdenâ€¦

Tired. The most prevalent feeling I get from this is an overwhelming sense of weariness, and even if the camerawork is jumpy throughout, John Lee Hancock plods along here. Maybe it's because the outcome is a completely foregone conclusion, and we're all familiar with the way Bonnie and Clyde's journey came to an end. And maybe it's because the film's main conflict isn't between the un-retired Rangers and the criminals, but between competing government agencies. I swear I could seeâ€¦
Neat little example of proto-animation and early editing trickery.

This gets credited with being the film to introduce the concept of editing to cinema. And while George Albert Smith should get his due in helping to pioneer the medium, it's really hard to believe that the rudimentary form of editing present here wouldn't have arisen independently in like fifteen other places.Purely a technical legacy piece, dwarfed by the output of people like Georges MÃ©liÃ¨s who were working at the same time.

Itâ€™s a brave filmmaker that makes a serial killer picture where the killer never shows up. That might be underselling this filmâ€™s importance in the increasingly influential South Korean cinema scene, but itâ€™s a good indicator of how confident Bong Joon-ho is in his abilities in just his second feature.The true brutality of this film is outside of its kills, which for the most part are not shown in real time, instead taking up residence in the utter hopelessnessâ€¦

I haven't seen the original Chilean version of this film, but I can't imagine that SebastiÃ¡n Lelio did it any favors by giving it an American palette swap. The good intentions drip from every second of this film like venom, and instead of eliciting much in an audience this becomes one of those inexplicable occasions where a parade of stars cosplay Regular People. It's not the worst example of that specific brand of cringe, but it's still hard to watchâ€¦

Pleasingly apeshit. I donâ€™t think Iâ€™ve ever seen so many men punching snakes, or throwing snakes, or tying snakes into knots, or fighting snake-men, in one place. Add to that copious cartoon magic powers and three different guys in Halloween devil costumes and youâ€™re equipped with more than enough camp to make it through this film. This is my first journey into 80s Phillippines cinema and I may need to journey further after this.Efren C. PiÃ±on doesnâ€™t provide muchâ€¦

I'm not always in the mood for hobo alley rotgut. When I am, though, it's because I want that precise, cheaply formulated flavor of artificial barrel aging, burning on the way down like a shot of kerosene. When I want it, I want it, and it's annoying when you get an ass pocket bottle of off-label whiskey that tries to hide its nature behind water. Let me taste that shit.This is most certainly the full-flavor rotgut of cinema. Theâ€¦

God, what an oppressive film. Two people in a failing relationship have a way of sucking the life out of a room, and itâ€™s an experience that Asghar Farhadi faithfully replicates for the viewer. An accurate artistic vision, surely. It makes for something of a slog, though.The story isnâ€™t so much the tragedy of something being lost as it is the tail end of a death march. Any joy that may have existed between Simin (Leila Hatami) and Naderâ€¦

For any with lingering doubts, Jordan Peele should be taken seriously as one of the better filmmakers in cinema today. If Get Out was proof of concept, Us is the continuation of development on several fronts. Us is another step forward for horror as a genre that is every bit as valuable as any other for artistic expression, and once again Peele puts some weight in his narrative punches as he goes to work on aspects of American society. Usâ€¦

The only redeeming feature about this was finding out how much of an idiot Kristy Swanson is, after doing some cursory research to find out what caused whatever dire straits that forced her to be in this shitheap.Don't be fooled by the enticing video nasty cover, as this does not at all deliver on the promise of lurid exploitation. Erin Berry, whose most notable contribution to cinema has been producing Ice Road Truckers, delivers ninety minutes of abysmal acting,â€¦

Itâ€™s been a while since a film made me want to move my ass and make a concerted effort to visit some place. The Mongolia presented in Khadak is a dream. Sweeping, impossible steppes that engulf its characters and look like they could swallow you up at any moment. Soviet New International buildings dot the cities like salt crystals congealing on the surface of a plane that looks infinite. Giant machines that match the size of those Soviet outposts tearâ€¦

Because of this film, I've instituted a new policy. I no longer even casually glance at Amazon's synopsis for films, because the way in which the copy for this was written suggested through poor punctuation that Bitty (Hilary Swank) and Nicky (Michael Shannon) were dealing with the end of a lifelong incestuous relationship. So throughout the first half of the movie, certain scenes took on an entirely different subtext for me as I kept waiting for that plot bomb toâ€¦

A comparison of Triple Frontier to Ocean's Eleven would be pretty unfair, given the wildly different moods of the two films. But like that film, Triple Frontier is a good use of a solid and noteworthy cast to push a film into "worthwhile watch" territory.Give casting director Katie Doyle a lot of credit for coming up with this roster after everyone else in Hollywood was attached to this film and then backed out. A list of actors that includesâ€¦

Dario Argento has a strange way of making films where his actors are almost incidental. Almost every aspect of Suspiria is wild, taking a turn at the forefront of the viewer's consciousness. From the start, the Goblin score does a ton of heavy lifting to set the strange mood, a fact that seeing this in a theater made readily apparent. The set design is incredible, from the site of the film's initial kill to the weird pastel gothic sensibility ofâ€¦

movietitle: The Boy Who Harnessed the Wind
review: Behold the latest exercise in the neo-mondo genre. Distinguishable from their grimy ancestors by high grade cinematography and Hallmark humanism, these films have adapted at the cellular level to the defenses of the enlightened 21st century mind and bypass that feeling of revulsion while still hitting that same mental sweet spot. That part of the Western mind that dumps endorphins into the bloodstream at the sight of people who are for sure worse off than you are, less civilized butâ€¦

Thereâ€™s a lot working against T2 Trainspotting that isnâ€™t necessarily its fault, though the initial choice to make it could be counted against Danny Boyle. Mostly itâ€™s the fact that any sort of continuation to the story after Renton walks away with the payday feels wrong. The ending of Trainspotting is one of the better finishes in film; the characters are old enough to start medicating themselves as their fate becomes apparent, but young enough to still have exuberance andâ€¦

Elia Kazan steps heavy. The viewer is given dense, meaningful elements to consider like stones continually layered onto the mind. Familial betrayal. The doomed presence of James Dean. The entrapment of women into an existence designed to grind them to dust. The Great War. Man's flaws illuminating the eternal shadow play of Cain and Abel. Like Giles Corey, I say more weight.This film is a masterclass. This is one of the stronger casts in 1950s cinema, which is notâ€¦

The first director's credit for Erich von Stroheim, and it's already got his slightly-unhinged little fingerprints all over it. Stroheim seems like he was just born for Hollywood, and you can tell he loves being in front of the camera. He mugs around here as an absurd little Austrian lieutenant groping his way through an Alpine tourist villa, the sheer goofiness of his pickup artist act helping it to feel more humorous than grotesque. Stroheim is adept at portraying charactersâ€¦

Noomi Rapace almost has enough action movie presence to carry a shitty production by herself. Almost.The only redeeming features of this film are its fight scenes, and Rapace is one of the select group of female actors working today with enough physicality to convincingly sell brawling violence. Close reaches its apex with a nice extended sequence in which a handcuffed Sam Carlson (Rapace) tangles with a henchman in an increasingly brutal encounter. The level of nastiness in that fightâ€¦

The pitfalls of being queer for found footage. The barriers to entry for films like this are extremely low, and so you end up with things like Char Man stealing your life away an hour and a half at a time.Kurt Ela and Kipp Tribble conspire to clog up the genre as directors and leads in a strictly formula exercise. Nothing at all happens for the first hour except for goofing around and a couple of acting moments thatâ€¦

If nothing else, The General gave me an excuse to go do some research on how it was filmed, which I would advise anyone to do. Buster Keaton was a complete fucking madman bent on making the craziest films possible. He's like some sort of avatar for the Vaudevillian impulse to destroy oneself in the service of entertainment, and fortunately for us his most insane work was committed to film. Even more fortunately for us the footage wasn't all burnedâ€¦

A little nunsploitation for the modern era. This drew me since that seems like a genre that could be very interesting with some revised sensibilities, but it wasnâ€™t to be.I expected more out of Darren Lynn Bousman. Not even on the level of expecting something creative like Repo the Genetic Opera, but I was at least hoping that he could deliver Saw-level visceral horror. St. Agatha doesnâ€™t really do much of anything, though. It doesnâ€™t fully commit to theâ€¦

Brie Larson immediately becomes one of the more charismatic leads of the MCU as we do this for the twenty-first time. Itâ€™s a little hard to buy her at times as a world-crushing badass, but she brings enough charm and moxie to the role that her debut Marvel feature is an above-average one.The most noteworthy aspect to Captain Marvel is the amount of chemistry between Nick Fury (Samuel L. Jackson) and Carol. Not only because of the seemingly unlikelyâ€¦

America didnâ€™t invent the art of the con, nor is it unique for enshrining it as part of the culture. What makes The Sting such a quintessentially American story is how it reflects our relationship with grifting. Weâ€™ve sublimated it here into the national consciousness in a way that it appears in the mythology we tell about ourselves, never really openly celebrating it but always with an admiring eye for the criminal. The American Dream is conning your way toâ€¦

Reminiscent of silent film in the sense that weâ€™re presented with raw imagery intended to convey emotional resonance through visual cues. Or something.The imagery is that of suburban alienation, a theme that might have found more traction in the closing days of the 1990s but feels laughable as a source of distress in the present. Tract home, tasteful interior, apparent psychotic break. That might be putting too much â€œstoryâ€ into a sensory experience but thatâ€™s what the brain wantsâ€¦

A solid, competently executed genre piece. Generally speaking, there's nothing here that hasn't been done before, but it should scratch that "flesh monsters terrorize a trapped group of survivors" itch that one occasionally gets. The film did remind me quite a bit of the hospital segment in Southbound, and both plumb a very specific creepy mood generated by deserted medical facilities.The film is distinguishable around the margins. Little choices that Steven Kostanski and Jeremy Gillespie make give this somethingâ€¦

Loneliness. Not so bad, eh?Beware a middle aged man looking to reboot the family experiment. He's either fucked it up before or he doesn't know what he's doing, and in the case of Aoyama (Ryo Ishibashi) it's the latter. As a person that's been on his own and forgotten how to share relationship space Aoyama enters the prospect of remarriage blindly and without a whole lot of thought. And as a relic of an increasingly obsolete social structure hisâ€¦

Welcome to fuckin' Deadwood.This film proved to be an amusing interlude while waiting for HBO's forthcoming Deadwood movie to drop, presenting a far cleaner and less erudite vision of the infamous Black Hills gold rush settlement. It's easy to forget how silly these production Westerns of the 40s and 50s were, before the genre really came into its lawless own. Alfred E. Green, a reliable studio content machine, packs an entire roster of goofball character actors into his productionâ€¦

Fascinating how a film from 1932, before the horrors of the Hays Code, can have a much healthier depiction of a prostitute than films today. Even with all the baggage of marriage-as-blessed-servitude and the sanitized presentation of the flesh trade, Edward Buzzell is content to let Carole Lombard portray an actual human without any of the Madonna/whore nonsense. Whether thatâ€™s some sort of recognition of humanity or just a wise business decision to let Lombard off the chain to beâ€¦

This is where things start to get good.The relationship of dreams to cinema is a naturally existing one, maybe the most natural of any art form. Others have tread that ground far more artfully so I'll content myself with enjoying this early consecration of that bond. The techniques may be rudimentary but the psychological understanding of dream imagery is not, and Georges MÃ©liÃ¨s, as a natural master of the narrative form, deploys the tools he has to convey theâ€¦

A neat little trinket from the father of special effects. The mix of traditional illusionary showmanship along with the clever editing techniques is indicative of what makes Georges MÃ©liÃ¨s a visionary figure. Film is a tool in the advancement of storytelling, rather than an end in itself, a lesson that was lost on purveyors of shorts for more than a decade after this.

Only Isabelle Huppert seems to have been let in on the secret that this is a trash femsploitation movie. Maybe that knowledge was on a need-to-know basis, since Ms. Huppert was the one who had to do all the goofy shit in the movie, up to and including staring for hours into a window while looming like a sensibly European Pennywise. For as terrifying as the premise could have been, Neil Jordan instead steers this film between the Scylla ofâ€¦

Allegory is a harsh spirit. Most of the time it burns all the way down like a swig from a plastic bottle of vodka, and you can see why places like the Soviet Union had a bit more of a taste for it. Stalker is far from the bottom shelf when it comes to allegorical narrative, but it still fights back as you take it in, and I had to struggle at times to keep it down as I keptâ€¦

movietitle: Alien Abduction: Incident in Lake County
review: Little gem at the crossroads of the proto-found footage genre and 1990s alien conspiracy paranoia. This is very, very much a product of its time and place, and if you can transport your brain to the late night UPN landscape of 1998, populated by shitty tabloid fodder and halfhearted attempts at various forms of exploitation, youâ€™ll be in the proper headspace.As always, thereâ€™s some stuff that an audience just has to accept with the found footage thing. The cameramanâ€¦

movietitle: Love Letters of a Portuguese Nun
review: I'd been meaning to cure my ignorance of JesÃºs Franco's vast catalogue. He always struck me as a more lurid version of Roger Corman. Right up my depraved alley. After this one, though, I'm not feeling much gumption to delve deeper into his hundreds of films.If you're pumping out dozens of productions a year, it leaves you little time to really do much with any one of them. Or at least that's what I'm assuming is the excuse forâ€¦

Are we just teleporting Liam Neeson into things now with the tacit understanding that heâ€™s going to turn into an unstoppable force of vengeance? Look man, I donâ€™t need a whole lot of reasoning behind a series of revenge killings. But we go here from the guy getting an award for plowing a single road for decades on end, to beating a succession of drug dealers to death.Thatâ€™s really the problem here. This script would have been wonderful hadâ€¦

There's some really odd parallels with Sideways in this film. In a way it feels like the Solvang Chamber of Commerce wanted a revisionist take on their town and called up Alexandre Lehmann to help exorcise the humorously loathsome spirits from their quaint touristy streets. I'm not sure it worked, since you still had two damaged men wandering the town and engaging in low-grade shenanigans, and while Sideways kind of embraced the depravity of its leads, Paddleton has a muchâ€¦

There's quite a bit of interest here if you're watching early film with an eye for the bits that signal or presage how cinema will develop in later years. The first point of interest being the writer, director, and star Lois Weber, who's never received her proper recognition as a foundational figure in film.The film is notable for its early use of the split-screen effect, which is definitely of visual interest since it's three perspectives slashed through with triangularâ€¦

Gaspar Noe is name-checked in the special thanks portion of the credits. A nice bit of etiquette after Emiliano Rocha Minter blew his fucking doors off in his first full-length film. And thatâ€™s no disrespect to Mr. Noe, an experienced hand at this point in transgressive cinema. But Mr. Minter went further and harder down the path thatâ€™s been laid down.The dilapidated madhouse of the filmâ€™s setting is a suitable reflection of the inside of a personâ€™s skull.NoÃ©â€¦

A very solid entry in the Lucio Fulci portfolio. The easy knock on City of the Living Dead is the story and dialogue, which don't even really make an effort to acquit themselves. The disjointed narrative and the way that even basic everyday interactions don't work as they should in this film just add to its sense of unreality and strangeness. I can't imagine that's necessarily on purpose, but stuff like the world's laziest gravediggers, the open-house psychoanalysis session, aâ€¦

Part of the fault is mine. This filmâ€™s native environment is the grimy two-screen theater of a sadly bygone era, or as a VHS feature with a good crowd of people and plenty of liquor and/or grass. Viewed in these places I could see this being a good time. As it is, I wavered between boredom and confusion as I watched on my own.As a low-budget action feature of the early 80s, the boxes are all checked off. Fucktonsâ€¦

David Fincher really called in every favor here. Possibly the ensembliest cast assembled in the pre-MCU era, which manages to give significant screen time to Jake Gyllenhaal, Robert Downey Jr. and Mark Ruffalo, but also makes time for some cherished workhorses like Brian Cox, Elias Koteas and Donal Logue. And ChloÃ« Sevigny is always a welcome sight.I avoided watching this film for years because it was impossible to imagine it standing in the same company as the leading lightsâ€¦

Thereâ€™s a tendency to dismiss criticism of shitty films because theyâ€™re supposed to be â€œfun.â€ What that impulse always misses is that fun, just like any other emotional response a movie is going for, isnâ€™t easy to achieve. It takes thoughtfulness and craft. John Wick is what fun looks like when itâ€™s done well.Keanu Reeves has that quality that Arnold Schwarzenegger had in his heyday. Heâ€™s got the ability to portray someone who is both relateable enough to theâ€¦

You're not necessarily looking for skullduggery and commentary on political corruption when you put on a Shaw Brothers film, and the amount of time that Chang Cheh spends on both these things can drag a bit. The narrative choice does let you see, though, why the Venom Mob was a successful outfit for so many years in the genre. The two lead Venoms, Kuo Chi and Sun Chien, both have quite a bit of charisma and stage presence, especially Mr.â€¦

I wrote my local Congressman today, asking that they make it illegal for streaming services to write inaccurate summaries. I was aware of a) the indie-darling buzz around this film, and b) the description on Amazon Prime declaring this a "hilarious, heartwarming" venture. Justice will be served when the Prime programming war criminals are clapped in chains and gibbeted in front of an old set of Blockbuster Video ruins.This was neither hilarious nor heartwarming. In fairness to the soon-to-be-gibbetedâ€¦

You couldn't make a film like this today. Not because you couldn't find talented actors, though Gregory Peck cuts a figure in one of cinema's greatest roles that no one is ever going to quite measure up to. And not because you couldn't find a director as suitably plainspoken as Robert Mulligan, though he was ideally suited for the job here. You just can't replicate the conditions in which this was born. The film comes from a time when ourâ€¦

As the founder of the eponymous mondo genre, the historical import of Mondo Cane is well-documented. Unpacking why it is this particular film launched a thousand grotesque ships is another matter. It's tempting to write this off as a collection of mashed up imagery organized loosely along shock and titillation, especially given that this is the product of three directors (Paolo Cavara, Franco Prosperi and Gualtiero Jacopetti). But more so than the obvious cues of animal cruelty and bouncing tits,â€¦

If you absolutely have to make a biopic, this is certainly a better way to do it than most. The enterprise seems to be more successful when a filmmaker picks a singular event or a smaller stretch of time to focus on, rather than condensing someoneâ€™s life into two hours. So, thank Christ, weâ€™re spared the rise from obscurity of Laurel and Hardy and the subsequent rise-fall-redemption-enshrinement arc thatâ€™s become mandatory in cinematic hagiography.Jon S. Baird clearly has aâ€¦

Hrrrrrrrm. â€œI donâ€™t know what I was expecting.â€ Thatâ€™s probably the best way to encapsulate how I feel about this one.Kevin Smith makes bad movies. Thatâ€™s just a given at this point. I get that some people enjoy them and I wouldnâ€™t crack on anyone for willingly watching any of his stuff (I just did, after all), but itâ€™s hard to really say much more than â€œwhelp, thatâ€™s what I getâ€ after sitting through one of his features.Iâ€¦

This is one of the more interesting casts Iâ€™ve seen for a horror picture. Tom Noonan and Mary Woronov are pretty heavy hitters in the realm of weird cinema, which makes it a shame that theyâ€™re absent for most of the film. And then thereâ€™s Greta Gerwig, deployed to great effect to create the first shocking moment in the film. The stars are a little less heralded, however; Jocelin Donahue and the house in the woods.Thereâ€™s so much layeredâ€¦

Stanley Kubrick by some reports discouraged people from seeing Fear and Desire in his later years, evidently somewhat embarrassed by his first film. He certainly shouldnâ€™t have felt any shame, and the film is a solid effort from a kid in his twenties on his first directing gig. But watching Fear and Desire is what I would imagine to be for Mr. Kubrick an uncomfortably intimate look into his developing mind. The dramatic lineage of war in his works beginsâ€¦

Diego GarcÃ­a really ought to have received a co-director credit for his work here. Cemetery of Splendor rides its cinematographer so hard Iâ€™m surprised he survived to work on Wildlife. For almost the entire film, the succession of long, meditative shots slowly meander by in a somnambulant manner, occasionally interrupted by dialogue or characters.I get that the photography is a big part of the draw. But thereâ€™s a dissonance to the unrelenting nature of shot after shot of everyâ€¦

Without knowing any of the history that went into this film, you might think that Alita: Battle Angel is merely a mediocre CGI pile. With the benefit of insight into the almost two decade long path this film took to release and its stewardship by one of filmâ€™s most accomplished technical pioneers, though, one is blessed with the knowledge of just how disappointed they should be. Sometimes I fucking hate knowledge.The usual way large budget filmmakers escape the sinâ€¦

Baskin started in its first iteration as a short film, and thereâ€™s an argument that it should have remained as such. The first hour of the film is excruciatingly slow, and doesnâ€™t really use that time except to really establish that everything is going to be shot in darkness. The only character that gets fleshed out is Yavuz (Muharrem Bayrak), primarily through a story about a surprise penis encounter. There are some inspired bits of foreshadowing, employing shots of grilledâ€¦

Perhaps my greatest fear is that I'll be tricked into wasting two hours of my life watching a Juggalo murder cosplay, and that kept me from watching this one when it hit the streaming services. Fortunately, that fear was unfounded. This time.This is quite the achievement for Damien Leone, who wrote, directed, edited, and did the special effects, which were noteworthy here. There's a fine line between summoning the spirit of the beloved 80s slasher film and looting itsâ€¦

You have to wonder how different the United States would look if D.W. Griffith hadn't been born in Kentucky to a former Confederate officer. Something to chew on later.The early years of cinema tend to be a battleground where artists fight against the limitations of the medium, and even here one begins to see Mr. Griffith's caviar production tastes starting to emerge. The battle scenes are fairly complex and large for a sixteen minute feature, and it's sort ofâ€¦

movietitle: Night Is Short, Walk On Girl
review: If the predominant coming of age story is a child taking the first steps toward adulthood, Night is Short, Walk on Girl is a fitting refinement. The story of a young adult taking their first steps toward joining larger society. That's a tale that's getting bleaker and bleaker as we ride the shopping cart down the arc of history, so it's something of a challenge to move a bastard's heart with something that doesn't quite fit in with the zeitgeist.â€¦

Well, that was an unexpected Cat People homage. Ivan Kavanagh's call-back to the paranoid walk down the stone-lined path was pleasing, but more so the ongoing sexual tension between David (Rupert Evans) and Claire (Antonia Campbell-Hughes), however one-sided it may have been for most of the film.Like Cat People, The Canal plumbs the depths of the horrors of marriage, the yawning abyss of which should be pretty familiar to anyone that's been married. It may be that the weakestâ€¦

For the reputation this film has, I was expecting something a little more gonzo. And like a bastard Jeff Lieberman got my hopes up in the initial going with the title sequence. This is probably the high point of the film, so anyone that checks out after the first five minutes can be forgiven. The credits, intercut with seemingly unconnected vignettes of people who you figure are good candidates to snap and coming back repeatedly to an eerie moon shot,â€¦

movietitle: Bad Times at the El Royale
review: A fun fucking yarn. Thatâ€™s pretty much the size of it. Drew Goddard might not have a sizable list of directorial credits, but his extensive work in writing and adaptation has given him a good eye for story and keeping the action paced here. The ability to pull together an ensemble cast certainly doesnâ€™t hurt.On the screen, this is mostly Jeff Bridgesâ€™ film, at the height of his mature career phase powers. Heâ€™s looking rough and weathered enough theseâ€¦

Steven Soderberghâ€™s name doesnâ€™t appear on posters for his movies lately. Itâ€™s always â€œdirector of other films that you may have liked based on your Netflix viewing history.â€ Thatâ€™s fitting, since heâ€™s devolved into something of a generic, socially-conscious PSA content farm, which of course makes him an ideal piece of machinery for the Netflix mines.
