The problem when you decide that youâ€™re going to teach society Important Lessons is that your work becomes boring and facile. Which is whatâ€¦

There were times during this film that I felt I was a guest in someone else's house during a family argument. Lee Chang-dong is well up into the guts of an invasive self-assessment of South Korean society, and some of the stuff that he's digging out doesn't really feel like it's fair to put before a foreign audience. It's extremely difficult to imagine an American filmmaker doing the kind of hard introspection here without any sort of specific political agenda,â€¦

To enjoy horror is to accept as the price of admission a few more genre restrictions and well-worn tropes than the typical film. If you can get past the initial silliness of the found footage format, there's not a whole lot of barriers to enjoyment of Noroi: The Curse.The stronger entries in the found footage canon tend to go lightly on the special effects and CGI, since embracing the cinÃ©ma vÃ©ritÃ© approach means that you're relying on human dramaâ€¦

I don't know what this film wants to be. If it's attempting to be an historical account of a part of the First World War, it didn't achieve that. If it's a showpiece for Peter Jackson's technical prowess, it wasn't that either. The depressing conclusion is They Shall Not Grow Old succeeds best at being a piece of propaganda, and not a particularly convincing one at that.The film's lack of historical grounding is a huge detriment, especially considering itsâ€¦

It's been a while since I've seen a film quite as aggressively awful as Polar. It's always embarrassing to see adults wallow around in a journey borne of a seventh-grade boy's locker, and I kept having flashbacks to Suicide Squad and Wanted. All three films have a cringe-inducing sense of stylistic flourish, a 30 year old virgin's interpretation of sex and relationships, and a total lack of understanding about how to employ violence. The Rob Zombie-inspired dream sequences certainly didn'tâ€¦

What happens when character actors find themselves in an ecosystem lacking in natural predators to keep them in their natural place? The Worldâ€™s Greatest Sinner, apparently.The film is not quite insane enough to make it stick out as an enduring midnight cult piece. The story of Clarence Hilliard (Timothy Carey) is demonstrably less weird than many of the real life examples of cult leaders with political aspirations. Though itâ€™s hard to fault Mr. Carey for that since guys likeâ€¦

As I am nothing close to resembling a professor of film, Iâ€™ll say nothing of the various technical achievements that make up Battleship Potemkin. Itâ€™s all been said before, though the use of montage and tracking shots are clearly ahead of their time to even casual students of cinema. Suffice to say itâ€™s one third of the foundation upon which this edifice, and therefore much of the cinematic world as we know it, rests.Sergei Eisensteinâ€™s eye for arresting imageryâ€¦

Itâ€™s good to remember sometimes, as we bow our heads in thanks for the emergent wave of prestige horror thatâ€™s washed up on our shores, that the genre can be unadulterated fun as well.It would be easy to hate Velvet Buzzsaw if Dan Gilroy ever made the mistake of looking back to see the killer just one step behind him. The world of exhibit art is fish in a barrel when it comes to parody. Any one of theâ€¦

It's easy to see settling into Before I Hang as the second part of the day's feature, munching your popcorn and thinking more about the Blitzkrieg newsreel preceding it than the film itself. Director Nick Grinde churns out a contract-satisfying sci-fi/thriller/horror mad doctor flick, and by all measures it checks the boxes to keep folks in the theater for an afternoon. The film winds up being a pretty standard Karloff vehicle.The unfortunate aspect of the film is that it'sâ€¦

Rami Malek deserved a far less safe avenue for the performance he gave as Freddie Mercury. In portraying the life of one of the eraâ€™s more transgressive public figures, Bryan Singer does what he usually does and delivers a studio sanctioned exercise in adding value to initial investment. Riding dutifully in the clattery old biopic train car, the audience gets the same tired story thatâ€™s been told so many times about so many famous people that they ought to justâ€¦

The infamous ten minute rape scene is where people tend to check out of Irreversible. I understand that temptation. But it was in the first twenty minutes that I almost bailed on this film. Gaspar NoÃ©'s camerawork during this stretch is completely fucking intolerable, and while I do appreciate the dose of self-awareness that comes with the camera travelling up his own ass as it heads into the nightclub, it was almost impossible to watch. I get that it's supposedâ€¦

As I watched this in the theater, I felt like Robert Mitchum in Night of the Hunter. There were parts of this film, or rather undercurrents to the story and why it was made, that roused my hate. But there were other aspects that made me want to push that hatred back into place, and it's a fortunate thing that no one else was in the theater that evening to watch as I arm wrestled myself. The black hole ofâ€¦

I donâ€™t know enough about Viggo Mortensenâ€™s personal life to know if heâ€™s taking roles based on his newfound acquaintance with buckets of chicken and pecan rolls, or if heâ€™s taking the increasingly successful â€œbecome a fat guyâ€ route to Oscar nominations. In any case, Green Book is strangely fixated on how many things the script can cram into Tony Lipâ€™s insatiable maw over the course of the film. Credit it to Peter Farrellyâ€™s DNA-encoded association with bodily functions, Iâ€¦

All respect to Ryan Coogler and Boots Riley, but this is it right here. This is Oaklandcore filmmaking in 2018.The film rests on a tripod. One leg is Carlos LÃ³pez Estrada capturing faithfully, for the first time that Iâ€™m aware of in a major film, the visual spirit of the City of Oakland. One is Daveed Diggs and the way he plays through an incredible range of fear responses throughout, giving this film its constant sense of the otherâ€¦

Thereâ€™s a sentimentality about instituions that stabs a little deeper with each year passing into the modern era. If we were to examine the American judicial system in the manner that Juror 8 (Henry Fonda) examines the case before him, we have to conclude that Sidney Lumetâ€™s portrayal is indeed sentiment. Juries, then and now, routinely deliver flawed verdicts, and no amount of high-minded intent is going to make an all-white, all-male jury an accurate representation of a personâ€™s peers.â€¦

Let's set the scene. At a key moment before embarking on a potentially lethal journey, the handsomely stoic Micah (Anthony Mackie) tells to intrepid scientist Sam Walden (Margaret Qualley) the story of how he let his wife starve to death so that he could survive. An act that he ultimately blames on Sam's father, Dr. Henry Walden (Danny Huston), and Micah apparently traveled hundreds of miles to settle this beef in person, before events lead to him screwing Dr. Walden'sâ€¦

Humphrey Bogart makes a good fucking villain.Nicholas Ray has a keen eye here in using Mr. Bogart's most defining characteristics as a leading man to create one of the more monstrous characters in film noir. His rough-hewn face goes beyond denoting a tough guy and serves as a warning of the unthinking violence simmering underneath. His dissipated charm is a weapon used to devastating effect on Gloria Grahame's Laurel Gray. His sardonic half-smile becomes maniacal when Mr. Ray lightsâ€¦

Leave it to our friends the Italians to spice up the classic Universal monster movie formula. Presaging the envelope pushing that will come to be a defining feature of Italian cinema into the 60s and 70s, Black Sunday (though I prefer the Mask of Satan title) starts off with an appropriately lurid opening sequence before settling back into ye olde standard Dracula-style tale. The camera ghoulishly lingers as Barbara Steele's Asa Vajda is branded with the mark of Satan, beforeâ€¦

You know how they say that you donâ€™t want to see how the sausage gets made? Iâ€™m waiting for someone to tell me that this isnâ€™t how actors actually see themselves. Because if it is Iâ€™ll probably need to substitute my film habit for heroin.It would be one thing if Josephine Decker were making a film on purpose where every single character is an insufferable twit. If it were making some sort of point about something, some observation aboutâ€¦

The testament of why you should always opt for the Criterion version of something if itâ€™s available. I suspect Iâ€™m going to need to rewatch this at some point as my copy of the film is a shitty English dub featuring degraded sound quality and all the visual acuity of a Shanghai street vendorâ€™s stall.That said, the points of interest here are primarily historical. This was Fritz Langâ€™s second sound feature, and he appears to still be getting theâ€¦

This is more a collection of disturbing sequences than a cohesive film, and probably the better for it that way. Director and writer DemiÃ¡n Rugna doesnâ€™t really provide much in the way of contextual undercurrent or depth to his characters, nor do his actors really make much of a lasting impression in performance. The traditional forces of narrative arenâ€™t really on this filmâ€™s side. So why embrace the weaknesses?A skinny humanoid stalks a man at night from under hisâ€¦

First, the superhero genre achieved stability. Technology finally caught up with the visual aspirations and producers finally started giving a shit about scripts in the early 00s. These films were demonstrated to be a solid investment, and savvy marketing and production kept the machine humming through various iterations over the next decade. Now, the machine is so well refined that the next phase seems to be calculated deviations in the core, repeatable story.The focus-group inclusion feel of Spider-Man: Intoâ€¦

The Russians have forgotten more about political cynicism than the rest of the world ever knew. Thus the Soviet Union provides the best possible backdrop for Armando Iannucciâ€™s thing that he does. The British parliamentarian flummoxry that heâ€™s honed so well finds itself grafted successfully to the centuries-old exercise in gallows humor that is Russian government. Itâ€™s hard to imagine where Mr. Iannucci goes from here, because this perhaps the perfect expression of his wish to portray baffled absurdity withâ€¦

The period in America between the end of WWII and the beginning of the larger turbulence of the 1960s is chronically mistreated. The national pastime of aping the appearance of an idealized family unit is constantly confused by modern heads with the act of living in such an idealized family unit. So any successful attempt to cut through the bullshit surrounding this era of history is welcome.These kinds of family stories of the 1950s and early 60s are interiorâ€¦

Whatever it was that made Vietnam what it was, itâ€™s as inexorably part of the American psyche as any other national trait. Jungle as proving ground has become a national ideal, which may say as much about the nation today as anything else.The action blockbuster as it has come to be defined lives within the boundaries set within a select few guideposts, and this film is certainly one of them. And John McTiernan, more than Michael Bay or anyâ€¦

A prime candidate for a remake. Perhaps even by the same director.There's a struggle here between the wonderful cinematic economy of this film and the effective storytelling that follows, and the overall stoned college student feel of the premise. In a sense this is a found footage film, as presented in the intimate, shaky camera work (somewhat unwelcome) and the sense of eeriness intruding into the mundane and escalating (more welcome). Thank Christ someone laid down a blueprint forâ€¦

Sometimes I think it's a shame that English became the de facto language of cinema early on. The Gallic sensibility just works so well with films. Paris and its late night streetlife suffuses everything it touches with its postwar sense of refinement masking an undercurrent of violence. The chaotic traffic, the young pretty people bustling through old neighborhoods toward the New International monoliths at the city center. Even mediocre French films are just so damn cool.This is far fromâ€¦

Thank you, Mimi Leder, for sparing us the now-standard biopic opening where the subject flashes back and forth between their career-defining pivotal moment and an earlier tribulation. Knowing exactly how the first ten minutes of any biopic is going to proceed, regardless of the subject, has made it wearisome to drag myself to watch each one as itâ€™s released, so I appreciated the slight deviation in the format here.Thereâ€™s a temptation here to react overly positively to On theâ€¦

My advice is to turn this off right at the last shot of Steve Carrellâ€™s David Sheff and TimothÃ©e Chalametâ€™s Nic Sheff sitting together in the hospital courtyard. Whatever you thought of the preceding two hours, it will be unsullied by the PSA text at the end, neatly slapping a happy ending onto a story that is bewilderingly held up as an exemplar of addiction. And it will be untainted by the voice of a callow young man reading Bukowskiâ€¦

A film by Federico Fellini is always an unmistakable experience. If you were to conjure him up and assign him a shoot for a dish soap commercial, anyone would see it and just say, "yup, Fellini." The strange circus sensibilities, the fantasy-laden set pieces that can strike at any time, the music. There are few directors today that I can think of that put their stamp on something quite as hard as Mr. Fellini.Juliet of the Spirits marks theâ€¦

You can only watch Hereditary once. The rewatch Iâ€™d been steeling myself for didnâ€™t diminish my first experience or reduce the film in my esteem. But it turns out that you canâ€™t break the same parts of yourself again in this case. That searing experience of first watching it is a one-time deal. Plan accordingly, because you donâ€™t get another shot to be fucked with like this.This film is an act of violence against the viewer that lesser directorsâ€¦

How is that Adam McKay, after trying so very hard to deviate from a traditional form using fourth wall breaking, meta commentary, silly Shakespearean interludes, an in-story narrator, and every other self-satisfied device he could thing of, still manages to shit out the incredibly tired opening to every recent biopic that he does here? I had feared that after seeing the beat-for-beat execution of the cold open to an important moment at the height of the subject's career, cut withâ€¦

Whatâ€™s notable about this film isnâ€™t that it reveals any unknown truths about how most of us come up, though it is firmly rooted in truth. The achievement is hopefully going to be playing a role in replacing the American sense of invulnerability with the understanding that our cities and towns are built on quicksand, ready to swallow anyone up as they struggle.Thatâ€™s a pretty tall fucking order for a personal project about fatherhood and skateboarding. And I doubtâ€¦

A pleasing bit of strangeness pulled out of the Hulu pool filter. Not only that, but a sharp effort from director Peter Strickland, who as a writer displays true knowledge of the essential qualities of his source material. Mr. Strickland strips away the lurid colors, the classical sets, and the copious blood of Argento-inspired Italian horror until all that is left is arguably the most important distinctor; the wanton sound effects and the prog keyboards. Impressive trick.Mr. Strickland hammersâ€¦

movietitle: The Cook, the Thief, His Wife & Her Lover
